div.head: Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS
div.p: Sec. 1-1. - How Code designated and cited. The ordinances embraced in the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated the "Code of Ordinances, City of Quitman, Georgia," and may be so cited. Such Code may also be cited as the "Quitman Code." (Code 1962, § 1-1; Code 1986, § 1-1) State law reference— Codification requirements, O.C.G.A. § 36-80-19. Sec. 1-2. - Definitions and rules of construction. In the construction of this Code and of all ordinances or resolutions, the following definitions and rules shall apply and govern, unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the board of commissioners: Board, board of commissioners, commission, or city commission. The term "board," "board of commissioners," "commission," or "city commission" means the Board of Commissioners of Quitman, Georgia. Bond. When a bond is required by law, an undertaking in writing, without seal, is sufficient, and in all bonds where the names of the obligors do not appear in the bond, but are subscribed thereto, they shall be bound thereby. Charter. The term "Charter" means the Charter of the city, as now existing or as hereafter amended or replaced. City. The term "city" means the City of Quitman, Georgia. Code. The term "Code" means this Code as designated in section 1-1. Commissioner. The term "commissioner" means a member of the board of commissioners. Computation of time. Except as otherwise provided by time period computations specifically applying to other laws, when a period of time measured in days, weeks, months, years, or other measurements of time except, hours is prescribed for the exercise of any privilege or the discharge of any duty, the first day shall not be counted but the last day shall be counted; and, if the last day falls on a Saturday or Sunday, the party having such privilege or duty shall have through the following Monday to exercise the privilege or to discharge the duty. When the last day prescribed for such action falls on a public and legal holiday as set forth in O.C.G.A. § 1-4-1, the party having the privilege or duty shall have through the next business day to exercise the privilege or to discharge the duty. When the period of time prescribed is less than seven days, intermediate Saturdays, Sundays, and legal holidays shall be excluded in the computation. Conjunctions. In a provision involving two or more items, conditions, provisions or events, which items, conditions, provisions or events are connected by the conjunction "and," "or" or "either … or," the conjunction shall be interpreted as follows: (1) "And" indicates that all the connected terms, conditions, provisions or events apply. (2 "Or" indicates that the connected terms, conditions, provisions or events apply singly or in any combination. (3) "Either … or" indicates that the connected terms, conditions, provisions or events apply singly but not in combination. Corporate limits or city limits. The term "corporate limits" or "city limits" means the corporate limits of the City of Quitman. County. The term "county" means Brooks County, Georgia. Court. The term "court" means the court provided by law for the punishment of offenders against the laws or ordinances of the city, whether the same shall be the police court now constituted or a court hereafter established pursuant to law. Delegation of authority. Whenever a provision requires or authorizes the head of a department or an official of the city to do some act or perform some function, it shall be construed to authorize the head of the department or the official to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to do the act or perform the function, unless the terms of the provisions designate otherwise. Gender. The masculine gender shall include the feminine and neuter. 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 15/196 Governing authority or governing body. The term "governing authority" or "governing body" means the board of commissioners of the City of Quitman, Georgia. Joint authority. A joint authority given to any number of persons or officers may be executed by a majority of them, unless it is otherwise declared. Legislative intent. In all interpretations of this Code or of ordinances or resolutions, the courts shall look diligently for the intention of the board of commissioners, keeping in mind at all times the old law, the evil and the remedy. Grammatical errors shall not vitiate any provision, and a transposition of words and phrases may be resorted to when a clause or sentence is without meaning as it stands. May. The term "may" is to be construed as being permissive and not mandatory. May not. The term "may not" states a prohibition. Minimum requirements. In the interpretation and application of any provision of this Code, it shall be held to be the minimum requirement adopted for the promotion of the public health, safety, comfort, convenience and general welfare. Where any provision of this Code imposes greater restrictions upon the subject matter than another more general provision, the provision imposing the greater restriction or regulation shall be deemed controlling. Month and year. The terms "month" and "year" mean a calendar month and calendar year, unless otherwise provided. Must. The term "must" is to be construed as being mandatory. Names of officers, departments. The name of any officer or department shall be read as though the words "of the City of Quitman" were added thereto. Nontechnical and technical words. The ordinary signification shall be applied to all words, except words of art or words connected with a particular trade or subject matter, in which case they shall have the signification attached to them by experts in such trade or with reference to such subject matter. Number. The singular or plural number shall each include the other, unless expressly excluded. Oath. The term "oath" includes affirmation. O.C.G.A. The abbreviation "O.C.G.A.," when used in the text or footnotes in this Code, refers to and means the Official Code of Georgia Annotated. Owner. The term "owner," applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, joint tenant, or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or of a part of such building or land. Person. The term "person" shall extend and be applied to any individual; any corporation, partnership, association or other entity organized under the laws of any state; any state or subdivision or instrumentality of a state; and any employee, agent or legal representative thereof. Preceding and following. The terms "preceding" and "following" mean generally next before and next after, unless the context requires a different signification. Property. The term "property" includes real and personal property. Signature or subscription. The term "signature" or "subscription" include the mark of all illiterate or infirm persons. State. The term "state" or "this state" mean the State of Georgia. Street. The term "street" includes streets, sidewalks, avenues, boulevards, roads, alleys, lanes and all other public highways in the city, unless otherwise provided. Substantial compliance. A substantial compliance with any requirement of this Code or ordinances amendatory thereof, especially on the part of public officers, shall be deemed and held sufficient, and no proceeding shall be declared void for want of such compliance, unless expressly so provided. Tense. The present or past tense shall include the future. Writing. The term "writing" includes printing and all numerals and also pictures, illustrations and printed or written designs. (Code 1962, § 1-2; Code 1986, § 1-2) State law reference— Rules of construction and definitions generally, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-1 et seq. Sec. 1-3. - Catchlines of sections; history notes; references. (a) The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part of the section, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or re-enacted. (b) History notes, cross references and state law references that appear in this Code after sections or subsections or that otherwise appear in footnote form are provided for the convenience of the user of the Code and have no legal effect. (c) Unless specified otherwise, all references to chapters or sections are to chapters or sections of this Code. (Code 1962, § 1-3; Code 1986, § 1-3) State law reference— Historical notes and catchlines of code sections not part of law, O.C.G.A. § 1-1-7. Sec. 1-4. - Effect of repeal of ordinances. The repeal of an ordinance shall not revive any ordinance in force before or at the time the ordinance repealed took effect. The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect, nor any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal, for an offense committed or matter covered under the ordinance repealed. 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 16/196 (Code 1962, § 1-4; Code 1986, § 1-4) Sec. 1-5. - Severability of parts of Code. It is hereby declared to be the intention of the board of commissioners that the sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code is declared unconstitutional, invalid or unenforceable by the valid judgment or decree of a court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality, invalidity or unenforceability shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code, since the same would have been enacted by the commission without the incorporation in the Code of any such unconstitutional phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section. (Code 1962, § 1-5; Code 1986, § 1-5) Sec. 1-6. - Provisions of Code considered as continuations of existing ordinances. The provisions appearing in this Code, so far as they are the same as ordinances adopted prior to and existing at the time of the effective date of this Code and ordinances adopted subsequent to such Code and included herein, shall be considered as continuations thereof and not as new enactments. (Code 1986, § 1-6) Sec. 1-7. - Miscellaneous ordinances not affected by Code. (a) Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect or be construed to repeal or otherwise affect the validity of any of the following: (1) Any ordinance or resolution promising or guaranteeing the payment of money by or for the city or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city or any evidence of the city's indebtedness or any contract or obligation assumed by the city; (2) Any ordinance or resolution granting any franchise or right; (3) Any ordinance or resolution appropriating funds, levying or imposing taxes or relating to an annual budget; (4) Any ordinance or resolution relating to salaries, compensation or bonds of city officers and employees or members of city boards or commissions or to compensation or pay plans or classification plans for such officers or employees; (5) Any ordinance or resolution authorizing, providing for or otherwise relating to any specific public improvement or making any assessment; (6) Any ordinance or resolution annexing territory of the city or otherwise altering the boundaries of the city; (7) Any zoning ordinance or amendments thereto, and any ordinance establishing a board of zoning appeals, board of architectural review, or planning commission, including joint commissions; (8) Any ordinance or resolution dedicating or accepting any subdivision plat or providing for subdivision regulations; (9) Any contract or obligation assumed by the city; (10) Any ordinance or resolution establishing and prescribing employment and personnel policies and procedures; (11) Any ordinance or resolution dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, closing, opening, widening, paving, vacating, etc., any street or public way in the city; (12) Any ordinance or resolution establishing and prescribing the street grades of any street in the city; (13) Any appropriation ordinance; (14) The administrative ordinances or resolutions of the city not in conflict or inconsistent with the provisions of this Code; (15) 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 17/196 Any ordinance or resolution of agreement with another political subdivision; (16) Any ordinance or regulation prescribing traffic regulations for specific locations concerning through streets, parking limitations, parking prohibitions, one-way traffic, limitations on loads of vehicles or loading zones, not in conflict or inconsistent with this Code; (17) Any ordinance or resolution establishing the amount of a fee, fine, rate or charge imposed by the provisions of this Code, or any ordinance contained therein or amendatory thereto; (18) Any ordinance or resolution adopted for purposes which have been consummated; (19) Any ordinance or resolution which is temporary, although general in effect, or special, although permanent in effect; or (20) Any ordinance or resolution establishing, accepting or amending a zoning map, thoroughfare map, or thoroughfare plan. (b) All such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code. (Code 1986, § 1-7) Sec. 1-8. - Code does not affect prior offenses, rights, etc. Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any offense or act committed or done, or any penalty or forfeiture incurred, or any contract or right established or accruing, or any prosecution, suit or proceeding pending or any judgment rendered, on or before the effective date of this Code. (Code 1986, § 1-8) Sec. 1-9. - Amendments to Code. (a) Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code may be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section number of this Code in the following language: "That section ____________ of the Code of Ordinances, City of Quitman, Georgia, is hereby amended to read as follows:…." The new provisions shall then be set out in full as desired. (b) In the event a new section not heretofore existing in the Code is to be added, the following language shall be used: "That the Code of Ordinances, City of Quitman, Georgia, is hereby amended by adding a section to be numbered ____________, which section reads as follows:…." The new section shall then be set out in full as desired. (c) All sections, articles, chapters or provisions desired to be repealed must be specifically repealed by section, article or chapter number, as the case may be. (Code 1962, § 1-6; Code 1986, § 1-9) Sec. 1-10. - Supplementation of Code. (a) By contract or by municipal personnel, supplements to this Code shall be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the board of commissioners. A supplement to the Code shall include all substantive permanent and general parts of ordinances adopted during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code. The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages which have become obsolete or partially obsolete, and the new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of the adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. (b) In preparing a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code which have been repealed or replaced shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. (c) When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier, meaning the person, agency or organization authorized to prepare the supplement, may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified Code. For example, the codifier may: (1) Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions; (2) 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 18/196 Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement, and make changes in such catchlines, headings and titles; (3) Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers; (4) Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections ____________ to ____________," inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code; (5) Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinance sections inserted in the Code; but in no case shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code. (Code 1962, § 1-6; Code 1986, § 1-10) Sec. 1-11. - Altering Code. It shall be unlawful for any person to change or amend, by additions or deletions, any part or portion of this Code or to insert or delete pages or portions thereof or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the city to be misrepresented thereby. (Code 1962, § 1-7; Code 1986, § 1-11) Sec. 1-12. - General penalty; collection of fines; continuing violations. (a) In this section, "violation of this Code" means any of the following: (1) Doing an act that is prohibited or made or declared unlawful, an offense, a violation or a misdemeanor by ordinance or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance. (2) Failure to perform an act that is required to be performed by ordinance or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance. (3) Failure to perform an act if the failure is prohibited or is made or declared unlawful, an offense, a violation or a misdemeanor by ordinance or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance. (b) Whenever in this Code or in any ordinance of the city any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense, or whenever in such Code or ordinance the doing of an act is required or the failure to do an act is declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty is provided therefor, the violation of any such provision of this Code or any ordinance shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00, imprisonment in the city or county jail, not to exceed six months, and to work upon the streets or other public places as the board of commissioners or chief of police may designate, not to exceed six months. Any one or more of these punishments may be inflicted by the court in its discretion and the fine imposed may be collected by execution. (c) Except as otherwise provided by law or ordinance: (1) With respect to violations of this Code that are continuous with respect to time, each day that the violation continues is a separate offense. (2) With respect to other violations, each act constitutes a separate offense. (d) The imposition of a penalty does not prevent suspension or revocation of a license, permit or franchise or other administrative sanctions. (e) Violations of this Code that are continuous with respect to time are a public nuisance and may be abated by injunctive or other equitable relief. The imposition of a penalty does not prevent injunctive relief. (Code 1962, § 1-8; Code 1986, § 1-12) State law reference— Maximum sentences and fines which may be imposed for violation of municipal ordinance, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-6(a)(2).

div.head: Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION
div.p: FOOTNOTE(S): (2) State Law reference— Supplemental powers of municipalities and counties enumerated, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III; powers of municipal corporations generally, O.C.G.A. §§ 36-34-2, 36-35-3. 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 19/196 ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL Secs. 2-1—2-18. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS Sec. 2-19. - General powers. The board of commissioners shall have full power and authority to pass ordinances, levy taxes, make appropriations, fix licenses and ratify the election and employment of all officers, agents and employees of the city, together with the right to fix the term of office and employment, prescribe the duties, fix the compensation and ratify the discharge from service, without cause or notice, of any city officer, employee or agent, and to designate the office and employment by such name as it deems expedient. (Code 1962, § 2-18; Code 1986, § 2-16) Sec. 2-20. - General powers and duties of chairperson. The chairperson of the board of commissioners shall be the chief executive officer of the city and shall preside at all meetings of the board. The chairperson shall direct the business of the meeting, keep order, put all questions to be voted upon, and in case of a tie, cast the controlling vote. He or she may, at his or her discretion, suspend all necessary debates and command silence whenever he or she may deem needful. (Code 1962, § 2-19; Code 1986, § 2-17) Sec. 2-21. - Duties of chairperson pro tem. In case of the absence or disqualification of the chairperson of the board of commissioners or of a vacancy in that office, the chairperson pro tem shall perform and discharge all routine duties of the chairperson. (Code 1962, § 2-20; Code 1986, § 2-18) Sec. 2-22. - Time and place of regular meetings. Regular meetings of the board of commissioners shall be on the first Tuesday of each month, in the city hall or such other place as the board may designate, at 7:00 p.m. (Code 1962, § 2-21; Code 1986, § 2-19; Ord. No. 217, 1-17-1977; Ord. No. 253, 1-12-1981; Ord. No. 281, 4-5-1983; Ord. No. 374, §§ 1, 2, 10-12-1989; Ord. No. 512, 4- 6-2004) State law reference— Meetings of political subdivisions, departments, agencies, etc., to be open to public; notice of meetings and agenda, O.C.G.A. § 50-14-1 et seq. Sec. 2-23. - Extra sessions. The chairperson of the board of commissioners shall have power to convene the board in extra session whenever, in his or her judgment, it becomes necessary. (Code 1962, § 2-19; Code 1986, § 2-20) Sec. 2-24. - Duty of commissioners to attend meetings. It shall be the duty of each commissioner to attend regularly all meetings of the board. (Code 1962, § 2-18; Code 1986, § 2-21) Sec. 2-25. - Annual appointment of officers and employees. At the first regular meeting of each year, the board of commissioners shall appoint the following officers and employees: (1) Chairperson of the board of commissioners. (2) City manager. (3) City clerk. (4) City treasurer. (5) City attorney. (6) Police chief. (7) Fire chief. (8) Building inspector. 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 20/196 (9) Electrical inspector. (10) Gas inspector. (11) Plumbing inspector. (Code 1962, § 2-22; Code 1986, § 2-22) Sec. 2-26. - Order of business at regular meetings. The following shall be the order of business at all regular meetings of the board of commissioners: (1) Reading the minutes of the last meeting, amendment and correction of the same, when necessary, and approval of the same; provided, however, that unless a reading of such minutes is requested by a commission member, they may be approved without a reading, if the city clerk has previously furnished each member with a copy thereof. (2) Presentation of petitions and communications. (3) Consideration of items on the agenda for the meeting in the order listed on such agenda. (4) Miscellaneous business. (5) Adjournment. (Code 1962, §§ 2-23, 2-29; Code 1986, § 2-23; Ord. No. 221, 10-7-1979) Sec. 2-27. - Entry to be made on approved minutes. Upon approval of the minutes of a meeting of the board of commissioners, the city clerk shall enter upon such minutes the date of the reading, if any, and approval of the same, and such entry shall be signed by the clerk and by the chairperson or chairperson pro tem of the board. (Code 1962, § 2-29; Code 1986, § 2-24) Sec. 2-28. - Rules of order. The following rules of order shall govern the conduct of meetings of the board of commissioners: (1) Every question of order shall be decided by the chair without debate, and the chair may call for the sense of the board on any question of order. (2) Each member of the board, when about to speak, shall respectfully address the chair, and no person shall speak more than twice on the same subject matter unless by unanimous consent of the board or to make an explanation. (3) Whenever the chairperson shall desire to address the board on the merits of any question before it, or to vacate the chair for any temporary purpose, he or she shall call upon some other member to fill his or her place during such vacation. (4) On an amendment being moved, a member who has spoken on the main question may speak again on the amendment. (5) When a question has been moved and been put by the chair in the affirmative and negative, it becomes a full question and cannot be debated afterwards unless under motion of reconsideration. (6) No motion for adjournment can be made by a member when another is speaking. (7) When a question is under debate, no motion shall be received but to adjourn, to lie on the table, for the previous question, to postpone to a day certain, to amend or to postpone indefinitely, which several motions shall have precedence in the order they stand arranged and the motion for adjournment shall always be in order and be decided without debate except as provided in subsection (6) of this section. (8) 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 21/196 Any matter or question will be tabled at the request of any member. (9) When a proper motion is made, but information is wanted, the proper motion is to postpone to a day certain. (10) When a matter is claiming present attention, but it is desired to reserve it for a more suitable occasion, the order is to "lie on the table." It may then be called for at any time. (11) The question is to be put first on the affirmative and then on the negative. (12) When any question before the board is decided by vote, the yeas and nays shall be recorded. (13) When a question has been made and carried in the affirmative or negative, it shall be in order for any member of the majority to move for the reconsideration thereof, but no motion for the reconsideration of any vote shall be in order after a bill, resolution, amendment or motion upon which the vote was taken has gone out of the possession of the board. (14) The consequences of a measure may be reprobated in strong terms, but to question the motives of those who propose to advocate it is a personal attack and out of order. (15) All reports, petitions and resolutions must be submitted to the board in writing. (16) Except as otherwise provided in this section or elsewhere in this Code, meetings of the board shall be governed by Robert's Rules of Order. (Code 1962, § 2-24; Code 1986, § 2-25) Sec. 2-29. - Interested commissioners not to vote. No commissioner shall be allowed to vote on any claim against the city which he or she presents or proffers in his or her own name, or in which he or she may be directly or indirectly interested. Where the private interests of a commissioner are concerned in a bill or question, he or she shall withdraw, and when such interest has appeared, his or her vote shall be disallowed, even after a decision. (Code 1962, § 2-25; Code 1986, § 2-26) State law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 36-30-6. Sec. 2-30. - Procedure for enacting ordinances. (a) When an ordinance or addition to or amendment of an ordinance is submitted to the board, it shall be read once at the meeting when offered, or twice, should the board, by unanimous consent, suspend the rules for that purpose. It shall then lie over to the next regular meeting, at which, if two readings were heard at the meeting when it was submitted, the board may take final action thereon, but no ordinance or addition, alteration or amendment thereof shall be passed until it has been read three times. (b) Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (a) of this section, if all members of the board are present and give unanimous consent thereto, any ordinance or addition to or amendment of an ordinance may be read three times at such meeting and the board may take final action thereon, either passing or rejecting the same. Also, by unanimous consent of all members of the board, an ordinance or addition to or amendment of an ordinance may be so read and passed at a called or special meeting of the board at which all members are present. (c) Notwithstanding the provisions of subsections (a) and (b) of this section, should a member of the board of commissioners be unable to perform his or her duties for 30 consecutive days, performance of duties being unable to attend any regular or called meeting of the board of commissioners due to illness, either mental or physical, and a certification by the commissioner's attending physician or a written notarized statement by the commissioner who is unable to perform his or her duties is presented to the city clerk and placed in the official minutes of the city attesting to the fact of the disability and that the disability shall continue for an additional period of time not yet determined, then, by a unanimous vote of the remaining four members of the board of commissioners, the rules may be waived at a special or called meeting, and an ordinance be read three times and adopted. Further, should a member of the board of commissioners be unable to attend a regularly scheduled or called meeting, then a written statement to the effect that the absent member wishes to vote affirmatively to waive the rules to allow a particular ordinance to be read three times at said meeting shall be deemed acceptable to allow the rules to be waived if all other commissioners vote to waive the rules. This will allow the reading of an ordinance three times and its adoption at a regular or called meeting. (Code 1962, § 2-26; Code 1986, § 2-27; Ord. No. 371, 8-25-1989) Sec. 2-31. - Recording and indexing of ordinances and resolutions. (a) The clerk shall keep a well bound, substantial book to be known as the ordinance book in which he or she shall record, in the order in which they are passed, all ordinances of the board. He or she shall keep another such book, to be known as the resolution book, in which he or she shall record, in the order in which they are passed, all resolutions of the board. 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 22/196 (b) Ordinances and resolutions recorded pursuant to this section shall be numbered consecutively, in the order of their passage, and the city clerk shall enter thereon the date of passage and whether at a regular or called meeting. Such entry shall be signed by the clerk and by the chairperson or chairperson pro tem of the board. (c) The city clerk shall keep an index, by subject matter, of all ordinances and resolutions of the board. (Code 1962, § 2-27; Code 1986, § 2-28) Sec. 2-32. - Minute entries for ordinances and resolutions. It shall not be necessary to enter upon the minutes in full the contents of any ordinance or resolution introduced to or passed by the board, but such minutes shall describe briefly the nature of the ordinance or resolution and the minutes of the meeting at which an ordinance or resolution is passed shall further describe the same by the number it bears in the ordinance or resolution book, such description being given as "Ordinance (or Resolution) No. (giving the number thereof)." (Code 1962, § 2-28; Code 1986, § 2-29) Sec. 2-33. - Presumption as to legal passage of ordinance or resolution. When the minutes of a meeting of the board of commissioners have been signed as provided in section 2-27, and contain therein the record of the passage of an ordinance or resolution and its number, and the ordinance or resolution has been entered in the appropriate book and the entry has been signed as provided in section 2-32, it shall be conclusively presumed that such ordinance or resolution was regularly and legally passed, and no evidence shall be offered to deny the fact of the regular and legal passage of such ordinance or resolution. (Code 1962, § 2-30; Code 1986, § 2-30) Secs. 2-34—2-54. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - CITY CLERK AND TREASURER Sec. 2-55. - Offices consolidated. The offices of city clerk and city treasurer are hereby consolidated and the person performing the duties incident to such offices shall be known as the city clerk and treasurer. Wherever in this Code or any ordinance of the city the terms "city clerk" or "city treasurer" is used, they shall be construed as meaning the city clerk and treasurer. (Code 1962, § 2-6; Code 1986, § 2-41) Sec. 2-56. - Bond. Before entering upon the duties of his or her office, the city clerk and treasurer shall give a good and sufficient bond, in a sum as established by ordinance of the board of commissioners from time to time, payable to the city and conditioned upon the faithful discharge of his or her duties. (Code 1962, § 2-7; Code 1986, § 2-42) Sec. 2-57. - General duties. It shall be the duty of the city clerk and treasurer: (1) To attend all meetings of the board of commissioners and record the minutes thereof in a book kept for that purpose. (2) To issue all summonses, processes and subpoenas for the attendance of witnesses ordered by the chairperson of the board of commissioners, and all such summonses, processes and subpoenas shall be signed by him or her and bear teste in the name of the chairperson. (3) To issue all licenses and make a record of the same. (4) To perform such other duties as are prescribed by the board or by this Code or other ordinance. (Code 1962, § 2-8; Code 1986, § 2-43) Sec. 2-58. - Duties with respect to receipt and disbursement of funds. It shall be the duty of the city clerk and treasurer to receive all funds due the city and pay out the same upon checks signed by him or her and countersigned as prescribed in section 50 of the Charter and to keep regular books showing his or her receipts and disbursements. (Code 1962, § 2-8; Code 1986, § 2-44) Sec. 2-59. - Books and accounts subject to examination by commissioners. The books and accounts of the city clerk and treasurer shall at all times be open to the commissioners for examination. (Code 1962, § 2-8; Code 1986, § 2-45) Secs. 2-60—2-76. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - CITY ATTORNEY 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 23/196 Sec. 2-77. - Appointment and term. The city attorney shall be appointed as provided in section 2-25, and he or she shall hold office only during the pleasure of the board of commissioners. (Code 1962, § 2-10; Code 1986, § 2-56) Sec. 2-78. - Compensation. The compensation for the services of the city attorney shall be fixed by the board of commissioners at the time of his or her appointment. (Code 1962, § 2-10; Code 1986, § 2-57) Sec. 2-79. - Duties. It shall be the duty of the city attorney to give to the board of commissioners or the city manager his or her written opinion touching any legal question involving the interest of the city, when such question is submitted in writing, together with the facts involved. It shall also be his or her duty to represent the city in the prosecution of all criminal causes in the police court, when requested by the chairperson of the board of commissioners, and he or she shall represent the city in all suits to which it is a party. (Code 1962, § 2-10; Code 1986, § 2-58) Secs. 2-80—2-101. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - PERSONNEL MANAGEMENT SYSTEM Sec. 2-102. - Adoption by reference. The employment rules, regulations, and standards for employees of the city shall be as set forth in the document entitled the Personnel Policies of the City of Quitman, which is hereby adopted by reference in its entirety and incorporated into this Code as if fully set out herein. A copy of this document is available for public examination in the office of the city clerk. (Code 1986, § 2-73; Ord. No. 215, art. IV, 9-13-1976; Ord. No. 452, § 2, 1-29-1996) Secs. 2-103—2-132. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - RETIREMENT BENEFITS FOR CITY PERSONNEL FOOTNOTE(S): (3) State Law reference— Authority to establish retirement systems for municipal employees, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(14), O.C.G.A. § 36-34-2(4); authority of municipality to provide insurance, retirement and pension benefits, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-4; social security coverage for employees of the state and political subdivisions of the state, O.C.G.A. § 47-18-1 et seq.; Georgia municipal employees benefit system, O.C.G.A. § 47-5-1 et seq. DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY Sec. 2-133. - Joint municipal employees retirement system. The contract attached to Ordinance No. 396 and on file in the office of the city clerk, between the city and the Joint Municipal Employees Retirement System, as provided by O.C.G.A. § 47-5-1 et seq., as amended, is hereby adopted and ratified by the city. (Code 1986, § 2-96; Ord. No. 258, 6-4-1981; Ord. No. 396, 2-5-1991) Secs. 2-134—2-164. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - SOCIAL SECURITY Sec. 2-165. - Extension of benefits. It is hereby declared to be the policy and purpose of the city to extend, at the earliest date possible under the agreement entered into by the state and the Federal Social Security Administration, to the employees and officials of the city and its instrumentalities, not excluded by law or by this division, the benefits of the system of Old Age and Survivor's Insurance, as authorized by the Federal Social Security Act, the state enabling act and amendments thereto. In pursuance of said policy, and for that purpose, the city shall take such action as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. (Code 1962, § 2-1[a]; Code 1986, § 2-106) Sec. 2-166. - Execution of agreements for coverage. (a) The chairperson of the board of commissioners is hereby authorized and directed to execute all necessary agreements and amendments thereto with the Employees' Retirement System of Georgia for coverage of employees and officials referred to in section 2-165, including employees that are in positions covered by a public retirement system, in the manner provided by law. (b) There is hereby excluded from this section any authority to make any agreement with respect to any position or any employee or official not authorized to be covered by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. (Code 1962, § 2-1[b], [f]; Code 1986, § 2-107) Sec. 2-167. - Withholdings. Withholdings from salaries or wages of employees and officials for the purpose provided for in section 2-165 are hereby authorized to be made in the amounts and at such times as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations and shall be paid over to the state agency. (Code 1962, § 2-1[c]; Code 1986, § 2-108) Sec. 2-168. - Contributions by city. 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 24/196 There shall be appropriated from the general operating funds of the city such amounts at such times as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations for employer's contributions, administrative expenses and a guaranty fund to assure that the state will not incur any debt or loss as a result of the agreement referred to in section 2-166. Such funds shall be paid over to the Employees' Retirement System of Georgia in accordance with regulations established by such agency. (Code 1962, § 2-1[d]; Code 1986, § 2-109) Sec. 2-169. - Records and reports. The city shall keep such records and make such reports as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations concerning the city's participation in the federal social security system. (Code 1962, § 2-1[e]; Code 1986, § 2-110) Sec. 2-170. - Release of escrow deposits. The chairperson of the board of commissioners is hereby authorized and directed to execute an agreement amending the original plan and agreement with the Employees' Retirement System of Georgia, in substantially the form attached to Ordinance No. 123 as exhibit A, providing for the release of social security escrow deposits. (Code 1962, § 2-1.1; Code 1986, § 2-111) Secs. 2-171—2-193. - Reserved. ARTICLE VII. - BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY Sec. 2-194. - Boards established. There are hereby established the following boards and commissions: (1) The park commission. (2) The recreation commission. (3) The board of trustees of the public library. Secs. 2-195—2-211. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - QUITMAN PLANNING COMMISSION Sec. 2-212. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Planning commission or commission means the Quitman Planning Commission created in this division. (Code 1986, § 2-126) Sec. 2-213. - Created; composition; qualifications and appointment of members. The Quitman Planning Commission is hereby created. The commission shall consist of three members who shall be residents of the city and who shall be appointed by the board of commissioners. (Code 1986, § 2-127) Sec. 2-214. - Terms of members; filling of vacancies. Members of the commission shall be appointed for terms of three years. Any vacancy in membership shall be filled for the unexpired term by appointment by the board of commissioners. (Code 1986, § 2-128) Sec. 2-215. - Compensation of members. Members of the planning commission shall serve without compensation, but may be reimbursed for actual expenses incurred in the performance of their duties. (Code 1986, § 2-129) Sec. 2-216. - Removal of members. The board of commissioners shall have the authority to remove any member of the planning commission for cause, on written charges, and after a public hearing. (Code 1986, § 2-130) Sec. 2-217. - Election and terms of officers. (a) The planning commission shall elect a chairperson and vice-chairperson for its membership. The term of such officers shall be for one year or until they are reelected or their successors are elected. 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 25/196 (b) The planning commission shall appoint a secretary, who may be an officer or employee of the city or of the commission. (Code 1986, § 2-131) Sec. 2-218. - Powers and duties. The planning commission is hereby vested with all the powers, duties and responsibilities set forth in the General Planning and Zoning Enabling Act of 1957 (1957 Ga. Laws (Act. No. 358), page. 420), as amended, notwithstanding the repeal thereof as general law. (Code 1986, § 2-132) Sec. 2-219. - Meetings; rules of procedure. (a) The planning commission shall meet at least once each month at the call of the chairperson and at such other times as the chairperson or the board of commissioners may determine and shall adopt rules for the transaction of business. (b) All meetings of the planning commission at which official action is taken shall be open to the public. (Code 1986, § 2-133) Sec. 2-220. - Assistance from city employees; appointment of employees and staff; procurement of professional assistance. The planning commission shall be entitled to receive such assistance from the employees of the city as it shall request and shall be authorized to appoint such employees and staff and to secure such professional assistance on a fulltime or parttime basis as it may, in its discretion, deem necessary or appropriate; provided that the expenditures therefor shall not be in excess of such amounts as are appropriated therefor by the board of commissioners. (Code 1986, § 2-134) Sec. 2-221. - Cooperative undertakings and contracts; acceptance and expenditure of funds. In the performance of its duties, the planning commission may cooperate with, contract with or accept funds from federal, state or local public or semipublic agencies or private individuals or corporations, may expend such funds and may carry out cooperative undertakings and contracts. It may make expenditures for the purchase of required equipment and supplies. (Code 1962, § 18-8; Code 1986, § 2-135) State law reference— Requirement that local government officials divulge any property, financial, or familial interest in a matter affected by a rezoning action which that official's local government will have a duty to consider, O.C.G.A. § 36-67A-2. Sec. 2-222. - Records. The commission shall keep a record of its resolutions, transactions, findings and determinations. All such records shall be kept in the custody of the city clerk and shall be public records. (Code 1986, § 2-136) Secs. 2-223—2-252. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - QUITMAN-BROOKS COUNTY PLANNING COMMISSION Sec. 2-253. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Planning commission or commission means the Quitman-Brooks County Planning Commission created in this division. (Code 1962, § 2-61; Code 1986, § 2-151) Sec. 2-254. - Created; purpose. In order to guide and accomplish a coordinated and harmonious development of the city and county which will, in accordance with existing and future needs, best promote public health, safety, morals, order, convenience, prosperity and the general welfare, as well as efficiency and economy in the process of development, the QuitmanBrooks County Planning Commission, is hereby created and established. (Code 1962, § 2-61; Code 1986, § 2-152) Sec. 2-255. - Composition; qualifications and appointment of employees. The planning commission shall consist of six members. Three of the members shall be residents of the city and appointed by the board of commissioners of the city and three of the members shall be residents of the county and appointed by the board of commissioners. (Code 1962, § 2-62; Code 1986, § 2-153) Sec. 2-256. - Terms of members; filling of vacancies. The terms of the members of the planning commission shall be for four years. Any vacancy in a city-appointed membership shall be filled for the unexpired term by the board of commissioners. (Code 1962, § 2-62; Code 1986, § 2-154) 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 26/196 Sec. 2-257. - Compensation of members. All members of the planning commission shall serve without compensation but may be reimbursed for actual expenses incurred in connection with their official duties. (Code 1962, § 2-62; Code 1986, § 2-155) Sec. 2-258. - Removal of members. The board of commissioners shall have the authority to remove any city-appointed member of the planning commission for cause, on written charges and after a public hearing. (Code 1962, § 2-62; Code 1986, § 2-156) Sec. 2-259. - Officers. The planning commission shall elect its chairperson from among its members. The term of the chairperson shall be one year, with eligibility for reelection. The commission shall appoint a secretary, who may be an officer or employee of the city or the county. (Code 1962, § 2-63; Code 1986, § 2-157) Sec. 2-260. - General powers and duties. The planning commission shall have all the powers, duties and responsibilities set forth in the General Planning and Zoning Enabling Act of 1957 (1957 Ga. Laws (Act. No. 358), page. 420), as amended, notwithstanding the repeal thereof as general law. (Code 1962, § 2-64; Code 1986, § 2-158) Sec. 2-261. - Rules of procedure; meetings; records. The planning commission shall make its own rules of procedure and determine the time of its meetings. All meetings of the commission at which official action is taken shall be open to the public and all records of the commission shall be public records. (Code 1962, § 2-63; Code 1986, § 2-159) Sec. 2-262. - Appointment of employees and staff; contracts for services. The planning commission may appoint such employees and staff as it may deem necessary for its work and may contract with the state planning agency and with city planners and other consultants for such services as it may require. (Code 1962, § 2-63; Code 1986, § 2-160) Sec. 2-263. - Limitation on expenditures. The expenditures of the planning commission, exclusive of gifts, shall be within the amounts appropriated for the purpose by the governing authorities of the city and the county. (Code 1962, § 2-63; Code 1986, § 2-161) Secs. 2-264—2-289. - Reserved. DIVISION 4. - GREATER BROOKS PLANNING COMMISSION Sec. 2-290. - Purpose. (a) This division establishes and provides for the Greater Brooks Planning Commission, which enables the city and the county to jointly implement the 2010 Greater Brooks County Comprehensive Plan. (b) In order to guide and accomplish a coordinated and harmonious development of the city and county which will, in accordance with existing and future needs found in adopted and amended comprehensive plans, best promote public health, safety, morals, order, convenience, prosperity and the general welfare, as well as efficiency and economy in the process of development, that the Greater Brooks Planning Commission, hereafter referred to as the planning commission, is hereby created and established, and said planning commission shall be organized and empowered according to the provisions of this division. (Ord. No. 448, 10-3-1995) Sec. 2-291. - Membership. The Greater Brooks Planning Commission shall consist of 11 members. The county will have five members; the city will have three members; and the cities of Barwick, Morven and Pavo will each have one member. The terms of the members shall be for four years. Any vacancy in membership shall be filled for the unexpired term by the unit of government which shall also have the authority to remove any appointed member for cause, on written charges, after a public hearing. All members shall serve without compensation but may be reimbursed for actual expenses incurred in connection with their official duties. (Ord. No. 448, § 1, 10-3-1995) Sec. 2-292. - Organization, rules, staff, and finances. The Greater Brooks Planning Commission shall elect its chairperson and vice-chairperson from among its members. The term of the chairperson and vice-chairperson shall be one year with eligibility for reelection. The planning commission shall appoint a secretary who may be an officer or employee of the city or the county. The planning commission shall adopt its own rules of procedure and determine its time of meeting. All meetings of the planning commission shall be open to the public and all records of the planning commission shall be a public record. The planning commission may appoint such employees and staff as it may deem necessary for its work and may contract with public or private consultants for such services as it may require. The expenditures of the planning commission, exclusive of gifts, shall be within the amounts appropriated for the purposes by the governing authorities of the cities and the county. 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 27/196 (Ord. No. 448, § 2, 10-3-1995) Sec. 2-293. - Powers and duties. From and after the time when the planning commission shall have been organized and selected its officers, and shall have adopted its rules of procedure, then said planning commission shall function only in an advisory capacity to each of the respective governing authorities and perform such additional functions and services for and on behalf of each governmental entity as shall be authorized or directed from time to time by the governing authority thereof. The Greater Brooks Planning Commission duties and responsibilities shall include, but not be limited to, the following: (1) To research, review, conduct hearings and make recommendations to the appropriate board and councils on updates and amendment to the 2010 Greater Brooks County Comprehensive Plan. (2) To work with various public and private organizations and agencies engaged in or interested in planning and development activities so as to provide leadership in identifying and implementing city and county goals and policies for planning and development. (3) To advise member units of government on environmental, public health, safety and general welfare matters which will include advisory recommendations of land development codes and ordinances. (Ord. No. 448, § 3, 10-3-1995) Secs. 2-294—2-314. - Reserved. DIVISION 5. - COASTAL PLAINS AREA PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION Sec. 2-315. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Planning and development commission or commission means the Coastal Plains Area Planning and Development Commission created in this division. (Code 1986, § 2-176) Sec. 2-316. - Created; purpose. In cooperation with the governing authorities of other area municipalities and counties, in order to guide and accomplish a coordinated and harmonious development of the city and the coastal plains area of the state which will, in accordance with existing and future needs, best promote public health, safety, morals, order, convenience, prosperity and the general welfare, as well as efficiency and economy in the process of development, the Coastal Plains Area Planning and Development Commission is hereby created and established. (Code 1962, § 2-51; Code 1986, § 2-177) Sec. 2-317. - Composition; appointment of members. The planning and development commission shall consist of two members from each of the counties participating in the coastal plains area planning commission. Of such two members from each county, one shall be appointed by the governing authority of the municipality wherein the county seat is located, or by the governing authorities of participating municipalities within such county, and the other members shall be appointed by the governing authority of such county. (Code 1962, § 2-52; Code 1986, § 2-178) Sec. 2-318. - Terms of removal of members; filling of vacancies. The term of office for all members of the commission shall be five years. Any vacancy in the membership shall be filled for the unexpired term by the governing authority making the appointment which has become vacant. The appointing authority shall also have the power to remove any member it may appoint for cause, on written charges, and after a public hearing. (Code 1962, § 2-53; Code 1986, § 2-179) Sec. 2-319. - Compensation. All members of the commission shall serve without compensation. (Code 1962, § 2-53; Code 1986, § 2-180) Sec. 2-320. - Officers. The commission shall elect a chairperson and vice-chairperson from among its appointive members. The term of office of the chairperson and vice-chairperson shall be for one year or until reelected or their successors are elected. The commissions shall appoint a secretary who may be an employee of the commission. (Code 1962, § 2-54; Code 1986, § 2-181) Sec. 2-321. - General powers and duties. It shall be the function and duty of the commission to make such careful and comprehensive surveys and studies of existing conditions and probable future development and to prepare such plans for physical, social and economic growth as will best promote the public health, safety, morals, convenience, prosperity and the general welfare, as well as efficiency and economy, in the development of the entire coastal plains area of the state and each political subdivision therein. In general, the commission shall have the powers, duties and responsibilities set forth in the General Planning and Enabling Act of 1957 (1957 Ga. Laws (Act. No. 358), page. 420), as amended, notwithstanding the repeal thereof as general law. (Code 1962, § 2-55; Code 1986, § 2-182) 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 28/196 Sec. 2-322. - Meetings, rules of procedure and records. The commission shall meet at least once each month at the call of the chairperson and at such other times as the chairperson or the board of commissioners may determine, shall adopt rules for the transaction of business and shall keep a record of its resolutions, transactions, findings and determinations, which record shall be a public record. (Code 1962, § 2-54; Code 1986, § 2-183) Sec. 2-323. - Appointment of employees and staff; cooperative undertakings and contracts; etc. The commission may appoint such employees and staff as it deems necessary for its work. In the performance of its duties, the commission may cooperate with, contract with or accept funds from federal, state or local public or semipublic agencies or private individuals or corporations, may spend such funds and may carry out such cooperative undertakings and contracts. It may make expenditures for the purchase of required equipment and supplies. (Code 1962, § 2-54; Code 1986, § 2-184) Sec. 2-324. - Limitation on expenditures. The expenditures of the commission, exclusive of gifts to the commission and contract receipts, shall be within the amounts appropriated for the purpose by the participating governing authorities. (Code 1962, § 2-54; Code 1986, § 2-185; Ord. No. 482, § 16, 4-6-1999)

div.head: Chapter 4 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES
div.p: FOOTNOTE(S): (4) State Law reference— Georgia Alcoholic Beverage Code, O.C.G.A. § 3-1-1 et seq.; prohibition of furnishing alcoholic beverages to, purchase and possession of alcoholic beverages by persons under 21 years of age, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-23; authority to adopt rules and regulations relating to manufacture, sale and distribution of distilled spirits, O.C.G.A. § 3-4-49; no decal, stamp, or other marking required on malt beverage containers designating the particular municipality in which a sale of malt beverages is made or in which resides a licensed retailer, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-82. ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL Sec. 4-1. - Definitions. (a) The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Beer means any malt beverage. Fortified wines, as defined in this article, are classed as liquor. License means the authorization by the governing authority of the city to engage in the sale of distilled spirits or alcoholic beverages by the drink on the premises. Licensee means a person, real or artificial, holding any class of license issued under the terms of this division. Lounge means a separate room connected with a part of and adjacent to the licensed premises of a restaurant and/or its adjacent lobby or reception area, with all booths, stools and tables being open to view only from within the lounge. All lounges shall have a seating capacity for at least 20 persons. All access and all exits to and from the lounge shall open into the restaurant and/or lobby or reception area adjoining the restaurant except that emergency exits or doors solely for service or delivery personnel are authorized. Manufacturer means a producer or bottler of beer, wine or distilled spirits. Premises means the definite closed or partitioned-in locality, whether a room, shop or building, wherein distilled spirits are sold. Private club means an organization existing under the laws of the state or a charter from a state or national parent organization and having a tax-exempt status under section 501 of the U.S. IRS Code, having at least 50 members regularly paying monthly, quarterly, semiannual or annual dues, organized and operated exclusively for pleasure, recreation and other nonprofitable purposes, owning, hiring or leasing a building or space therein for the reasonable use of its members with suitable kitchen and dining room space and equipment for cooking, preparing and serving meals for its members or guests; provided that no member or officer, agent or employee of the club is paid or directly receives, in the form of a salary or other compensation, any profits from the sale of alcoholic beverages to the club or its member or guests beyond the amount of such salary as may be fixed by its members at any annual meeting or by its governing board out of the general revenue of the club. Private residence means a house, dwelling or building wherein not less than one family customarily resides. Restaurant means any public place kept, used, maintained, advertised and held out to the public as a place where meals are actually and regularly prepared and served at any time when mixed drinks are sold or served; provided, however, that a restaurant shall not be required to serve food after 10:00 p.m., and mixed drinks shall not be sold or serve at any time not allowed by this chapter. Retail beer dealer means any person who engages in selling beer within the corporate limits of the city at retail only to consumers and any person serving beer only to consumers for a pecuniary consideration within the corporate limits of the city. Retail sale means selling or offering for sale alcoholic beverages to any member of the public by pouring for on-the-premises consumption. School means only such state, county, city or other schools as teach the subjects commonly taught in the common schools of this state and shall not include private schools where only specialized subjects such as law, stenography, business, music, art, medicine, dentistry, vocational occupations and other special subjects are taught. Wholesale beer dealer means any person who sells beer to other wholesale dealers or to retail beer dealers. 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 29/196 Wholesaler means any person, engaged in distribution or selling to retailers for the purpose of resale any alcoholic beverages as defined herein. ARTICLE II. - RETAIL BEER DEALER'S LICENSE FOOTNOTE(S): (5) State Law reference— Local license required, O.C.G.A. §§ 3-3-2, 3-5-40 et seq. Sec. 4-39. - Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of a retail beer dealer except under a license issued pursuant to this article. (Code 1962, § 3-3; Code 1986, § 3-26) Sec. 4-40. - Filing and contents of application. A written application for a retail beer dealer's license shall be filed with the city clerk, which application shall contain the following information: (1) The full name and address of the applicant, indication as to whether the applicant is an individual, partnership or corporation, and if the applicant is a partnership, the names and addresses of each partner. (2) The location or address of the place of business at which the applicant will engage in the retail beer business, if and when permission to do so is granted by the city and a license issued. (3) 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 30/196 Such other information as the city clerk may, under the direction of the board of commissioners, from time to time require. (Code 1962, § 3-4; Code 1986, § 3-27) Sec. 4-41. - Applicant's fingerprints. All applicants for a license under this article shall furnish a complete set of fingerprints, which shall be forwarded to the Georgia Bureau of Investigation, which shall search the files of the Georgia Crime Information Center, for a period of two years immediately preceding the date of the application, for any instance of criminal activity. The Georgia Bureau of Investigation shall also submit such fingerprints to the Federal Bureau of Investigation under the rules established by the United States Department of Justice for processing and identification records. The federal record, if any, shall be obtained and returned to the city. (Code 1986, § 3-28) Sec. 4-42. - Fee. (Code 1986, § 3-29) Sec. 4-43. - Approval or disapproval of application. (a) Every application filed with the city clerk pursuant to this article shall be presented by the clerk to the board of commissioners in a meeting duly assembled and, after investigating the fitness of the applicant and the fitness of the proposed location of the retail beer business, the board of commissioners shall approve or disapprove the application. If the application is disapproved, the clerk shall return to the applicant the check submitted with the application. (b) In considering an application for a retail beer dealer's license, the board of commissioners may, in its sole discretion, consider any extenuating circumstances which may reflect favorably or unfavorably on the applicant, application or proposed location of the business. (c) No application shall be approved under this section if the applicant has been convicted under any federal, state or local law for a criminal offense involving moral turpitude, or has been convicted under any federal, state or local law of any criminal offense involving alcoholic beverages, gambling or tax law violations, if such conviction tends to indicate that the applicant would not maintain his or her retail beer business in conformity with federal and state law and the ordinances of the city. (Code 1962, § 3-5; Code 1986, § 3-30) Sec. 4-44. - Disapproval if place of business located near church or church school. (b) For issuance of this beer license, all measurements to determine distances shall be measured by the most direct route of travel on the ground and shall be measured in the following manner: (1) From the door of the structure from which the alcoholic beverage is sold or offered for sale; (2) In a straight line to the nearest public sidewalk, walkway, street, road or highway; (3) Along such public sidewalk, walkway, street, road or highway by the nearest route; (4) To the front door of the building, or to the nearest portion of the grounds, whichever is applicable under the appropriate statute. (Code 1962, § 3-14; Code 1986, § 3-31; Ord. No. 488, § 3-31, 11-8-1999) Sec. 4-45. - Notice of, and hearing on, disapproval. Upon application made within five days of receipt of the notice, the applicant shall be afforded a hearing, with opportunity to present evidence and cross examine opposing witnesses. The applicant may appear at such hearing in person and by attorney. (Code 1986, § 3-32) Sec. 4-46. - Issuance. If an application for a retail beer dealer's license is approved by the board of commissioners, the city clerk shall issue a proper license to the applicant authorizing the applicant to engage in the business of a retail beer dealer at the business location designated in the application. 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 31/196 (Code 1962, § 3-5; Code 1986, § 3-33) Sec. 4-47. - Valid only at designated location; not transferable. (Code 1962, § 3-6; Code 1986, § 3-34) Sec. 4-48. - Display. Every person holding a retail beer dealer's license shall display the license prominently at all times on the premises for which the license was issued. (Code 1986, § 3-35) Sec. 4-49. - Expiration. A retail beer dealer's license shall expire upon, and be of no validity after July 31, next after its issuance. (Code 1962, § 3-6; Code 1986, § 3-36) Sec. 4-50. - Suspension or revocation. (a) Any retail beer dealer's license may be suspended for a definite length of time or revoked pursuant to this section. (b) The making of any statement in an application for a retail beer dealer's license which statement is later found to be false, shall constitute grounds for revocation of the license. (c) The performance of any act prohibited by this chapter or the failure to perform any act required hereby, as well as the violation of this Code or of any ordinance of the city or any law, state or federal, relating to the sale of alcoholic beverages, shall constitute grounds for the revocation of a retail beer dealer's license. (d) A retail beer dealer's license may be temporarily suspended and the place of business closed upon receipt of evidence by the board of commissioners or the chief of police of any violation referred to in this section. (e) No license shall be revoked under this section, unless the licensee has been given at least three days written notice, in person or by registered mail, of the intention of the board to take such action. The notice shall specify the time, place and purpose of the hearing and the charges upon which the board proposes to take action. At the hearing, the licensee shall have the right to appear, in person and by attorney, and the board and the licensee shall have the right to present evidence relating to the question as to whether or not a violation, as set forth in this section, has occurred, as well as evidence relating to any extenuating or mitigating circumstances. (Code 1962, § 3-11; Code 1986, § 3-37) Secs. 4-51—4-73. - Reserved. This provision shall not apply to any holder of a license hereunder unless, subsequent to the adoption of the ordinance from which this section derives, such license holder divests himself or herself of 50 percent or more of the interest in the business owned by him or her at the time of the enactment of this chapter, but shall be effective with regard to any establishment for which a new alcoholic beverage license is applied for after adoption of this chapter to make use of an existing building, or other premises, as well as applicants for licenses who will be required to comply with this chapter in the erection of, or use of, a new building. (c) Permitted areas for consumption on premises. The consumption of alcoholic beverages shall be permitted only inside that portion of the licensee's building designated for such consumption, or at such outside location immediately adjacent to the building and specifically designated for the consumption of food and alcoholic beverages, but 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 34/196 not for the consumption of alcoholic beverages only, with such outside location for the consumption of food and alcoholic beverages to include patios, decks, screen porches and like areas. (Ord. No. 521, § 3-54, 6-14-2005) Sec. 4-147. - Appeal from decision of city manager. Any objections or procedural questions shall be decided by the commission chairperson. The city commission shall have the right to increase or decrease the suspension after hearing the evidence or to permanently revoke the license if it finds that this article has been violated. (Ord. No. 521, § 3-55, 6-14-2005)

div.head: Chapter 6 - AMUSEMENTS
div.p: ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL Secs. 6-1—6-20. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - PUBLIC DANCEHALLS DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY Sec. 6-21. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Public dancehall means any place open to the general public where dancing is permitted, to which an admission fee is charged, or for which compensation is in any manner received, either directly or indirectly, by cover charge or otherwise, or where refreshments or food or any form of merchandise are served for compensation before, during or after dancing. The sale of any refreshments, food or any form of merchandise at any such place, or the exhibiting of such for sale, shall be deemed direct compensation for any such dance hall within the meaning of this section. This section, however, shall not apply to dances held for benevolent or charitable purposes, or when the same are conducted under the auspices of religious, educational, civic or military organizations. In addition, the term "dancehall" as used in this article, shall not 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 36/196 apply to hotels and inns within the definition of O.C.G.A. §§ 43-21-1 and 43-21-2 nor to persons who, incidental to their principal business or occupation, accept from time to time seasonal boarders in their private residences. (Code 1986, § 3.5-11) Sec. 6-22. - Board approval required for change of ownership, management or location. The ownership, management or location of a public dancehall shall not be changed without the approval of the board of commissioners. (Code 1986, § 3.5-12) Sec. 6-23. - Right of entry of police. Members of the city police department may enter any public dancehall operated pursuant to a permit issued under the provisions of this article at all hours to ensure that the peace and quiet of the city are preserved and that the conditions and restrictions of this article are observed. (Code 1986, § 3.5-13) Sec. 6-24. - Minimum seating requirements. The total seats available in a public dancehall shall not be less than the total number of patrons present at any one time. (Code 1986, § 3.5-14) Sec. 6-25. - Closing hours. The closing hour of public dancehalls shall not be later than 2:00 a.m. and they shall remain closed until 12:00 p.m. noon of the following day. (Code 1986, § 3.5-15) Sec. 6-26. - Operator not to permit intoxicated or disorderly persons on premises. It shall be unlawful for any person operating a public dancehall in the city to suffer or permit any person under the influence of alcoholic beverages or any disorderly person to enter or remain in such dancehall, whether participating in the dancing or not. (Code 1986, § 3.5-16) Sec. 6-27. - Minors prohibited if alcoholic beverages sold; exception. (a) It shall be unlawful for any minor to enter, be or remain in any public dancehall in the city if alcoholic beverages are consumed or are sold or dispensed for consumption therein, except on business, and when on business, such minor shall be required to depart therefrom as soon as his or her business is transacted. (b) It shall be unlawful for the owner, operator or person in charge of any public dancehall in the city where alcoholic beverages are consumed or are sold or dispensed for consumption therein, to allow or permit any minor to enter, be or remain in any such public dancehall or place, except on business, and when on business, such minor shall be required to depart therefrom as soon as his or her business has been transacted. (c) The presence of any minor in any public dancehall for the purpose of dancing or watching dancing shall not be considered as being therein on business. (d) The term "alcoholic beverage," when used in this section, shall have the meaning prescribed by section 3-1-2 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated (O.C.G.A. § 3-1- 2). (e) The owner, operator or person in charge of any such public dance hall shall have and keep posted conspicuously at the entrance or entrances thereof a sign or signs in bold letters, not less than two inches in height, reading: "NO MINORS ALLOWED." (Code 1986, § 3.5-17) Sec. 6-28. - Lewd, indecent, etc., dances, etc. It shall be unlawful for any person operating a public dance hall in the city to suffer or permit in such dancehall any lewd, indecent or immoral dance, posture, performance or conduct by any person. (Code 1986, § 3.5-18) Secs. 6-29—6-59. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - PERMIT Sec. 6-60. - Required. (a) No person shall operate a public dancehall in the city without having first obtained a permit issued pursuant to this division. (b) No license shall be granted by the city for the operation of a public dancehall in the city until the permit required by this section has been issued. 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 37/196 (Code 1986, § 3.5-24) Sec. 6-61. - Application. Any person desiring to obtain a permit for the operation of a public dancehall shall make written application therefor to the board of commissioners. Such application shall be filed with the city clerk and shall contain the following information: (1) The location of the proposed dancehall. (2) The names and addresses of all persons who are owners, operators or managers of the dance hall, together with the names and addresses of all person having a financial interest in the dancehall, including stockholders, lien holders or partners. (3) If the owner or operator is a corporation, the names and addresses of the true or equitable owners of the stock of such corporation. (4) A detailed statement of the facilities to be provided, including type of food or beverages to be offered, the seating capacity of the dancehall and the amount of off-street parking space available for patrons. (Code 1986, § 3.5-25) Sec. 6-62. - Fee. The fee for a permit required by this division shall be such as is prescribed, from time to time, by the board of commissioners. (Code 1986, § 3.5-26) Sec. 6-63. - Referral of application to city manager. The city clerk is hereby authorized and directed to transmit directly to the city manager, for investigation and report to the board at a subsequent meeting, each application for a permit under this division. (Code 1986, § 3.5-27) Sec. 6-64. - Board hearing on application; issuance or refusal. Upon the filing of an application for a public dancehall permit, and upon receipt of the report referred to in this division, the board of commissioners may hear statements and receive evidence as to the suitability of the location of the proposed public dancehall, preference being given to ground floor locations, as to the suitability and adequacy of the facilities, and as to the fitness and financial responsibility of the persons who will own, conduct or manage the same. The board shall, by resolution upon a record vote, grant or refuse the permit; provided, however, that no such permit shall be issued unless it shall appear that all persons having a financial interest in or connected with the management or operation of the dancehall, including stockholders or lien holders, are of good reputation and are otherwise acceptable to the council. (Code 1986, § 3.5-28) Sec. 6-65. - Permit subject to article provisions. Every permit to operate a public dancehall in the city shall be subject to the conditions and restrictions of this division (Code 1986, § 3.5-29) Sec. 6-66. - Transfer. A permit to operate a public dancehall shall not be transferable, without the approval of the board of commissioners. (Code 1986, § 3.5-30) Sec. 6-67. - Revocation. Upon the violation of any provision of this article, the board of commissioners shall have the right, in addition to any other remedies allowed by law, to revoke the permit for the operation of the public dance hall involved in such violation, after due hearing and upon not less than five days' notice in writing to the holder of the permit. Such notice shall be sent by registered mail to the address given by the holder of the permit when applying for the permit. (Code 1986, § 3.5-31) Secs. 6-68—6-92. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - COMMERCIAL RECREATION CENTERS DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY Sec. 6-93. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Commercial recreation center or center means any establishment where foosball, table tennis, shuffleboard or any other game of recreation or amusement is displayed for public patronage, including electronic game machines or devices, pinball machines and the like, where the insertion of a coin, slug or token or the payment of a fee is required and where two or more such tables or game machines or devices are used or displayed for use, irregardless of other additional goods or services which might be available on the premises. (Code 1986, § 3.5-42; Ord. No. 409, 4-7-1992) 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 38/196 Sec. 6-94. - Management. Every center shall at all times be under management and control by a person at least 18 years of age who shall be on the premises of the center at all times during the hours of operation. (Code 1986, § 3.5-43) Sec. 6-95. - Ground floor location required; window space.
