Any person so arrested shall have the right to give bond for his or her appearance at the next regular session of the municipal court. (Code 1962, § 17-10; Code 1986, § 20-6) Sec. 26-7. - Failure of citizens to assist police. If any citizen of the city shall, when called upon by the chief of police or any other city police officer to assist in arresting any person, or in maintaining order in the city, fail or refuse to assist such officer, he or she shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. (Code 1962, § 17-11; Code 1986, § 20-7) Sec. 26-8. - Police department standard operating procedures adopted. (a) The Quitman Police Department Standard Operating Procedures is hereby adopted in its entirety and made a part of this Code. (b) Section 12, Tow Services of the Police Standard Operating Procedures, adopted in this section, is amended by adding the following: individuals wishing to be included on the city police department's wrecker rotation must satisfy and be subject to the following: 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 76/196 (1) The city Code of Ordinances, chapter 58, article III, sections 58-130 through 58-152 (2) The owner/driver must successfully pass a background examination of employment, driver and criminal history. It shall be the policy of the city police department that no owner/driver shall be added to the wrecker rotation who has been adjudicated guilty of a crime involving theft, use of drugs or alcohol or moral turpitude. (Code 1986, § 20-8; Ord. No. 404, 10-1-1991; Ord. No. 473, § I, 1-6-1998) Sec. 26-9. - Surcharge. A ten percent surcharge for the purchase and funding of technology equipment is added to the principal amount of all fines imposed by the city court for the city. These funds shall be used for the purchase of computer hardware and software and to purchase new technologically advanced equipment to improve the efficiency and safety of the police department for the city. This surcharge shall be in addition to all other surcharges presently imposed. (Ord. No. 510, §§ I, II, 11-4-2003)

div.head: Chapter 28 - LIBRARY
div.p: FOOTNOTE(S): (18) State Law reference— Local and regional public libraries, O.C.G.A. § 20-5-20 et seq. Sec. 28-1. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Library means the Brooks County Library. Library board means the board of trustees of the library. (Code 1962, § 2-43; Code 1986, § 12-1) Sec. 28-2. - Library system board—Appointment of members; term. The board of commissioners of the city shall appoint four members to the Brooks County Library System Board for three-year terms, with the starting and ending dates corresponding with the fiscal year for the state. (Code 1986, § 12-2; Ord. No. 366, § 1, 4-3-1989) Sec. 28-3. - Same—Residency requirement. All members of the Brooks County Library System Board, appointed by the board of commissioners of the city, shall be residents of the city. (Code 1986, § 12-3; Ord. No. 366, § 1, 4-3-1989) Sec. 28-4. - Same—Filling of vacancies. Should any appointed trustee vacate his or her office, whether voluntarily or involuntarily, then the board of commissioners of the city shall appoint another party to fill the unexpired term. (Code 1986, § 12-4; Ord. No. 366, § 1, 4-3-1989)

div.head: Chapter 30 - LICENSES AND OCCUPATION TAX
div.p: FOOTNOTE(S): (19) State Law reference— Power of municipal governing authority to levy and collect occupational taxes and licensing fees within corporate limits, Ga. Const. art. IX, § IV, ¶ I(b)(2); business and occupation taxes, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-5 et seq. ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL Sec. 30-1. - Purpose and scope of tax. The occupation tax levied herein is for revenue purposes only and is not for regulatory purposes, nor is the payment of the tax made a condition precedent to the practice of any such profession, trade, or calling. The occupation tax only applies to those businesses and occupations which are covered by the provisions of O.C.G.A. §§ 48-13- 05 to 48-13-26. All other applicable businesses and occupations are taxed by the local government pursuant to the pertinent general and/or local law and ordinances. (Ord. No. 451, § 19-45, 12-5-1995) Sec. 30-2. - Definitions. The definitions set forth in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-5 (Specific, Business, and Occupation Taxes-General Provisions-Definitions) shall be effective as definitions of the words, terms and phrases used in this chapter. All words, terms and phrases used herein, other than those specifically defined elsewhere in this chapter, shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-5, and shall have the same scope and effect that the same words, terms and phrases have where used in O.C.G.A. § 48-13- 5. (Ord. No. 451, § 19-37, 12-5-1995) Secs. 30-3—30-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - OCCUPATION TAX AND FEES 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 77/196 Sec. 30-31. - Required. This section shall govern the licensing and permitting of all charitable fundraising activities conducted within the city. Fundraising activities are any activities conducted by a church, civic group, school, whether kindergarten, elementary, or secondary, including but not limited to any club or organization associated with such school, plus any other type of organization or group which is recognized by the United States Internal Revenue Service as a charitable or nonprofit organization to raise money for a purpose set out in subsection (b) of this section. (b) Classification. Fundraising activities are classified as any event whereby money is collected by an organization described in subsection (a) of this section for charitable purposes or for the funding of educational projects, religious use, public use, including but not limited to raising funds for any governmental organization or department of government, state, national county or city, it being the intent of the board of commissioners that this section be interpreted broadly to include all types of fundraising activities conducted for charitable purposes. Fundraisers include but are not limited to bake sales, car washes, the selling of food, carnivals, gospel sings, amateur theatrical performances, dances, auctions, walkathons and other activities of like nature. (c) Permit requirements. Any person, organization, group, club, charity, school, etc., must obtain a permit three days in advance of the scheduled fundraising activity. All permit applications shall be signed by the individual in charge of the fundraising activity and shall include the individual's name and address. Upon the receipt and approval by the city manager of the permit application, the same shall be signed by the city manager and issued through the clerk/treasurer's office. In the event the city manager is unavailable to sign the permit, the clerk/treasurer is authorized to issue a permit on behalf of the city under this section. (1) In the event the city manager, or the clerk/treasurer in the absence of the city manager, determines that the application does not meet the requirements of this section for the issuance of a fundraising permit, the application shall be denied and the reasons for denial shall be furnished in writing to the applicant. (2) Upon the denial by the city manager or clerk/treasurer of an application for a fundraising permit, the applicant shall have the right to request that the decision of the city manager or clerk/treasurer be reviewed by the board of commissioners at its next regularly scheduled meeting. (3) In the event a fundraising permit is denied, the applicant shall have the right to purchase the appropriate city business license and to proceed with the event should all other requirements of this Code be complied with. (d) Limitation of number of permits. No applicant shall be granted more than four fundraising permits in any calendar year. In the event the applicant is a club or other subunit or organization under the direction and control of the school system, the four permits per calendar year shall apply to that specific club, organization or subunit and not the 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 83/196 school as a whole. Each club, organization or subunit of the schools shall be entitled to four fundraising permits per year. (e) Special conditions. The city manager shall have the authority to impose special conditions upon the issuance of a fundraising permit, should in his or her opinion such conditions be necessary for the protection of the general public and their well-being. Special conditions may include but are not limited to the following: (1) The requirement that a security guard be present. (2) That certain fundraising activities be conducted in certain areas so as to reduce the danger of traffic accidents. (3) Limitation of the hours that the activity may be conducted or restrictions as to the location and number of signs advertising the fundraising activity. All special restrictions shall be shown upon the face of the fundraising permit issued, and the same shall be available at the site of the activity for inspection by the police department at all times that the fundraising activity is being conducted. Failure to comply with the special conditions of a fundraising permit will be grounds for the denial of future permits and shall constitute a violation of this section on behalf of the person executing the permit application. (f) Food sales. Any fundraising application involving the sale of on-site prepared food must include an approved permit from the county health department and must comply with any and all regulations of the health department. (g) Exemption on grounds that business is operated for charitable purpose. No business on which a business registration or occupation tax is levied by this chapter shall be exempt from said registration or tax on the ground that such business is operated for a charitable purpose, unless 100 percent of the entire proceeds from said business are devoted to such purpose. An affidavit shall be required from the principal officer of the business to the city attesting to the fact that the business is a 100 percent charitable organization. The city may require additional affidavits or proof at its discretion. Additionally, the city cannot levy any occupation tax, regulatory fee, or administrative fee on any state or local authority, or nonprofit organization. Proof of nonprofit status may be required. ARTICLE VII. - DOWNTOWN ACTIVITIES Sec. 30-183. - Downtown promotional activities. (a) The Merchant's Association of the City of Quitman, the Chamber of Commerce or any other nonprofit organization consisting of merchants of the city either in existence as of the date of the adoption of the ordinance from which this article was derived or in the future, may petition the board of commissioners of the city for permission to conduct special promotional activities in the downtown area to promote the sale of goods and services from the downtown merchants to the general public. Said permission may cover all streets and sidewalks over which the board of commissioners of the city has control. (b) Said promotional activities shall consist of activities which, in the opinion of the board of commissioners of the city, shall promote increased traffic in the downtown area of the city and would be beneficial to the business of the merchants of the downtown area of the city. Said promotional activity may include but shall not be limited to sidewalk sales by the merchants, yard sales by the merchants and other parties acting with the permission of the affected merchant and the organization sponsoring the promotional activity and festival type events. (c) In the event that a promotional activity is approved by the board of commissioners of the city and goods are being sold and/or promoted for sale in the downtown area by parties other than the local merchants, the board of commissioners shall have the authority to waive city business licensees for the promotional event in question. This shall not be interpreted as to require the waiver of business fees by the board of commissioners but shall be entirely discretionary upon their part. The board may waive the licensees for the entire promotional activity or may waive the licensees for a portion of the participants and not all. (d) Any organization desiring to conduct a promotional activity for the downtown area shall make application to the board of commissioners a minimum of 30 days, except for requests currently pending, prior to the proposed scheduled activity and shall provide the board of commissioners with a detailed proposal of what activities shall be 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 85/196 undertaken during the promotional event. In the event that a yard sale by persons other than the downtown merchants is to be conducted in the downtown area, the organization promoting the promotional activity shall be required to furnish to the city office a list of all parties participating along with names and addresses and telephone numbers of the same. This list may be supplemented on the day of the activity to include new participants. (Code 1986, § 13-50; Ord. No. 429, 11-17-1993)

div.head: Chapter 32 - MANUFACTURED HOMES
div.p: FOOTNOTE(S): (22) State Law reference— Standards and requirements for construction, installation, and licensing of manufactured homes and mobile homes, O.C.G.A. §§ 8-2-110 et seq., 8-2-130 et seq., and 8-2-160 et seq. ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL Secs. 32-1—32-18. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - SINGLE-FAMILY MANUFACTURED HOMES Sec. 32-19. - Intent. (a) It is the intent of this article to provide for the placement of manufactured homes and industrialized buildings with dwellings which have been constructed under these and other lawful regulations on lots in the same district, zoning classification or general area as a special exception except in historical districts. (b) Manufactured homes which do not conform to the standards established in the definition of dwelling, single-family and mobile homes will be permitted in mobile home parks provided they comply with the requirements of mobile home parks as set out in this. (Ord. No. 462, § A, 12-3-1996) Sec. 32-20. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Dwelling, single-family, means structure containing not more than one dwelling unit designed for residential use, which meets or exceeds the following standards: (1) Minimum width in excess of 18 feet. (2) Minimum square footage required by the zone in which located. (3) The roof shall have a minimum 2:12 roof pitch and shall have a surface of wood shakes, asphalt composition, wood shingles, concrete, fiberglass or metal tiles, slate, built up gravel materials, or other materials approved by the building official. (4) The exterior siding materials shall consist of wood, masonry, concrete, stucco, masonite, metal or vinyl lap or other materials of like appearance. (5) Be attached to a permanent foundation, axle wheels and tongue removed. (6) Be constructed according to standards established either by the State Minimum Standard Codes, as amended from time to time, for site-built homes, or the National Manufactured Housing Construction and Safety Standards Act for manufactured homes, or the state Industrialized Building Act for residential industrialized buildings. Each of these codes shall be applicable to the specific structure to which it applies. (7) Skirting must be installed. Dwelling unit means a structure or a portion of any structure designed, arranged and used for living quarters for one or more persons living as a single housekeeping unit with cooking facilities, but not including units in hotels, motels, boardinghouses or like uses. Industrialized building means any structure or component thereof which is wholly or in substantial part made, fabricated, formed, or assembled in manufacturing facilities for installation on a building site and has been manufactured in such a manner that all parts or processes cannot be inspected at the installation site without disassembly, damage to, or destruction thereof. Industrialized buildings are constructed and regulated in accordance with the Industrialized Buildings Act, 1982 Ga. Laws (Act. No. 1466), pages. 1637, 1643 (O.C.G.A. § 8-2-110 et seq.). Manufactured home means a structure defined by and constructed in accordance with the National Manufactured Housing Construction and Safety Standards Act of 1974 as amended, 42 USC 5401 et seq. The definition at the date of adoption of this part is as follows: The term "manufactured home" means a structure, transportable in one or more sections, which, in the traveling mode, is eight body feet or more in width or 40 body feet or more in length, or, when erected on site, is 320 or more square feet, and which is built on a permanent chassis and designed to be used as a dwelling with or without a permanent foundation when connected to the required utilities, and includes the plumbing, heating, air conditioning, and electrical systems contained therein; except that such term shall include any structure which meets all the requirements of this 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 86/196 definition except the size requirements, and with respect to which the manufacturer voluntarily files a certification required by the secretary and complies with the standards established under this title. Mobile home means a structure, transportable in one or more sections, which, in the traveling mode, is eight body feet or more in width or 40 body feet or more in length or, when erected on site, is 320 or more square feet and which is built on a permanent chassis and designed to be used as a dwelling with or without a permanent foundation when connected to the required utilities and includes the plumbing, heating, air conditioning, and electrical systems contained therein and manufactured prior to June 15, 1976. Other manufactured homes means any manufactured home not meeting the definition of dwelling, single-family. Structure means anything constructed or erected with a fixed location on or in the ground, or attached to something having a fixed location on the ground. Structures include but are not limited to the following: site-built buildings, industrialized buildings, manufactured homes, mobile homes, billboards, swimming pools, advertising signs, satellite dishes, and fallout shelters. (Ord. No. 462, § B, 12-3-1996) Sec. 32-21. - Manufactured homes as single-family dwellings. (a) Permitted locations. Manufactured homes qualifying as dwelling, single-family, may be allowed in all residential districts, except those areas designated as historical districts, as a special exception and shall be regulated uniformly with other housing constructed on site, subject to requirements and limitations set forth in this article. Approval shall be in accordance with section 32-24 (b) Compatibility standards. Compatibility standards for manufactured homes meeting the definition of dwelling, single-family, are as follows: (1) Manufactured homes qualifying as dwelling, single-family, shall be compared to site-built and other housing in the immediate general area within the same zoning or residential district or area. Approval shall be granted upon the finding that the manufactured home is substantially similar or superior in size, siding material, roof material, foundation and general aesthetic appearance to: a. Site-built or other forms of housing which may be permitted in the same general area under this section; b. Existing development; or c. Proposed development in the same zoning district or area. (2) All towing devices, wheels, axles and hitches must be removed. (3) At each exterior door there must be a landing that is a minimum of 36 inches by 48 inches. (Ord. No. 462, § C, 12-3-1996) Sec. 32-22. - Industrialized buildings as single-family dwellings. Permitted locations. Industrial buildings qualifying as dwelling, single-family, may be allowed as a special exception in all residential districts except those designated as historical districts and shall be regulated uniformly with other housing constructed on site, subject to requirements and limitations set forth in this article. Approval shall be in accordance with section 32-24. (Ord. No. 462, § D, 12-3-1996) Sec. 32-23. - Other manufactured homes and mobile homes used for residential purposes. (a) Permitted locations. Manufactured homes which do not meet the definitions of dwelling, single-family and mobile homes shall be permitted within areas designated as mobile home parks and must comply with the requirements set forth in this Code. (b) Standards. Standards for the placement of manufactured homes not meeting the definitions of dwelling, single-family and mobile homes are as follows: (1) A 30-foot setback is required from any other dwelling unit on the site. (2) The structure must be connected to the water and sewerage system, including well and septic tank, if applicable, approved by the city or county health department. (3) 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 87/196 The structure must be installed according to State of Georgia, Installation of Manufactured Homes and Mobile Homes Rules and Regulations as established and published by the state safety fire commissioner (O.C.G.A. § 8-2-160 et seq.). (4) The area beneath each such structure must be enclosed with materials manufactured for such purposes, either brick, block, concrete or rock, which have been approved by the city building inspector. (5) A manufactured home or mobile home when used as an accessory structure or dwelling shall be located to the rear of the principal structure. (6) The standards set out in subsections (b)(1) and (b)(5) of this section are not applicable to and shall not be applied to manufactured homes, other manufactured homes or mobile homes otherwise regulated hereunder when located in a manufactured home rental community or park or mobile home rental community or park. (c) Special exceptions. Manufactured homes which do not the meet definitions of dwelling, single-family and mobile homes shall be permitted as a special exception for residential use in all zoning districts which allow single-family residences. (Ord. No. 462, § E, 12-3-1996) Sec. 32-24. - Permitting requirements. The permitting requirements are as follows: (1) A property owner shall obtain zoning approval for lot use from the city zoning administrator prior to a permit request. (2) A property owner shall provide a dealer with these specifications for review. (3) A dealer shall submit a job order or sales contract indicating that said specifications will be met. Upon approval of a dealer's job order or sales contract, permits for delivery and setup of a manufactured home will then be issued. (Ord. No. 462, § F, 12-3-1996) Sec. 32-25. - Inspection procedures. A manufactured home shall be inspected in two phases: (1) After delivery and prior to joining the front and rear sections; and (2) After all installations are complete and utilities connected to city services. (Ord. No. 462, § G, 12-3-1996)

div.head: Chapter 34 - MUNICIPAL COURT
div.p: FOOTNOTE(S): (23) State Law reference— Municipal authority to establish, maintain and operate a municipal court, O.C.G.A. § 36-32-1 et seq. Sec. 34-1. - Time of sessions. (a) Municipal court shall be regularly scheduled to be open and in session for the hearing and disposition of all cases on the docket at least twice per month at such times as the presiding judge of the municipal court may set until all cases are disposed of or until the court is declared in recess by the presiding judge. The presiding judge shall also be authorized to specially set cases for trial at such other and further times as he or she may designate in writing or to hold additional court sessions from those regularly scheduled as he or she shall deem necessary in the interest of an orderly administration of the court. (b) Further, the municipal court judge shall be authorized to cancel a regularly scheduled session and lay over all scheduled cases to the next regularly scheduled session or to a special called session at the discretion of the presiding judge. (Code 1962, § 2-11; Code 1986, § 14.5-1; Ord. No. 322, § 2, 8-4-1986; Ord. No. 386, §§ A, B, 5-1-1990; Ord. No. 393, §§ A, B, 12-27-1990) Sec. 34-2. - Duty of municipal court clerk to attend sessions and keep records. The municipal court clerk shall attend the sessions of the municipal court and keep a record of the proceedings of the court in a separate book from the minutes of the council. 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 88/196 (Code 1962, § 2-8; Code 1986, § 14.5-2; Ord. No. 322, § 1, 8-4-1986) Sec. 34-3. - Subpoenas for witnesses; failure of witness to appear. All subpoenas for witnesses to appear before the municipal court shall be issued by the municipal court clerk and may be served by any police officer or other person designated by the board of commissioners. Any witness who shall fail or refuse to appear in obedience to any subpoena so served, and who fails to furnish a satisfactory excuse rendered under oath, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. (Code 1962, § 2-12; Code 1986, § 14.5-3; Ord. No. 322, § 1, 8-4-1986) Sec. 34-4. - Court fines. There is imposed and shall be collected on all fines over $17.50, imposed by the recorders court of the city, a service fee of $4.00 in addition to the fine set by the judge of said court. This administrative fee shall be in addition to all other add-ons to the fine imposed by law. (Ord. No. 518, § 1, 4-5-2005)

div.head: Chapter 36 - NUISANCES
div.p: ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL Sec. 36-1. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Nuisance means anything within the city or its police jurisdiction that causes hurt, inconvenience or damage to another and the fact that the act done may otherwise be lawful shall not keep it from being a nuisance. The inconvenience complained of shall not be fanciful, or such as would affect only one of fastidious taste, but it shall be such as would affect an ordinary, reasonable person. Any such nuisance may be abated as provided in this article. (Code 1986, § 16-10) Sec. 36-2. - Enumeration of nuisances. (a) The various nuisances described and enumerated in this section shall not be deemed to be exclusive, but shall be in addition to all other nuisances described and prohibited in this Code. (b) The following are hereby declared to be nuisances: (1) Things interfering with peace or comfort. Sounds, animals, or things which interfere with the peace or comfort or disturb the quiet of the community. (2) Obnoxious, offensive odors. The emission of obnoxious and offensive odors; the tainting of the air rendering it offensive or unwholesome so as to affect the health or comfort of reasonable persons residing in the neighborhood thereof. (3) Discharging of offensive matter. The placing or throwing or discharging from any house or premises and flow from or out of any house or premises, of any filthy, foul or offensive matter or liquid of any kind, into any street, alley or public place, or upon any adjacent lot or ground. (4) Water pollution. The obstruction or pollution of any watercourse or source of water supply in the city. (5) Stagnant water. Any stagnant pool of water in the city. (6) Emission of dense smoke. The emission of dense smoke from any fire, chimney, engine, oil burner or other agency in the city so as to cause annoyance or discomfort to the public. (7) Vacant lots. Any vacant lot whereon debris is permitted to accumulate and remain in such a manner as to create a fire hazard or other hazard to the public health, safety and welfare. (8) Nonconforming structures, machines, etc. Any building, business, thing, machine or machinery, erected, repaired, conducted, maintained, operated or used within the city contrary to or in violation of any of the fire and safety regulations of this Code, state law or city ordinance. (9) Animal enclosures., Any enclosure in which any animals are kept, dog kennels or runs and other animal or fowl pens wherein manure, dung, filth or litter is allowed to accumulate. (10) 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 89/196 Privies. The construction or maintenance of any surface closet, privy or privy vault on any premises within the city. (11) Dead animals. The carcass of any dead animal of any kind on any premises within the city. (12) Depositing trash, garbage, refuse, etc., on private or public property. The depositing and leaving on private or public property of trash, garbage, refuse, scrap building materials, paper, cardboard containers, brick, cement rubbish, tree residue, cans, containers, or any other rubbish and trash which is a menace to public health and safety in the city. (13) Sales of controlled substances; drug pushers. a. Any business where illegal sales of controlled substances take place on the premises with such frequency that the recorder determines that the owner or operator or manager in charge of such business knew, or in the exercise of ordinary care should have known, that such sales were taking place and such owner or operator or manager in charge has failed to take effective action to stop such sales. b. Any business where persons who are known to the owner or operator or manager in charge of such business, or should in the exercise of ordinary care be known to them or who are reputed to be illegal sellers or purveyors of controlled substances, are permitted to loiter on the premises without legitimate business reasons. (14) Weeds, etc. Permitting weeds, deleterious or unhealthy growth of vegetation on real property such as would constitute a haven for vermin or harmful or which would present a health hazard or danger to the general public. (Code 1986, § 16-12; Ord. No. 397, § 2, 5-7-1991) Sec. 36-3. - Prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain or permit the existence of any nuisance on any property within the city. (Code 1986, § 16-13; Ord. No. 397, § 2, 5-7-1991) Sec. 36-4. - Issuance of summons for abatement. Whenever any nuisance exists within the city limits, or upon any property within the police jurisdiction of the city, or whenever any condition shall exist on any property within the city limits or the police jurisdiction of the city which is required or subject to be demolished, removed or abated under any of the ordinances of the city, and the owner or other person responsible therefor refuses or fails after reasonable notice to demolish, remove or abate the same, the chief of police or the inspection officer, or the officer having responsibility for the enforcement of the same, may issue a summons and cause the same to be served upon such owner or other person responsible for such condition, describing the condition complained of and specifying the ordinances or parts thereof claimed to be violated thereby, and requiring such person to appear before the municipal judge of the city at a time, date and place specified therein, to show cause why such condition should not be demolished, removed or abated. (Code 1986, § 16-14; Ord. No. 397, § 2, 5-7-1991) Sec. 36-5. - Order for abatement. (a) If the recorder at the hearing shall determine that a condition does exist, as alleged, which constitutes a nuisance or a condition which under this Code or the ordinances of the city is required or subject to be demolished, removed or abated, the recorder shall issue his or her order and judgment so finding, and shall order the property owner, or other person responsible therefore, to demolish, remove or abate the condition within a period of time to be fixed by the recorder. The order shall provide how the condition is to be abated, including but not limited to rehabilitation or demolition of any buildings or structures located on the property in question. The order shall further provide that if the property owner or other person responsible therefor shall fail to comply with the order within the time specified, the city shall be authorized to proceed without further notice to demolish, remove or abate such condition, and to take whatever action deemed necessary to demolish, remove or abate such condition, and the expense thereof shall be charged against the owner of the property in question and shall be a lien against the property upon which the condition existed, ranking equally with the lien for city taxes. (b) Execution shall issue for such costs as in the case of city taxes, and the procedure for the enforcement of the execution shall thereafter be the same as in the case of city taxes. (Code 1986, § 16-15; Ord. No. 397, § 2, 5-7-1991) Sec. 36-6. - Nuisances constituting imminent danger. Whenever any condition shall exist which constitutes an immediate and grave hazard to public health and safety requiring immediate action, the condition may be abated or otherwise remedied summarily and without following the procedures set forth in section 36-5. (Code 1986, § 16-16; Ord. No. 397, § 2, 5-7-1991) Sec. 36-7. - Service on nonresidents and others. Whenever it shall be necessary for the city to proceed under sections 36-5 and 36-6 and the owner of the property or other person responsible therefor resides outside the city limits, or cannot be found after diligent search, service of the notice required by section 36-4 shall be made by posting a copy of the notice on the property involved, and by publishing the notice in The Quitman Free Press once a week for four consecutive weeks, the last notice to be not longer than ten days nor less than one day prior to the hearing. Where the address of the person to be served is known, or where there is a last known address, a copy of the notice shall also be mailed to the person at 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 90/196 such address by certified mail or statutory overnight delivery, return receipt requested. In all cases where personal service cannot be made upon such person within the city limits, the case shall proceed as quasi in rem, and the execution shall issue in rem. (Code 1986, § 16-17; Ord. No. 397, § 2, 5-7-1991) Sec. 36-8. - Other power preserved. Nothing in this article shall in any way affect the power and authority of the recorder to punish for any violations which the conditions may constitute, nor shall it affect the power and authority of the recorder to punish by contempt for failure to comply with the municipal court's order. (Code 1986, § 16-18; Ord. No. 397, § 2, 5-7-1991) Secs. 36-9—36-19. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - NOISE CONTROL Sec. 36-20. - Use of loudspeakers; permit. (a) The use and operation of a loudspeaker or public address system upon the streets, alleys or public property within the city limits by any person is prohibited and declared to be unlawful unless such person shall obtain a written permit from the city manager at least 48 hours prior to the commencement of the use thereof. (b) To obtain the permit referred to in subsection (a) of this section, written application shall be made to the city manager by the person desiring to use the loudspeaker or public address system, in which application, the applicant shall state the time, place and manner of the proposed use, and the type of loudspeaker or public address system which is proposed to be used and the vehicle, if any, upon which the same shall be located. (Code 1986, § 16-43; Ord. No. 397, § 2, 5-7-1991) Sec. 36-21. - Exemptions from article. There shall be exempt from the prohibitions of this article, the playing, using or operating of any of the devices or instruments named in this article: (1) By churches for the emission of church music or sounds from bells or chimes; (2) By any public school sponsored project or activity; (3) By any candidate for public office; or (4) By any project sponsored for charitable purposes and not for profit or personal gain. The playing, using or operating of such devices for the above-named purposes shall be restricted to the hours of 9:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m. (Code 1962, § 14-5; Code 1986, § 15-16) Sec. 36-22. - Operation or use on streets or in parks. It shall be unlawful for any person, either as principal, agent or employee, to play, use or operate, for advertising purposes or any other purposes whatsoever, on or in the public streets, alleys, parks or sidewalks in the city, any sound truck or any loudspeaker or sound amplifier, or radio or phonograph with a loudspeaker or sound amplifier, or any other instrument of any kind or character which emits therefrom loud or raucous sounds and is attached to and upon any vehicle. (Code 1962, § 14-2; Code 1986, § 15-17) Sec. 36-23. - Use prohibited in certain part of city. It shall be unlawful for any person, either as principal, agent or employee, to play, use or operate, for advertising purposes or any other purposes whatsoever, any sound truck, loudspeaker, sound amplifier, radio or phonograph with a loudspeaker or sound amplifier or any other instrument of any kind or character which emits therefrom loud and raucous sounds, when the playing, using or operating thereof emits its sounds over, upon or into the public streets, alleys, parks or sidewalks in the city, within the area bounded on the west by Madison Street, on the east by Jefferson Street, on the south by Battle Street and on the north by Stevens Street. (Code 1962, § 14-3; Code 1986, § 15-18) Sec. 36-24. - Disturbance of peace and quiet. It shall be unlawful for any person, either as principal, agent or employee, to play, use or operate, for advertising purposes or any other purposes whatsoever, outside the boundaries described in section 39-23, any sound truck, loudspeaker, sound amplifier, radio or phonograph with a loudspeaker or sound amplifier or any other instrument of any kind or character which emits therefrom loud and raucous sounds, when the playing, using or operating thereof disturbs the peace and quiet of any person. (Code 1962, § 14-4; Code 1986, § 15-19) Secs. 36-25—36-47. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - JUNK Sec. 36-48. - Definitions. 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 91/196 The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Inoperable condition means a condition that prevents its use for the purpose for which it was originally manufactured. Junk means any automobile, motor vehicle, mechanized equipment, machinery, appliance, scrap metal, or other scrap material which has been located on the property for a period of 30 days or longer in an inoperable condition. (Code 1986, § 16-20; Ord. No. 397, § 2, 5-7-1991) Sec. 36-49. - Repair or removal of junk upon receipt of notice. Upon receipt of notice is writing from the city housing official, the owner or person in possession of any premises upon which is located any junk, as defined in section 36- 48, shall within 30 days: (1) Repair such junk and place it in operable condition; (2) Cause such junk to be removed from the premises and disposed of in a manner so as not to constitute a violation of any of the ordinances of the city and so as not to constitute a nuisance; or (3) Submit to the housing official a plan satisfactory to that official for placing such junk in an operable condition within a time deemed by the housing official to be reasonable under all the circumstances. (Code 1986, § 16-21; Ord. No. 397, § 2, 5-7-1991) Sec. 36-50. - Failure to comply with provisions; penalty. Any person failing to comply with the provisions of section 36-49 shall be guilty of an offense as defined by and as punishable to the maximum allowed by the city Charter. Sec. 36-51. - Declaration of nuisance; abatement. Any junk remaining on premises in violation of the terms of this article after the procedures herein prescribed have been followed is hereby declared to be harmful and dangerous to the public health, safety and welfare and is hereby declared to be a nuisance. The abatement of such junk shall be accomplished by the city housing official pursuant to the provisions of and in the manner prescribed by this article. (Code 1986, § 16-26; Ord. No. 397, § 2, 5-7-1991) Sec. 36-52. - Quiet zones. The board of commissioners shall have authority to establish or designate quiet zones in the vicinity of hospitals or at other locations within the city. When such zones are identified by signs or markers clearly visible to an ordinarily observant person, it shall be unlawful for any person to make any unreasonable or unnecessary noise therein. (Code 1962, § 20-1; Code 1986, § 15-1)

div.head: Chapter 38 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS
div.p: FOOTNOTE(S): (24) State Law reference— Limitation on home rule powers of municipal corporations with respect to duplication of state criminal offenses, Ga. Const. art. III, § VI, IV; O.C.G.A. § 36-35-6(a)(2); Criminal Code of Georgia, O.C.G.A. § 16-1-1 et seq.; unlawful pandering, O.C.G.A. § 16-6-12; nuisances, O.C.G.A. § 41-1-1 et seq.; jurisdiction of municipal court or magistrate court to abate nuisance, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-5; abandoned motor vehicles generally, O.C.G.A. § 40-11-1 et seq. ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL Secs. 38-1—38-18. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - UNLAWFUL ACTS Sec. 38-19. - Interfering with city officers prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to molest, interrupt or interfere with any officer or employee of the city, in the performance of his or her duties at any time. (Code 1986, § 16-30; Ord. No. 397, § 2, 5-7-1991) Sec. 38-20. - Fortunetelling. (a) Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: For gain means the receipt or acceptance of payment, either in cash or in kind, donation, gratuity or reward of any kind. Fortunetelling means and includes fortunetelling, astrology, clairvoyancy, palm reading and any other practice which involves forecasting the future. (b) Deceptive to the public. The practice of fortunetelling is hereby found and declared to be inherently deceptive to the public. 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 92/196 (c) Penalties for certain acts. (1) Any person, whether individually and for himself or herself, or as an employee or agent of another, who shall, within the city limits, perform or offer to perform for gain any act of fortunetelling shall be guilty of an offense. (2) Any person engaging or offering to engage or holding himself or herself out as engaging in the practice of fortunetelling for gain within the city limits shall be guilty of an offense. (Code 1986, § 16-31; Ord. No. 397, § 2, 5-7-1991) Sec. 38-21. - Barbed wire fences. It shall be unlawful for any person to put up any barbed wire fencing in the city, without first obtaining the consent of the board of commissioners. Any person constructing such fencing without obtaining the consent of the board and who shall fail or refuse to remove the fencing within such time as may be prescribed by the board, after having been notified by the chief of police, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. (Code 1986, § 16-32; Ord. No. 397, § 2, 5-7-1991) Sec. 38-22. - Garage sales. (a) Garage sales may be held by individuals for the purpose of disposing of personal property in any zoning classification, provided the person holding said sale resides at the location and has obtained a permit from the city clerk authorizing the sale. (b) A permit for a garage sale shall be issued by the city clerk without charge. The permit shall state the date or dates of the sale, the name of the person conducting the sale, and the location of the sale. It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct a garage sale without first obtaining a permit. (c) Only two garage sales may be held by an individual in any year, and no such sale shall last more than two consecutive days. Under no circumstances shall such a sale be conducted off the premises of the owner of the property to be disposed of at the sale, except that it shall be permissible for neighbors to conduct a joint sale on the property of one of the neighbors who is a participant in the sale. (Code 1986, § 16-33; Ord. No. 397, § 2, 5-7-1991; Ord. No. 408, 1-14-1992) Sec. 38-23. - Curfew for certain minors. (a) The purposes of this section are: (1) To reduce the incidents of vandalism and criminal damage to property. (2) To protect the residents of the city. (3) To protect the morals of the minors of the city. (4) To promote the public welfare of the city and to protect the peace and good morals of the city. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of 17 years to be upon or remain upon any street or alley or outside any building in the city between 11:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m., except on Friday and Saturday nights when such time shall be extended to 12:00 midnight, except in case of an emergency or when accompanied by a parent. (Code 1986, § 16-34; Ord. No. 397, § 2, 5-7-1991) Sec. 38-24. - Exceptions. The provisions of section 38-23 shall not apply in the following instances: (1) When a minor is accompanied by his or her parent, guardian, or other adult having the lawful care and custody of the minor; (2) When the minor is upon an emergency errand directed by his or her parent or guardian or other adult person having the lawful care and custody of such minor, or if such minor is seeking medical treatment; 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 93/196 (3) When the minor is returning directly home from a school activity, entertainment, recreational activity, or dance; (4) When the minor is returning directly home from lawful employment that makes it necessary to be in the above referenced places during the prescribed period of time; (5) When the minor is attending or traveling directly to or from an activity involving the exercise of first amendment rights of free speech, freedom of assembly, or free exercise of religion; (6) When the minor is in a motor vehicle of parental consent for normal travel. All cases of interstate travel through the city are excepted from the curfew; or (7) When the minor is an emancipated minor as defined in O.C.G.A. § 15-11-200. Sec. 38-25. - Damaging trees, flowers, etc., in streets or parks. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to cut down, mutilate, destroy or damage, cut any limbs from, or cut the bark or wood on, any tree, flower, bush or shrub on the streets or in the parks of the city without having first secured the written consent of the board of commissioners. (b) The provisions of this section shall not apply to any work done by duly authorized employees or agents of the city. (Code 1986, § 16-35; Ord. No. 397, § 2, 5-7-1991) Secs. 38-26—38-53. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC PEACE Sec. 38-54. - Disorderly conduct—Prohibited acts. It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in: (1) Fighting or quarreling in such manner and in such place as to annoy or disturb the peace, quiet, comfort, or repose of persons in any office, or any dwelling, hotel, or other type of residence, or of any persons in the vicinity of any public place. (2) Using any indecent, vulgar, obscene, threatening or abusive language in or near a public place which has a direct tendency to cause acts of violence by the person to whom or of whom the remarks are addressed. (3) Yelling, shouting, singing, chanting or making any other loud noise by any means whatsoever, whether by voice, hand clapping, stomping or by mechanical means, on the public streets or on other public property or in proximity thereto in such manner and to such extent as to annoy or disturb the peace, quiet, comfort or repose of persons in any office, or in any dwelling, hotel, or other type residence, or of any person in the vicinity. (Code 1986, § 16-40; Ord. No. 397, § 2, 5-7-1991) Sec. 38-55. - Same—At sporting events or other games, etc. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person attending or at any baseball or other game at any park or other place in the city to: (1) Do any act or thing which interferes or is liable to interfere with the progress of the game. (2) Stand or sit in the aisles or passageways of the grandstands, bleachers or other seating places provided or to go into any seat different from that for which he or she has paid and is entitled to. (3) Go beyond any line, fence or rope or other contrivance established by the authorities at such games as a division line between players and the public and beyond which the public is prohibited. (4) Place any bottle in any place or position within the park or other public place while such game is in progress, where or when such bottle being so placed causes injury or is likely to cause injury to any person. (5) 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 94/196 Assemble with another or others at any place in such park or other public places while any game is in progress, for the purpose of betting. (b) It shall also be unlawful for any player or participant in any game specified in this section to refuse to go without the enclosure of the park or other public place when ordered to do so by the proper official of the game. (Code 1986, § 16-41; Ord. No. 397, § 2, 5-7-1991) Sec. 38-56. - Loitering. (a) Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Loitering means remaining idle in essentially one location and shall include the concept of spending time idle; to be dilatory; to linger; to stay; to saunter; to stand around; and shall also include the colloquial expression "hanging around." Public place means any place to which the general public has access and a right to resort to for business, entertainment or other lawful purpose, but does not necessarily mean a place devoted solely to the uses of the public. It shall also include the front or immediate area of any store, shop, restaurant, or other type of business, and also public grounds, areas or parks. (b) Police order to disburse. (1) It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter, loaf, wander, stand or remain idle either alone/or in concert with others in a public place in such a manner as to: a. Obstruct any public street, public highway, public sidewalk or any other public place or building by hindering or impeding or tending to hinder or impede the free passage of vehicles, traffic or pedestrians. b. Commit in or upon any public street, public highway, public sidewalk or any other public place or building, any act or thing which is an obstruction or interference to the free and uninterrupted use of property or with any business lawfully conducted by anyone in or upon or facing or fronting on any such public street, public highway, public sidewalk or any other public place or building, all of which prevents the free and uninterrupted ingress, egress and regress therein, thereon and thereto. c. Create or cause to be created a danger of a breach of the peace. d. Create or cause to be created any disturbance or annoyance to the comfort and repose of any person. e. Make unsolicited remarks of an offensive, disgusting or insulting nature which are calculated to annoy or disturb the person to or in whose hearing they are made. (2) When a person causes or commits any of the conditions enumerated in subsection (b)(1) of this section, a police officer or any law enforcement officer shall order that person to stop causing or committing such condition or conditions and to move on or disburse. Any person who fails or refuses to obey such order shall be guilty of a violation of this section. (3) Any person who violates any of the provisions of this section shall be subject to punishment according to the general penalties described in section 1-12. Any such violation shall constitute a separate offense on each successive date continued. (Code 1986, § 16-44; Ord. No. 397, § 2, 5-7-1991) Secs. 38-57—38-85. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - OFFENSES AGAINST PROPERTY Secs. 38-86—38-113. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC SAFETY AND HEALTH DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY Sec. 38-114. - Obstructing fire apparatus, etc. It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct in any manner any fire apparatus or any of the officers or members of the fire department while in the performance of their duties. (Code 1986, § 16-70; Ord. No. 397, § 2, 5-7-1991) Sec. 38-115. - Discharging firearms; dangerous weapons. (a) 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 95/196 Firearms. It shall be unlawful for any person to fire a gun, pistol or any other firearm within the city or its police jurisdiction, except by military companies when on drill or parade or at a funeral in honor of the dead, or by police officers in the line of duty; however, the firing of shotguns within the city limits while hunting upon lands with the permission of the owner thereof shall be lawful, provided no such shooting shall take place within 1,000 feet of any dwelling or public road. Firearms may be discharged within designated small arms firing ranges. It shall be unlawful for any firearms to be discharged in the city or its police jurisdiction in violation of O.C.G.A. § 16-11-103, 16-11-104. (b) Other dangerous instruments. It shall be unlawful for any person to shoot an airgun, bow and arrow, slingshot or any other like instrument that is dangerous within the city or its police jurisdiction, except that such instrument may be discharged within approved and supervised areas of private property for such purposes. (Code 1986, § 16-71; Ord. No. 397, § 2, 5-7-1991) Sec. 38-116. - Violations of emergency telephone use. It shall be unlawful for any person to intentionally use the emergency telephone service maintained by the city, being telephone number 911, for any purpose other than to summon assistance in a bona fide and genuine emergency. (Code 1986, § 16-72; Ord. No. 397, § 2, 5-7-1991) Sec. 38-117. - Defecation in public. It shall be unlawful for any person to defecate or urinate in any place within the city, other than in a water closet or other place of like kind provided for such purposes. (Code 1986, § 16-73; Ord. No. 397, § 2, 5-7-1991) Secs. 38-118—38-147. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - INHALATION OF DANGEROUS SUBSTANCES Sec. 38-148. - Inhaling or smelling certain substances prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person intentionally to inhale or smell of fumes from automobile transmission fluids, automobile transmission stop leak fluids, automobile brake fluids, or similar automobile fluids, or to inhale or smell the fumes of model glue, as that term is defined in O.C.G.A. § 16-13-90, for the purpose of causing a condition of intoxication, stupefaction, hallucination, euphoria, excitement, exhilaration or dulling of the senses or nervous system. (Code 1986, § 16-80; Ord. No. 397, § 2, 5-7-1991) Sec. 38-149. - Sales of certain substances limited. It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or transfer possession of any automobile transmission fluids, automobile transmission stop leak fluids, automobile brake fluids, or similar automobile fluids or model glue as defined in O.C.G.A. § 16-13-90 to any person under 14 years of age unless he or she shall have in his or her possession and shall exhibit upon request, the written consent of the parent or legal guardian of such person to make such purchase or to have possession of such substance. (Code 1986, § 16-81; Ord. No. 397, § 2, 5-7-1991) Sec. 38-150. - Purchase or possession of certain substances by minors restricted. It shall be unlawful for any person under 14 years of age to buy or to possess any automobile transmission fluids, automobile transmission stop leak fluids, automobile brake fluids or similar automobile fluids not included in the definition of model glue found in O.C.G.A. § 16-13-80, unless the purchase or possession of such substance is for lawful use, and the person under 14 years of age buying or possessing such substance shall have in possession, the written consent of the parent or legal guardian of such person to make such purchase or have possession of such substance. (Code 1986, § 16-82; Ord. No. 397, § 2, 5-7-1991) Secs. 38-151—38-168. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC MORALS Sec. 38-169. - Disorderly houses. It shall be the duty of the chief of police, upon the information of any citizen and supported by affidavit, that a disorderly house is kept within the city or its police jurisdiction or one which tends to the corruption of the morals of the people, to apply to the recorder for a warrant against such person, so that the charge may be inquired into and such proceedings had as the ordinances and laws direct. (Code 1986, § 16-91; Ord. No. 397, § 2, 5-7-1991)

div.head: Chapter 40 - PARADES
div.p: FOOTNOTE(S): (25) State Law reference— Authority of city to regulate processions or assemblages on streets, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371(a)(3). ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL Sec. 40-1. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Parade means any parade, march, ceremony, show, exhibition, pageant or procession of any kind, or any similar display, in or upon any street, sidewalk, park or other public place in the city. (Code 1962, § 14-21.1; Code 1986, § 17-1) Secs. 40-2—40-22. - Reserved. 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 96/196 ARTICLE II. - PERMIT Sec. 40-23. - Required. No person shall engage or participate in, aid, form or start any parade, unless a parade permit application is first submitted to the chief of police for investigation, and given final approval by the city manager. (Code 1962, § 14-21.1; Code 1986, § 17-16) Sec. 40-24. - Application. Application for a parade permit shall be filed with the chief of police not less than 30 days nor more than 60 days before the date on which it is proposed to conduct the parade. The application shall set forth such information as the chief of police finds reasonably necessary to a fair determination as to whether the permit should be issued. (Code 1962, § 14-21.1; Code 1986, § 17-17) Sec. 40-25. - Fee. There shall be paid, at the time of filing an application for a parade permit, a fee in such amount as is prescribed by the board of commissioners; provided that this requirement may be waived if the parade is to be organized or conducted by a religious, charitable, civic, fraternal, educational or public group or organization. (Code 1962, § 14-21.1; Code 1986, § 17-18) Sec. 40-26. - Investigation; issuance. Upon receipt of an application for a parade permit, the chief of police shall make or cause to be made an investigation to determine whether the permit should be issued. The permit shall be approved by the city manager and issued by the chief of police, if it is found that the conduct of the parade will not unduly obstruct or hamper fire or police services, will not unreasonably interfere with public use of the streets or sidewalks, will not damage the streets or sidewalks, that the parade is scheduled to move from its point of origin to its point of termination without unreasonable delay, and that the permit applicant has obtained all required state permits for the event and followed all state and local rules and regulations relevant to conducting the event. (Code 1962, § 14-21.1; Code 1986, § 17-19) Secs. 40-27—40-55. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - PUBLIC DEMONSTRATIONS Sec. 40-56. - Conduct. All assemblies, parades and picketing shall be peaceful and unattended by noise and boisterousness, and there shall be no yelling, shouting, singing, chanting, clapping or making any other loud noise by any means whatsoever whether by voice, hand clapping, stomping or by mechanical means to such extent as to annoy or disturb the peace, quiet, comfort or repose of reasonable persons in any office, dwelling, hotel or other type residence, or any persons in the vicinity; however, the use of bands shall be permitted in parades. (Code 1986, § 16-50; Ord. No. 397, § 2, 5-7-1991) Sec. 40-57. - Use of sidewalks and streets. Picketing and demonstrations shall be conducted only on the public sidewalks maintained by the city, and only in such manner and on such locations on the sidewalks as not to interfere with the free passage of traffic on the sidewalks. No picketing or demonstrating will be conducted on those portions of the city streets used primarily for vehicular traffic. (Code 1986, § 16-51; Ord. No. 397, § 2, 5-7-1991) Sec. 40-58. - Use of placards and signs. Picketers or demonstrators shall carry only cardboard or paper placards or signs. The placards or signs shall not be more than 36 inches in length and not more than 36 inches in width. (Code 1986, § 16-53; Ord. No. 397, § 2, 5-7-1991) Sec. 40-59. - Prohibited in certain places. There shall be no picketing or demonstrating in front of any building in which the following are located, affecting the normal operation thereof, while the following are in use: (1) A church. (2) A fraternal order. (3) A school. (4) A hospital, nursing home or rest home. (Code 1986, § 16-54; Ord. No. 397, § 2, 5-7-1991) Sec. 40-60. - Notice of proposed picketing or demonstrating. 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 97/196 The chief of police is to be given at least five hours' notice by any person planning to picket or demonstrate. This written notice shall include the name of the organization or organizations planning to picket and also shall include the names of the places of business or public facilities which will be picketed and the hours that the picketing or demonstrating will be conducted. (Code 1986, § 16-55; Ord. No. 397, § 2, 5-7-1991) Sec. 40-61. - Duty to disperse as directed by police. Whenever the free passage of any street or sidewalk in the city shall be obstructed by a crowd, the persons composing such crowd shall disperse or move on when directed to do so by a police officer. It shall be unlawful for any person to refuse to so disperse or move on when so directed by a police officer. (Code 1986, § 16-56; Ord. No. 397, § 2, 5-7-1991) Sec. 40-62. - Use of vehicles for picketing or demonstrating. No vehicles shall be used in any picket or demonstrating line, and all picketers or demonstrators shall be afoot. (Code 1986, § 16-57; Ord. No. 397, § 2, 5-7-1991) Sec. 40-63. - Malicious mischief. It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully, mischievously or maliciously destroy, disfigure or injure any real or personal property of the city. (Code 1986, § 16-60; Ord. No. 397, § 2, 5-7-1991) Sec. 40-64. - Camping on streets, etc. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to camp upon any street, alley or public property within the city. (b) As used in this section, the term "to camp" shall mean and be evidenced by sleeping, lighting or maintaining fires or use of public property as living quarters. (Code 1986, § 16-61; Ord. No. 397, § 2, 5-7-1991) Sec. 40-65. - Blocking ingress and egress. It shall be unlawful for any person to block or interfere with the free ingress and egress to private or public property. (Code 1986, § 16-62; Ord. No. 397, § 2, 5-7-1991) Sec. 40-66. - Remaining on business property after closing. It shall be unlawful for any person to remain upon the premises or parking areas of any business while such business is closed, without the consent of the owner of the business; however, in parking areas which are common to more than one business, such conduct shall be unlawful only while all of the businesses are closed. (Code 1986, § 16-63; Ord. No. 397, § 2, 5-7-1991) Sec. 40-67. - Attachments to utility light poles and lampposts. (a) No business, partnership, corporation, LLC, organization or individual shall attach, or allow to be attached on their behalf, any signs, banners, flags, advertisements or devises of any kind to a utility light pole or lamppost. (b) Violations of this section shall be punished as follows: (1) First offense, $50.00. (2) Second offense, $200.00. (3) Third offense and subsequent offenses, $500.00. (c) Each day that a sign, banner, flag, advertisement or device of any kind is attached to a city street light or lamppost shall be a separate offense. (Ord. No. 515, § 16-64, 7-13-2004)

div.head: Chapter 42 - PARKS AND RECREATION
div.p: FOOTNOTE(S): (26) State Law reference— Power to provide parks, recreation areas, programs and facilities, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, III(a)(5); authority of municipality to construct and operate parks, swimming pools, golf courses, recreation grounds and buildings used for sports, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-3; establishment of recreation systems authorized, 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 98/196 O.C.G.A. § 36-64-1 et seq. ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL Sec. 42-1. - Walking on grass in parks. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to walk upon the grass growing in any of the parks of the city. (b) This section shall be effective only in park areas where notice of the prohibition contained herein is posted. (Code 1962, § 14-16; Code 1986, § 18-1) Secs. 42-2—42-20. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - PARK COMMISSION Sec. 42-21. - Created; composition; appointment of members. There is hereby created a park commission for the city, which shall consist of three members appointed by the board of commissioners as provided in section 42-22. (Code 1962, § 2-36; Code 1986, § 18-16) Sec. 42-22. - Qualifications and terms of members. The members of the park commission shall be citizens of the city and shall hold office for one year and until their successors are appointed and qualified. (Code 1962, § 2-36; Code 1986, § 18-17) Sec. 42-23. - Vacancies. Vacancies on the park commission caused by death, resignation or removal may be filled by the board of commissioners. (Code 1962, § 2-36; Code 1986, § 18-18) Sec. 42-24. - Authority. The park commission is hereby vested with full authority over the planting and care of the parks of the city, including the center and side parks on the streets of the city, and with full authority to designate the kind and nature of plants, flowers, trees and shrubs to be planted in the parks and to remove therefrom any plants, flowers, trees or shrubs which are not in accordance with the design of planting determined by the commission. (Code 1962, § 2-36; Code 1986, § 18-19)

div.head: Chapter 44 - PEDDLERS AND ITINERANT MERCHANTS
div.p: FOOTNOTE(S): (27) State Law reference— Peddlers and itinerant traders, O.C.G.A. § 43-32-1 et seq.; transient merchants, O.C.G.A. § 43-46-1 et seq. ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL Secs. 44-1—44-18. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - PEDDLERS Sec. 44-19. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Peddler means any person who goes to any house, home, store, office or place of business in the city, for the purpose of selling or attempting to sell any goods, wares, merchandise, service or other thing of value for a present consideration or deposit in advance, whether for present or future delivery. (Code 1962, § 15-1; Code 1986, § 19-16) Sec. 44-20. - Unlawful entry. It shall be unlawful for any peddler to forcibly enter any premises in the city, for any purpose referred to in this article, or to enter any premises against the will of any occupant thereof. (Code 1962, § 15-3; Code 1986, § 19-17) Sec. 44-21. - Refusal to leave premises on request. It shall be unlawful for any person who has entered the premises of another for any purpose referred to in this article to refuse to leave the premises immediately upon request by any occupant of the premises. (Code 1962, § 15-3; Code 1986, § 19-18) Secs. 44-22—44-45. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - ITINERANT MERCHANTS DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY Sec. 44-46. - Definitions. 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 99/196 The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Itinerant merchant means any person, whether a resident of the city or not, who engages in a temporary business of selling and delivering, whether as owner, agent, consignee or employee, goods, wares and merchandise within the city, and who, in furtherance of such purpose, hires, leases, uses or occupies any building, apartment, shop, structure, motor vehicle, tent, railroad boxcar, public room in a hotel or lodginghouse, street, alley or other place within the city, for the exhibition and sale of such goods, wares and merchandise. The term "itinerant merchant" shall not be construed to include any person who, while occupying such temporary location, does not sell from stock, but exhibits samples for the purpose of securing orders for future delivery only. (Code 1962, § 15-9; Code 1986, § 19-31) Secs. 44-47—44-65. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - LICENSE Sec. 44-66. - Required. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of an itinerant merchant within the city, unless he or she has a current license to do so issued pursuant to this Code. (b) The licensing requirements applicable to a license issued under this division are in addition to the requirements and fees prescribed by the provisions found under chapter 30, pertaining to licenses. (Code 1962, § 15-10; Code 1986, § 19-41) Sec. 44-67. - Application—Generally. Application for a license required by this division shall be in writing and sworn to and signed by the applicant, if an individual, by all partners, if a partnership or by the president, if a corporation. The application shall be filed with the city clerk and shall contain or show: (1) The name of the person having the management or supervision of the applicant's business during the time that it is proposed that it will be carried on in the city; the local address of such person while engaged in such business; the permanent address of such person; and the capacity in which such person will act, that is, whether as proprietor, agent or otherwise. (2) The name and address of the person for whose account the business will be carried on, if any, and if a corporation, under the laws of what state the same is incorporated. (3) The place in the city where it is proposed that the business be conducted. (4) The place, other than the permanent place of business of the applicant, where the applicant, within the six months next preceding the date of the application, conducted a transient business, stating the nature thereof and giving the post office and street address of any building or office in which such business was conducted. (5) A statement of the nature, character and quality of the goods, wares and merchandise to be sold or offered for sale by the applicant in the city; the invoice value and quality of such goods, wares and merchandise; whether the same are to be sold from stock in possession or from stock in possession and by sample, by direct sale or by direct sale and by taking orders for future delivery; where the goods or property proposed to be sold are manufactured or produced; and where such goods or products are located at the time the application is filed. (6) A brief statement of the nature and character of the advertising done or proposed to be done in order to attract customers. Copies of all such advertising, whether by handbills, circulars, newspaper advertising or otherwise, shall be attached to the application as exhibits thereto. (7) Whether or not the person having the management or supervision of the applicant's business has been convicted of a crime, misdemeanor or the violation of any municipal ordinance, the nature of such offense and the punishment assessed therefor. (Code 1962, § 15-11; Code 1986, § 19-42) Sec. 44-68. - Same—Accompanying fingerprints, references and credentials. Each application filed pursuant to this division shall be accompanied by the following: (1) The fingerprints of the person having the management or supervision of the applicant's business or, in lieu thereof, at least three letters of recommendation from reliable owners of property in the county, certifying as to such person's business responsibility or other evidence which establishes to the satisfaction of the city clerk the business responsibility of such person. (2) Credentials from the person for whom the applicant proposes to do business, authorizing the applicant to act as such representative. 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 100/196 (Code 1962, § 15-11; Code 1986, § 19-43) Sec. 44-69. - Applicant's bond. (a) Before any license required by this division is issued, the applicant shall file with the city clerk a bond running to the city, in a sum as established by ordinance of the board of commissioners, from time to time, executed by the applicant as principal and by a surety company authorized to do a surety business in the state and having an agency in the city as surety. The bond shall be conditioned that the applicant shall comply fully with all of the provisions of the ordinances of the city and the statutes of the state regulating and concerning the sale of goods, wares and merchandise and will pay all judgments rendered against the applicant for any violation of such ordinances or statutes, together with all judgments and costs that may be recovered against the applicant by any person for damage growing out of any misrepresentation or deception practiced on any person transacting business with the applicant, whether the misrepresentation or deception was made or practiced by the applicant or by his or her servants, agents or employees. Action on the bond may be brought in the name of the city for the use of the aggrieved person. (b) The city clerk shall not accept a bond tendered pursuant to this section, unless it has been approved by the city attorney, both as to form and as to the responsibility of the surety thereon. (Code 1962, § 15-13; Code 1986, § 19-44) Sec. 44-70. - Fee. The fee for a license under this division shall be that prescribed by ordinance of the board of commissioners from time to time for the particular line of business in which the applicant is to engage. The fee shall be paid prior to issuance of the license. (Code 1962, § 15-15; Code 1986, § 19-45) Sec. 44-71. - Investigation of applicant; issuance or denial. (a) Upon receipt of an application pursuant to this division, the city clerk shall cause such investigation of the applicant's business responsibility to be made as he or she deems necessary for the protection of the public. If, as a result of the investigation, the applicant's business responsibility is found to be unsatisfactory, the application shall be denied. If, as a result of the investigation, the applicant's business reputation appears to be satisfactory, the city clerk shall so certify in writing and a license shall be issued by the city clerk, provided the applicant has complied with all provisions of this division. (b) If a person applying for a license under this division desires to do business at more than one place within the city, separate licenses may be issued for each place of business and shall be posted conspicuously in each place of business, as required by this division. (Code 1962, § 15-12, 15-14; Code 1986, § 19-46) Sec. 44-72. - Contents. Each license issued pursuant to this division shall contain the number of the license, the date the same is issued, the nature of the business authorized to be carried on, the amount of the license fee paid, the expiration date of the license, the place where business may be carried on under the license, and the name of the person authorized to carry on the same. (Code 1962, § 15-12; Code 1986, § 19-47) Sec. 44-73. - Posting. A license issued under this division shall be posted conspicuously in the place of business named therein. (Code 1962, § 15-14; Code 1986, § 19-48) Sec. 44-74. - Expiration. A license issued under this division shall expire on August 1 after its issuance. (Code 1962, § 15-15; Code 1986, § 19-49) Sec. 44-75. - Revocation. Any license issued pursuant to this division may be revoked by the city clerk for any cause which would have justified the clerk in refusing to issue the license. (Code 1962, § 15-16; Code 1986, § 19-50) Sec. 44-76. - Records to be kept. (a) The city clerk shall keep a record of all licenses issued pursuant to this division. (b) The city clerk shall deposit the record of fingerprints of a person licensed under this division, together with the license number, with the chief of police. The chief of police shall report to the city clerk any complaints against such person and any conviction for a violation of this article. The city clerk shall keep a record of such complaints and violations. (Code 1962, §§ 15-12, 15-16; Code 1986, § 19-51)

div.head: Chapter 46 - SOIL EROSION AND SEDIMENTATION CONTROL
div.p: 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 101/196 FOOTNOTE(S): (28) State Law reference— Erosion and Sedimentation Act of 1975, O.C.G.A. § 12-7-1 et seq.; local land disturbing activity ordinances, O.C.G.A. § 12-7-4; local land disturbing ordinances, O.C.G.A. § 12-7-6; local erosion programs O.C.G.A. § 12-7-8. Sec. 46-1. - Title. This chapter will be known as the "City of Quitman Soil Erosion and Sedimentation Control Ordinance." (Code 1986, § 21-1; Ord. No. 416, § 1, 1-20-1993; Ord. No. 528, § I, 11-3-2005) Sec. 46-2. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Best management practices (BMPs) means a collection of structural practices and vegetative measures which, when properly designed, installed and maintained, will provide effective erosion and sedimentation control. The term "properly designed" means designed in accordance with the hydraulic design specifications contained in the Manual for Erosion and Sediment Control in Georgia specified in O.C.G.A. § 12-7-6(b). Board means the board of natural resources. Buffer means the area of land immediately adjacent to the banks of state waters in its natural state of vegetation, which facilitates the protection of water quality and aquatic habitat. Commission means the state soil and water conservation commission. Cut means a portion of land surface or area from which earth has been removed or will be removed by excavation; the depth below original ground surface to excavated surface. Also known as excavation. Department means the department of natural resources. Director means the director of the environmental protection division of the department of natural resources. District means the Middle South Georgia Soil and Water Conservation District. Division means the environmental protection division of the department of natural resources. Drainage structure means a device composed of a virtually nonerodible material such as concrete, steel, plastic or other such material that conveys water from one place to another by intercepting the flow and carrying it to a release point for stormwater management, drainage control, or flood control purposes. Erosion means the process by which land surface is worn away by the action of wind, water, ice, or gravity. Erosion and sedimentation control plan means a plan for the control of soil erosion and sedimentation resulting from a land disturbing activity. Also known as the "plan."
