Proposed structures or additions to existing structures and paved areas. h. Delineate the 25-foot horizontal buffer adjacent to state waters and the specified width in MRPA areas. i. Delineate the specified horizontal buffer along designated trout streams, where applicable. j. Location of erosion and sedimentation control measures and practices using coding symbols from the Manual for Erosion and Sediment Control in Georgia, chapter 6 (4) Maintenance of all soil erosion and sedimentation control practices, whether temporary or permanent, shall be at all times the responsibility of the property owner. (d) Permits. (1) Permits shall be issued or denied as soon as practicable but in any event not later than 45 days after receipt by the local issuing authority of a completed application, providing variances and bonding are obtained, where necessary. (2) No permit shall be issued by the local issuing authority unless the erosion and sedimentation control plan has been approved by the district and the local issuing authority has affirmatively determined that the plan is in compliance with this chapter, any variances required by this chapter are obtained, bonding requirements, if necessary, are met and all ordinances and rules and regulations in effect within the jurisdictional boundaries of the local issuing authority are met. If the permit is denied, the reason for denial shall be furnished to the applicant. (3) If the tract is to be developed in phases, then a separate permit shall be required for each phase. (4) The permit may be suspended, revoked, or modified by the local issuing authority, as to all or any portion of the land affected by the plan, upon finding that the holder or his or her successor in the title is not in compliance with the approved erosion and sedimentation control plan or that the holder or his or her successor in title is in violation of this chapter. A holder of a permit shall notify any successor in title to him or her as to all or any portion of the land affected by the approved plan of the conditions contained in the permit. (Code 1986, § 21-5; Ord. No. 416, § 5, 1-20-1993; Ord. No. 528, § V, 11-3-2005) Sec. 46-6. - Inspection and enforcement. (a) The state department of natural resources, environmental protection division, will periodically inspect the sites of land disturbing activities for which permits have been issued to determine if the activities are being conducted in accordance with the plan and if the measures required in the plan are effective in controlling erosion and sedimentation. Also, the local issuing authority shall regulate both primary and secondary permittees as such terms are defined in the state general permit. Primary permittees shall be responsible for installation and maintenance of best management practices where the primary permittee is conducting land disturbing activities. Secondary permittees shall be responsible for installation and maintenance of best management practices where the secondary permittee is conducting land disturbing activities. If, through inspection, it is deemed that a person engaged in land disturbing activities as defined herein has failed to comply with the approved plan, with permit conditions, or with the provisions of this chapter, a written notice to comply shall be served upon that person. The notice shall set forth the measures necessary to achieve compliance and shall state the time within which such measures must be completed. If the person engaged in the land disturbing activity fails to comply within the time specified, he or she shall be deemed in violation of this chapter. (b) The state department of natural resources, environmental protection division, shall have the power to conduct such investigations as it may reasonably deem necessary to carry out duties as prescribed in this chapter, and for this purpose to enter at reasonable times upon any property, public or private, for the purpose of investigation and inspecting the sites of land disturbing activities. (c) No person shall refuse entry or access to any authorized representative or agent of the local issuing authority, the commission, the district, or division who requests entry for the purposes of inspection, and who presents appropriate credentials, nor shall any person obstruct, hamper or interfere with any such representative while in the process of carrying out his or her official duties. (Code 1986, § 21-6; Ord. No. 416, § 6, 1-20-1993; Ord. No. 528, § VI, 11-3-2005) 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 109/196 Sec. 46-7. - Penalties and incentives. (a) Failure to obtain a permit for land disturbing activity. If any person commences any land disturbing activity requiring a land disturbing permit as prescribed in this chapter without first obtaining said permit, the person shall be subject to revocation of his or her business license, work permit or other authorization for the conduct of a business and associated work activities within the jurisdictional boundaries of the local issuing authority. (b) Stop work order. (1) For the first and second violations of the provisions of this chapter, the director or the local issuing authority shall issue a written warning to the violator. The violator shall have five days to correct the violation. If the violation is not corrected within five days, the director or the local issuing authority shall issue a stop work order requiring that land disturbing activities be stopped until necessary corrective action or mitigation has occurred; provided; however, that, if the violation presents an imminent threat to public health or waters of the state or if the land disturbing activities are conducted without obtaining the necessary permit, the director or the local issuing authority shall issue an immediate stop work order in lieu of a warning; (2) For a third and each subsequent violation, the director or the local issuing authority shall issue an immediate stop work order; (3) All stop work orders shall be effective immediately upon issuance and shall be in effect until the necessary corrective action or mitigation has occurred; (4) When a violation in the form of taking action without a permit, failure to maintain a stream buffer, or significant amounts of sediment, as determined by the local issuing authority or by the director or his or her designee, have been or are being discharged into state waters and where best management practices have not been properly designed, installed, and maintained, a stop work order shall be issued by the local issuing authority or by the director or his or her designee. All such stop work orders shall be effective immediately upon issuance and shall be in effect until the necessary corrective action or mitigation has occurred. Such stop work orders shall apply to all land disturbing activity on the site with the exception of the installation and maintenance of temporary or permanent erosion and sediment controls. (c) Bond forfeiture. If, through inspection, it is determined that a person engaged in land disturbing activities has failed to comply with the approved plan, a written notice to comply shall be served upon that person. The notice shall set forth the measures necessary to achieve compliance with the plan and shall state the time within which such measures must be completed. If the person engaged in the land disturbing activity fails to comply within the time specified, he or she shall be deemed in violation of this chapter and, in addition to other penalties, shall be deemed to have forfeited his or her performance bond, if required to post one under the provisions of this chapter. The issuing authority may call the bond or any part thereof to be forfeited and may use the proceeds to hire a contractor to stabilize the site of the land disturbing activity and bring it into compliance. (d) Monetary penalties. Any person who violates any provisions of this chapter, or any permit condition or limitation established pursuant to this chapter, or who negligently or intentionally fails or refuses to comply with any final or emergency order of the director issued as provided in this chapter shall be liable for a civil penalty not to exceed $2,500.00 per day. For the purpose of enforcing the provisions of this chapter, notwithstanding any provisions in any city charter to the contrary, municipal courts shall be authorized to impose a penalty not to exceed $2,500.00 for each violation. Notwithstanding any limitation of law as to penalties which can be assessed for violations of county ordinances, any magistrate court or any other court of competent jurisdiction trying cases brought as violations of this chapter under county ordinances approved under this chapter shall be authorized to impose penalties for such violations not to exceed $2,500.00 for each violation. Each day during which a violation or failure or refusal to comply continues shall be a separate violation. (Code 1986, § 21-7; Ord. No. 416, § 7, 1-20-1993; Ord. No. 528, § VII, 11-3-2005) Sec. 46-8. - Education and certification. After December 31, 2006, all persons involved in land development design, review, permitting, construction, monitoring, or inspection or any land disturbing activity shall meet the education and training certification requirements, dependent on their level of involvement with the process, as developed by the commission. (Ord. No. 528, § VIII, 11-3-2005) Sec. 46-9. - Administrative appeal, judicial review. (a) Administrative remedies. The suspension, revocation, modification or grant with condition of a permit by the local issuing authority upon finding that the holder is not in compliance with the approved erosion and sedimentation control plan; or that the holder is in violation of permit conditions; or that the holder is in violation of any ordinance; shall entitle the person submitting the plan or holding the permit to a hearing before the county board of zoning appeals within 60 days of written notice of appeal. (b) Judicial review. Any person aggrieved by a decision or order of the local issuing authority, after exhausting his or her administrative remedies, shall have the right to appeal de novo to the superior court of the county. (Code 1986, § 21-8; Ord. No. 416, § 8, 1-20-1993; Ord. No. 528, § IX, 11-3-2005) Sec. 46-10. - Liability. (a) 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 110/196 Neither the approval of a plan under the provisions of this chapter, nor the compliance with provisions of this chapter shall relieve any person from the responsibility for damage to any person or property otherwise imposed by law nor impose any liability upon the local issuing authority or district for damage to any person or property. (b) The fact that a land disturbing activity for which a permit has been issued results in injury to the property of another shall neither constitute proof of nor create a presumption of a violation of the standards provided for in this chapter or the terms of the permit. (c) No provision of this chapter shall permit any persons to violate the Georgia Erosion and Sedimentation Act of 1975, the Georgia Water Quality Control Act or the rules and regulations promulgated and approved thereunder or pollute any waters of the state as defined thereby. (Code 1986, § 21-9; Ord. No. 416, § 9, 1-20-1993; Ord. No. 528, § X, 11-3-2005)

div.head: Chapter 48 - SOLID WASTE
div.p: FOOTNOTE(S): (29) State Law reference— Authorization to provide garbage and solid waste collection and disposal, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(2); Georgia Comprehensive Solid Waste Management Act, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-20 et seq.; Litter Control Law, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-42 et seq. ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL Sec. 48-1. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Garbage means all refuse or domestic waste of animal, fruit, vegetable or grain origin that attends or is attributable to the preparation, use, cooking, dealing in, handling or storage of meat, fish, fowl, fruit, vegetables or grain and other organic materials or substances normally to be disposed of from residences, churches, schools, business establishments and similar places. Tin cans or other containers that have contained food are considered as garbage until they have been washed. Animal excrement or manure is considered as garbage. All other organic materials not specified herein are also considered as garbage, if such materials are not stored in a manner to prevent fly breeding; for example, improperly stored fertilizer or stock feeds, vegetables and grass cuttings, even though intended as feed for domestic animals. Other waste means animal carcasses, trees, shrubbery trimmings and all other refuse of organic origin occurring in a volume too great to be contained in six standard 35- gallon garbage containers with lids in place. Superintendent means the city's superintendent of streets and sanitation. Trash or rubbish means all nonedible refuse matter of organic or nonorganic origin, such as paper, rags, excelsior, wood, glass, tin cans, crockery, metals, ashes, yard trimmings and leaves, incapable of sustaining fly breeding. (Code 1962, § 10A-1; Code 1986, § 22-1) Sec. 48-2. - Landfill regulations and charges. The use of the city's sanitary landfill shall be subject to such regulations and charges as the board of commissioners may, from time to time, prescribe. (Code 1962, § 10A-7; Code 1986, § 22-2) Sec. 48-3. - Unlawful disposal generally. It shall be unlawful for any person to: (1) Burn any garbage or refuse, except waste paper, boxes, brush, grass, weeds and cuttings from trees, lawns or gardens, unless burned in a furnace or upon a permit from the fire chief and the superintendent. (2) Bury or deposit any garbage or refuse in such a manner as to be unsanitary or offensive to the sight or smell of the public. (Code 1962, § 10A-16; Code 1986, § 22-3) Sec. 48-4. - Securing of vehicle loads. No person shall convey or cause to be conveyed upon the public streets, alleys or lanes of the city any garbage, trash, rubbish or other materials of like nature, unless such materials are secured in such manner as to prevent them from falling or being blown from the vehicle while in transit. (Code 1962, § 10A-11; Code 1986, § 22-5) Sec. 48-5. - Unlawful accumulations. No person shall permit or suffer garbage or refuse to accumulate in or about any yard, lot, place or premises, or upon any street or sidewalk adjacent thereto or abutting thereon, owned or occupied by him or her or for which he or she may be the agent, within the city, or suffer such lot, yard, place or premises to be or remain in an unsanitary condition by reason of deposits of garbage or refuse. (Code 1962, § 10A-16; Code 1986, § 22-6) Sec. 48-6. - Trash containers on public property. The park commission is authorized to place suitable trash and rubbish containers within the city parks and on other city property wherever needed. 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 111/196 (Code 1962, § 10A-10; Code 1986, § 22-8) Secs. 48-7—48-33. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - COLLECTION BY CITY Sec. 48-34. - City's exclusive right. The board of commissioners of the city shall have the right, by resolution, to contract with private companies or individuals for the collection of garbage, trash, rubbish, or debris within the corporate limits of the city, under such terms and conditions as the board of commissioners may deem to be in the best interest of the citizens of the city. In the event that the board of commissioners contracts with a private corporation for the collection and disposal of garbage, trash, rubbish, or debris within the corporate limits of the city, then the terms of said contract shall be binding upon the residents of the city. (Code 1962, § 10A-18; Code 1986, § 22-21; Ord. No. 454, § 2, 2-6-1996) Sec. 48-35. - Prohibited collections—Construction waste. The city shall not be responsible for the collection and hauling of rubbish, trash, discarded building material, dirt, rock, metal or other like material originating from private property preliminary to, during or subsequent to the construction of new buildings or the remodeling of old buildings of any type. All such material shall be removed by the owner of the property or the contractor. In the case of new buildings, no certificate of occupancy shall be issued until such material has been removed. (Code 1962, § 10A-7; Code 1986, § 22-31) Sec. 48-36. - Same—Household appliances, raw animal waste and dead animals. The city shall not be responsible for the collection and hauling of household appliances, including refrigerators, stoves, washing machines, dryers and the like, raw animal waste and dead animals. (Code 1962, § 10A-7; Code 1986, § 22-32) Sec. 48-37. - Same—Dangerous materials. No person shall place or cause to be placed with material to be collected pursuant to this article any acid, corrosive or explosive material, flammable liquid or any other dangerous material of any kind. The city will not be responsible for the collection and disposal of such material. (Code 1962, § 10A-12; Code 1986, § 22-33) Sec. 48-38. - Interference with receptacles or materials set out for collection. No person, other than employees of the city charged with such duty, shall move, molest or interfere with any refuse receptacle or its contents or any other waste material set out for collection by city personnel, unless authorized by the superintendent of streets and sanitation. (Code 1962, § 10A-2; Code 1986, § 22-34) Secs. 48-39—48-64. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - YARD TRIMMINGS DISPOSAL REGULATIONS Sec. 48-65. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Commercial solid waste means all types of solid waste generated by stores, offices, restaurants, warehouses and other nonmanufacturing activities, excluding residential and industrial wastes. Composting means the controlled biological decomposition of organic matter into a stable, odor-free humus. Leachate collection system means a system at a landfill for collection of the leachate which may percolate through the waste and into the soils surrounding the landfill. Municipal solid waste means any solid waste derived from households, including garbage, trash and sanitary waste in septic tanks and includes solid waste from singlefamily and multifamily residences, hotels and motels, bunkhouses, campgrounds, picnic grounds, and day use recreation areas. The term "municipal solid waste" includes yard trimmings and commercial solid waste but does not include solid waste from mining, agricultural or silvacultural operations or industrial processes or operations. Municipal solid waste disposal facility means any facility or location where the final deposition of any amount of municipal solid waste occurs, whether or not mixed with or including commercial or industrial solid waste, including but not limited to municipal solid waste landfills. Municipal solid waste landfill means a disposal facility where any amount of municipal solid waste, whether or not mixed with or including commercial waste, industrial waste, nonhazardous sludges or small quantity generator hazardous waste, is disposed of by means of placing an approved cover thereon. Yard trimmings means leaves, brush, grass clippings, shrub and tree prunings, discarded Christmas trees, nursery and greenhouse vegetative residuals, and vegetative matter resulting from landscaping development and maintenance, other than mining, agricultural and silvacultural operations. (Ord. No. 460, § 1, 10-1-1996) Sec. 48-66. - Placement and disposal of yard trimmings; prohibitions. (a) It shall be unlawful to place or mix yard trimmings with municipal solid waste within the city. (b) Yard trimmings shall not be disposed at any municipal solid waste disposal facility having a liner and leachate collection system or requiring vertical expansion located within the city. (Ord. No. 460, § 2, 10-1-1996) 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 112/196 Sec. 48-67. - Sorting, storing, composting and collecting yard trimmings. Yard trimmings shall be sorted and stored in the following manner: (1) Leaves to be collected by the city shall be placed in piles just back of the curb in the area between the curb and sidewalk. If no sidewalk exists, the leaves should be piled in the same general vicinity, but so as not to block the flow of water in the side ditch of the street. (2) All branches, limbs and shrubbery to be collected by the city shall be cut into lengths of six feet or less and no single piece shall exceed 100 pounds in weight. (Code 1962, § 10A-5; Code 1986, § 22-30; Ord. No. 460, § 3, 10-1-1996)

div.head: Chapter 50 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS
div.p: FOOTNOTE(S): (30) State Law reference— City has power to construct and maintain roads, including curbs, sidewalks, street lights and devices to control the flow of traffic, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(4); municipal street systems, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-90 et seq.; powers with respect to municipal street system, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-92; regulation of maintenance and use of public roads generally, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-1 et seq.; obstruction of, encroachment on, solicitation on, or material injury to public roads, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-1. Sec. 50-1. - Consent required to open, close or alter street or alley. (a) No street or alley shall be opened, closed or altered without the consent of the board of commissioners. Any person intending to make application for such consent shall give at least 30 days notice of such intention to the board. (b) Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall, in addition thereto, be held responsible for the expense of restoring the street or alley interfered with to its original condition. (Code 1962, § 18-3; Code 1986, § 23-2) Sec. 50-2. - Excavations—Permit required. No person shall make any excavation in, or dig or haul earth from, any street, alley or other public way of the city without first obtaining a permit so to do from the city manager. (Code 1962, § 18-1; Code 1986, § 23-4) Sec. 50-3. - Same—Warning lights. All ditches or excavations made pursuant to a permit required by section 50-2, all tools and materials used in connection therewith and all displaced earth shall be lighted with sufficient red lights for safety to the public from sundown to sunup. (Code 1962, § 18-2; Code 1986, § 23-5) Sec. 50-4. - Use of streets for business purposes. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person, whether as agent or employee of another or otherwise, to make use of the public streets or alleys within the corporate limits of the city for the purpose of hauling or transporting persons or goods for gain or profit, or for the purpose of soliciting business, taking orders for or picking up or delivering any merchandise, laundry, dry cleaning, goods or other articles, for gain or profit, unless the board of commissioners shall have first granted to such person the privilege of using the streets and alleys for such purposes. (b) Except when otherwise provided by ordinance or resolution of the board of commissioners, the issuance by the city of a business license to a person shall confer upon the licensee, during the term of the license, the privilege of using the streets and alleys of the city for such purposes as the streets and alleys are usually and customarily used by businesses of the type and kind for which the license is issued, provided the licensee, when obtaining such license, has fully complied with all valid regulations of the city with regard to procuring the license and with regard to engaging in such business within the city. (c) The privilege of using the streets and alleys of the city for the purposes referred to in subsection (a) of this section shall be granted only by the issuance of a business license pursuant to this Code or some other applicable provision of this Code or by motion or resolution duly passed by the board of commissioners in lawful meeting assembled. No such motion shall be made and no such resolution shall be offered until the person desiring the privilege has filed with the city clerk a written application therefor, distinctly describing the use which such applicant expects to make of the streets and alleys. (Code 1962, §§ 13-28—13-30; Code 1986, § 23-6) Sec. 50-5. - Parking or storage of property on city-owned street rights-of-way. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person, corporation or entity to park or store motor vehicles on or to use city-owned street rights-of-way for the storage of any other personal property. 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 113/196 (b) Anyone violating this section shall be fined a minimum of $52.00 for each violation. If more than one vehicle is involved, then each vehicle shall constitute a separate offense. Each day that this section continues to be violated shall be a separate and distinct offense. (Ord. No. 526, § I, 11-3-2005) Sec. 50-6. - Drainage of water from buildings across sidewalks. Any person owning any building in the city, which building fronts on a sidewalk, shall be required to conduct water falling from the building across the sidewalk and into the street by means of pipes, drains or sewers constructed of material approved by the building inspector. If any person shall fail or refuse to so conduct the water from his or her building, when notified so to do, by the chief of police, he or she shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. In addition, the city shall install the necessary pipes, drains or sewers and the cost thereof shall be collected from such person by execution. (Code 1962, § 18-4; Code 1986, § 23-7) Sec. 50-7. - Procedures for disposal of narrow, irregularly shaped, small strips of city property. (a) The board of commissioners, on its own motion or upon the written request of any citizen or entity owning property abutting any strip of land in the city that is narrow or irregularly shaped and/or so small as to be incapable of being used independently as zoned or under applicable subdivision or other developmental ordinances, or as streets, may offer to sell the property to abutting property owners without the necessity of conducting an auction or requesting sealed bids after advertisement under the following terms and conditions: (1) Upon its own motion, or upon the request of any property owner whose property abuts a tract of city-owned property, the board of commissioners may conduct a preliminary investigation of any city property, reviewing information on the property, recommendations of the city manager, city utilities superintendent and any other city personnel or other interested parties. After an investigation, the board of commissioners shall make a finding as to the potential use of the property and its value to the city. (2) If the board of commissioners determines that the property is of a size and shape that is incapable of being used independently as zoned, or as a street (whether city owns the property, in fee simple, or the same is used by easement) and that the property is of no significant value to the city because of its size, shape and location, then the board of commissioners may declare that it is not practical to use the property as a tract and that it has no significant value or use to the city. (3) Upon a determination by the board of commissioners that the property cannot be used as a tract and is of no significant value to the city, the board of commissioners shall consider and determine at a public hearing at which it will consider any comments of any interested parties and the city personnel, and any other evidence which may be pertinent to the question, and shall make a determination as to whether the disposal of the property to the abutting landowners would facilitate the highest and best use of the abutting owner's property. If the board of commissioners makes an affirmative determination of this question, the board of commissioners may approve the property to be sold under subsection (b) of this section. This hearing shall be within 40 days of the motion by the board or the receipt of the written request from an adjoining property owner. (b) In the event that the sale of property under this section has been approved in accordance with subsection (a) of this section, the board of commissioners shall notify each abutting property owner by certified mail or by personal service by the police department of the availability of the property by purchase from the city. (1) This notification shall give the owners a minimum of ten days' notice and a maximum of 30 days' notice of the time and place of the meeting of the board of commissioners to conduct a sale of the property. At the meeting, all interested abutting property owners shall be given the opportunity to bid upon the property. At the meeting of the board of commissioners, the board shall have the option to agree to sell to the highest bidder or to reject all bids and retain the property for use by the city. The city shall have the right to retain an easement over any property that it decides to sell under this section or to sell less than fee simple title should the board of commissioners determine that the same is in the best interest of the city. (2) In the event the board of commissioners accepts the highest bidder or bidders for the property, the purchaser or purchasers shall be responsible for furnishing the city with a current survey of the property prepared by a state-registered surveyor; and the city shall, upon the payment of the agreed purchase price, furnish the purchaser with a quitclaim deed to the property in question. The city shall be under no obligation to transfer any property until the receipt of the aforementioned survey and full purchase price. The survey shall be delivered to the city a minimum of five days prior to closing. Closing shall be within 60 days of the date of the meeting in which the city agrees to sell said property. A 25 percent deposit shall be due and payable upon the acceptance of the bid, which shall be forfeited by the purchasers in the event the closing does not take place within 60 days and the time has not been extended by the city unless the failure to close is the fault of the city. All payments shall be made by cashier's check, cash, certified check, or money order. (3) In the event a citizen brings a request to the board of commissioners under this section, the request shall be accompanied by an administrative fee to handle the administrative costs of the city's investigating the property to make the determinations required in accordance with this section. The amount of the administrative fee shall be established by ordinance or resolution of the board of commissioners, from time to time, and made available for public examination in the office of the city clerk. In the event the city commission on its own motion institutes a determination proceeding, no administrative handling fee shall be assessed on any party. (Code 1986, § 23-11; Ord. No. 403, 8-6-1991) Sec. 50-8. - Parking on city sidewalks. It shall be unlawful for any person to park or drive a motorized vehicle upon the sidewalks of the city for any purpose, including the delivery of goods or the pickup of goods from any merchant. (Ord. No. 511, § 1, 2-3-2004) 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 114/196 Sec. 50-9. - Accepting merchandise delivery, loading from vehicle parked on city sidewalk. It shall be unlawful for any person to accept delivery of any merchandise from any vehicle parked on a city sidewalk or to load any merchandise offered for sale on to or into any vehicle parked on the city sidewalk in the city. (Ord. No. 511, § 2, 2-3-2004)

div.head: Chapter 52 - TAXATION
div.p: FOOTNOTE(S): (31) State Law reference— Taxation power of municipal and county governments, Ga. Const. art. IX, § IV, I(a) and (b)(2); ad valorem taxation of property, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-1 et seq.; municipal taxation, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-350 et seq.; local administrative provisions, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-380 et seq. ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL Sec. 52-1. - Property subject to taxation. All property liable to taxation under the laws of this state, both real and personal, within the limits of the city, shall be subject to taxation by the board of commissioners to such extent as may be necessary for the support and maintenance of the city government; provided, however, that the rate shall not exceed the authority granted by the laws of the state. (Code 1962, § 19-1; Code 1986, § 24-1) Sec. 52-2. - Tax rate and computation. The board of commissioners shall, assess such rate of tax as shall be sufficient for the support and maintenance of the city government during the year for which the tax is levied, subject to the limitation prescribed in section 52-1. The city clerk shall compute the tax due by each taxpayer, using for that purpose the value of property determined as provided in this chapter and the rate of taxation fixed by the board of commissioners. (Code 1962, § 19-7; Code 1986, § 24-2) Sec. 52-3. - To whom and when taxes payable; collection of delinquent taxes. All taxes shall be paid to the city clerk. All taxes, except license taxes, shall become due and payable each year in one payment on December 20, or 60 days from the date of the mailing of the tax notice, whichever is later. Should any person fail or refuse to pay his or her taxes on or before such due date, an execution shall be issued by the city clerk and the taxes shall then be collected in the manner prescribed by the Charter or by the state laws for collection of state and county taxes. (Code 1962, § 19-9; Code 1986, § 24-3) Sec. 52-4. - Property tax exemption. (a) The percentage of exemptions from taxation of certain personal property defined herein is hereby set at 20 percent of its value. (b) Pursuant to Official Code of Georgia Annotated, section 48-5-48.2 (O.C.G.A. § 48-5-48.2), the following tangible personal property is hereby included in the said exemption and has been approved by the citizens of the city: (1) Inventory of goods in the process of manufacture or production which shall include all partly finished goods and raw materials held for direct use or consumption in the ordinary course of the taxpayer's manufacturing or production business in the state. The exemption provided for herein shall apply only to tangible personal property which is substantially modified, altered or changed in the ordinary course of the taxpayer's manufacturing, processing or production operations in this state. (2) Inventory of finished goods manufactured or produced within the state in the ordinary course of the taxpayer's manufacturing or production business when held by the original manufacturer or producer of such finished goods. The exemption provided for herein shall be for a period not exceeding 12 months from the date such property is produced or manufactured. (3) Inventory of finished goods which, on January 1, are stored in a warehouse, dock or wharf, whether public or private, and which are destined for shipment to a final destination outside the state and inventory of finished goods which are shipped into the state from outside this state and stored for transshipment to a final destination outside this state. The exemption provided for herein shall be for a period not exceeding 12 months from the date such property is stored in this state. All property that is claimed to be exempt under the provisions of this subsection shall be designated as being "in transit" upon the official books and records for the warehouse, docks or wharfs, whether public or private, where such property is being stored. Such official books and records shall contain a full, true and accurate inventory of all such property, including the date of the receipt of the property, the date of the withdrawal of the property, the point of origin of the property, and the point of final destination of the same, if known. The official books and records of any such warehouse, dock or wharf, whether public or private, pertaining to any such in transit property, shall be at all times open to the inspection of all taxing authorities of this state and of any political subdivision of this state. (c) That the exemption amount of 20 percent of the value of the tangible property defined herein shall not be reduced in any amount until and unless such exemptions are revoked or repealed. (d) Any increase in the percent value of the property to be exempted as set by this section shall be increased only by the board of commissioners passing the appropriate ordinance to increase the amount of the exemptions. 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 115/196 (Code 1986, § 24-4; Ord. No. 311, §§ 1—4, 2-3-1986) Secs. 52-5—52-26. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - TAX ASSESSORS FOOTNOTE(S): (32) Editor's note— The board of commissioners has designated the county tax assessor to serve as the tax assessor for the city. Sec. 52-27. - Oath. The tax assessors appointed pursuant to section 54 of the Charter shall, before entering upon the discharge of their duties, take the following oath before some officer of the city: "I solemnly swear that I will faithfully and impartially perform the duties required of me as tax assessor for the City of Quitman during my continuance in office, and in all things pertaining to my office. So help me God." (Code 1962, § 19-14; Code 1986, § 24-16) Sec. 52-28. - Authority to require information from taxpayers. The tax assessors shall have authority to require any taxpayer to furnish them with a list of all notes, accounts, mortgages, stocks, bonds and other securities and investments and of all other property owned by them when, in their opinion, the same is necessary for a correct assessment. When a list of any property is required by the tax assessors, they shall give a ten-day notice to the taxpayer of whom the list is required and the notice shall state the day on which the list shall be furnished. If any person of whom such list is required and to whom such notice has been given fails or refuses to furnish the list, the assessors shall proceed to make such assessment as they may deem just and equitable. (Code 1962, § 19-18; Code 1986, § 24-17) Sec. 52-29. - Return of assessments made. The tax assessors shall make return of the assessments made by them to the board of commissioners on or before March 1 of each year. (Code 1962, § 19-17; Code 1986, § 24-18) Secs. 52-30—52-46. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - TAX RETURNS Sec. 52-47. - Notice to make. The city clerk shall give a 30 day notice to all taxpayers, by publication or otherwise, to come forward and make returns, such notice to be given 30 days before January 1 of each year. (Code 1962, § 19-2; Code 1986, § 24-31) Sec. 52-48. - Form and contents. The city clerk shall have prepared printed tax return forms, the form of which may be provided by the board of commissioners. The form shall be so arranged as to show the location of real estate, the character of improvements thereon, whether business houses or residences, with each lot or parcel separately listed, showing the section and lot number, and a schedule of personal property embracing the following items: merchandise, money and solvent notes, accounts, stocks, bonds, household and kitchen furniture, office furniture, jewelry, watches, pianos, horses, cattle, hogs, motor vehicles, guns, pistols and all other property not herein mentioned. Forms shall be delivered to all taxpayers of the city, upon application to the city clerk. (Code 1962, §§ 19-3, 19-5; Code 1986, § 24-32) Sec. 52-49. - Return to be at fair market value. Property returned pursuant to this article shall be returned by the owner or holder thereof at its fair market value. (Code 1962, § 19-7; Code 1986, § 24-33) State law reference— Property to be returned at fair market value, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-6. Sec. 52-50. - Oath to be attached. (a) The following oath shall be attached to the form for tax returns provided for by the board of commissioners: "I do solemnly swear that I have carefully read or have heard read, and have duly considered the questions propounded in the foregoing tax list, and that the value placed by me on the property returned as shown by the list is the true market value thereof; and I further swear that I have returned for the purpose of being taxed thereon every species of property that I own in my own right or have control of either as agent, executor, administrator, or otherwise; and that in making this return, for the purpose of being taxed thereon, I have not attempted either by transferring my property to another or by any other means to evade the laws governing taxation in this state. I do further swear that in making this return I have done so by estimating the true worth and value of every species of property contained therein." (b) The oath provided for in this section shall be subscribed by the person making the return and it may be attested by the officer receiving the same or by any other officer authorized to administer oaths under state law. (Code 1962, § 19-4; Code 1986, § 24-34) Sec. 52-51. - Filing. Tax return forms shall be filled out and sworn to by the taxpayer and shall be returned to the city clerk between January 1 and March 1 of each year, except that, after property is once returned by a taxpayer, no subsequent annual return need be filed by the taxpayer, unless additional property is acquired or improvements are made to 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 116/196 property returned. (Code 1962, § 19-5; Code 1986, § 24-35) Sec. 52-52. - Duty of clerk to receive. The city clerk shall receive the returns, under oath, of all persons liable to taxation by the city. (Code 1962, § 2-8; Code 1986, § 24-36) Sec. 52-53. - Consolidation and preparation of digest. The city clerk shall consolidate tax returns made to him or her, after the assessment of the value of the property so returned has been made by the tax assessors, and transcribe the same on a tax digest of the city in alphabetical order. (Code 1962, §§ 2-8, 19-8; Code 1986, § 24-37) Sec. 52-54. - Failure to make. If any taxpayer fails to make return of his or her taxable property upon the printed forms and by the time provided for in section 52-51, the tax assessor shall make return of his or her property from the best information obtainable, as provided by the law regulating tax returns in this state, and assess a double tax thereon, from which the taxpayer shall not be relieved except, for providential or other good and sufficient cause preventing the making of the return, such cause to be presented by the defaulter, in writing and under oath, to the board of commissioners. The sufficiency of such cause shall be passed upon by the board. The board may hear any evidence of the defaulter or of the tax assessors. (Code 1962, § 19-6; Code 1986, § 24-38)

div.head: Chapter 54 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES
div.p: FOOTNOTE(S): (33) State Law reference— Cities are authorized to exercise power over parking facilities and traffic control devices, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(4) and (11); power of local authorities with respect to uniform rules of the road, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-370 et seq.; jurisdiction of municipal courts over misdemeanor traffic offenses, O.C.G.A. § 40- 13-21(a). ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL Sec. 54-1. - Definitions. The definitions set forth in O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1 (Definitions), shall be effective as definitions of the words, terms and phrases used in this chapter. All words, terms and phrases used herein, other than those specifically defined elsewhere in this chapter, shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them in O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1, and shall have the same scope and effect that the same words, terms and phrases have where used in O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1. (Code 1986, § 14-1) Sec. 54-2. - General authority of board to regulate traffic. (a) The board of commissioners shall have the authority to exercise all of the powers enumerated under O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371(a) regarding the streets and highways within the corporate limits of the city. (b) Upon the adoption of any regulation authorized by O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371(a), it shall be the duty of the chief of police to cause to be installed signs, signals or markers at the affected locations in such manner as to give notice of the regulation to drivers of vehicles and pedestrians. No such regulation shall be effective until such signs, signals and markers have been installed, and it shall be unlawful for any driver or pedestrian to fail to comply with the directions of any such sign, signal or marker. (Code 1962, § 20-1; Code 1986, § 14-2) Secs. 54-3—54-22. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - OPERATION OF VEHICLES GENERALLY Sec. 54-23. - Rules of the road adopted. Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 40-6-1 et seq., the Uniform Rules of the Road of the State of Georgia are hereby adopted as and for the traffic regulations of the city with like effect as if recited at length herein. (Code 1962, § 20-01; Code 1986, § 14-16; Ord. No. 234, 12-11-1978) Sec. 54-24. - General speed limit. In the absence of duly authorized signs or signals establishing maximum speeds, it shall be unlawful for any person to operate any vehicle on the streets of the city at a greater rate of speed than 25 miles per hour. (Code 1962, § 20-15; Code 1986, § 14-17; Ord. No. 234, 12-11-1978) Sec. 54-25. - Speed limits on specific streets. (a) On-system zones. The following system speed zones are hereby established in the city: (1) 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 117/196 State Route 33 from south city limits (M.L. 11.01) to Hill Street (M.L. 11.73) a distance of 0.72 mile to be zoned 45 m.p.h. (2) State Route 33, school zone, from south city limits (M.L. 11.01) to Green Street (M.L. 11.42) a distance of 0.41 mile to be zoned 25 m.p.h. from 7:15 a.m. to 8:30 a.m. and from 2:45 p.m. to 3:30 p.m., school days only. (3) State Route 33 (State Route 76) from Hill Street (M.L. 11.73) to State Route 38 (U.S. 84, M.L. 11.97) a distance of 0.24 mile to be zoned 35 m.p.h. (4) State Route 33 (State Route 76) from State Route 38 (U.S. 84, M.L. 12.13) to Bartow Street (M.L. 12.38) a distance of 0.25 mile to be zoned 35 m.p.h. (5) State Route 33 (State Route 76) from Bartow Street (M.L. 12.38) to north city limits (M.L. 13.15) a distance of 0.77 mile to be zoned 45 m.p.h. (6) State Route 38 (U.S. 84) from west city limits (M.L. 9.64) to Tallokas Road (M.L. 10.06) a distance of 0.42 mile to be zoned 45 m.p.h. (7) State Route 38 (U.S. 84) from Tallokas Road (M.L. 10.06) to Quincy Street (M.L. 10.31) a distance of 0.25 mile to be zoned 40 m.p.h. (8) State Route 38 (U.S. 84) from Quincy Street (M.L. 10.31) to Southern Railroad (M.L. 11.00) a distance of 0.69 mile to be zoned 35 m.p.h. (9) State Route 38 (U.S. 84) from Southern Railroad crossing (M.L. 11.00) to Usher Street (M.L. 11.21) a distance of 0.21 mile to be zoned 40 m.p.h. (10) State Route 38 (U.S. 84) from Usher Street (M.L. 11.21) to east city limits (M.L. 11.63) a distance of 0.42 mile to be zoned 45 m.p.h. (11) State Route 76 from southwest city limits (M.L. 9.81) to State Route 33 (M.L. 9.92) a distance of 0.11 mile to be zoned 45 m.p.h. (12) State Route 76 from State Route (M.L. 11.80) to northeast city limits (M.L. 12.20) a distance of 0.40 mile to be zoned 55 m.p.h. (b) Off-system zones. The following off-system speed zones are hereby established in the city: (1) Twenty-five miles per hour zones. a. South Highland Street, from State Road 38 (U.S. 84) (Screven Street) to Haygood Street. b. North Webster Street, from State Road 38 (U.S. 84) (Screven Street) to its intersection with Moultrie Road. c. North Madison Street, from State Road 38 (U.S. 84) (Screven Street) to the north city limits. d. Barwick Road (Tallokas), from State Road 38 (U.S. 84) (Screven Street) to Bartow Street. e. Bartow Street, from Barwick Road (Tallokas) to State Road 33 (Washington Street) and from State Road 33 (Washington Street) to State Road 76 (North Highland Street). (2) Thirty-five miles per hour zones. a. South Highland Street, from Haywood Street to the southeast city limits. b. Moultrie Road, from the intersection of North Webster Street to the north city limits. 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 118/196 c. Barwick Road (Tallokas), from Bartow Street to the northwest city limits. (c) Signs. Signs giving notice of the speed zones established in subsection (a) of this section shall be erected by the state department of transportation. Signs giving notice of the speed zones established in subsection (b) of this section shall be erected by the city. When any such sign is in place, it shall be unlawful for any person to drive or operate a vehicle at a speed in excess of the limit indicated thereon. (Code 1962, § 20-15.1; Code 1986, § 14-18; Ord. No. 234, 12-11-1978; Ord. No. 369, 8-7-1989; Ord. No. 392, 9-4-1990) Sec. 54-26. - U-turns prohibited at certain intersections. Drivers of motor vehicles are prohibited from making a U-turn while proceeding along Screven Street at the intersection of East Screven Street with Washington Street and at the intersection of Screven Street with South Court Street. (Code 1962, § 20-20; Code 1986, § 14-19) Secs. 54-27—54-55. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - PARKING Sec. 54-56. - Marking of spaces generally. It shall be the duty of the city to keep streets plainly marked in the business district of the city, indicating the parking places within which motor vehicles may be parked. (Code 1962, § 20-26; Code 1986, § 14-31) Sec. 54-57. - Parking within marked spaces. It shall be the duty of all drivers of motor vehicles, when parking within the city, to park within duly marked parking spaces. (Code 1962, § 20-27; Code 1986, § 14-32) Sec. 54-58. - Marking and use of special spaces for doctors and police. The city manager shall have the authority to designate and mark exclusive parking spaces for motor vehicles used by medical doctors and the police department of the city. Any other person parking in the spaces so marked, or in any way interfering with their intended use, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. (Code 1962, § 20-31; Code 1986, § 14-33) Sec. 54-59. - Parallel parking required on certain streets. All motor vehicles parked on Forsyth Street, between South Washington Street and South Court Street, or portion thereof, shall be parked parallel with the curb and within the spaces marked off by the city as parking areas. (Code 1962, § 20-28; Code 1986, § 14-34) Sec. 54-60. - Maximum parking time generally. It shall be unlawful for any person to park or leave any vehicle upon the streets of the city for a period of 24 hours or longer. (Code 1962, § 20-29; Code 1986, § 14-35) Sec. 54-61. - Parking limit in business district. No vehicle shall be parked for more than one hour in any marked parking space in the business district, which is hereby designated for limited parking with a one-hour limit. (Code 1962, § 20-30; Code 1986, § 14-36) Sec. 54-62. - Parking in prohibited or restricted spaces. No vehicle shall be parked in a no parking space designated and marked pursuant to section 54-2, and no vehicle shall be parked in a restricted parking space so designated and marked, other than a vehicle operated by the person for whom the space is restricted. (Code 1962, § 20-32; Code 1986, § 14-37) Sec. 54-63. - Parking at alley or driveway entrance. No vehicle shall be parked at the entrance to any alley or the driveway into any business building, unless the space so situated has been marked by the city as a parking area. (Code 1962, § 20-32; Code 1986, § 14-38) Sec. 54-64. - Parking in loading zones. No vehicle shall be parked in a loading zone designated and marked pursuant to section 54-2, except for the purposes of loading and unloading merchandise, wares, goods, luggage, baggage, express or other like articles, and then only for the period of time reasonably necessary for the accomplishment of the loading or unloading. (Code 1962, § 20-32; Code 1986, § 14-39)

div.head: Chapter 56 - UTILITY SYSTEMS
div.p: FOOTNOTE(S): 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 119/196 (34) State Law reference— Home rule powers of municipality to regulate sewage collection and disposal systems and water treatment systems, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(6), (7); Georgia Water Quality Control Act, O.C.G.A. § 12-5-20 et seq.; unlawful to damage, injure or interfere with property of public utility companies, municipalities or political subdivisions, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-25; municipalities authorized to acquire, construct, operate and maintain water and sewage systems, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-5. ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL Sec. 56-1. - General duties of city clerk with respect to utilities. The city clerk shall receive all applications for city utility service, collect all charges for such service and keep a record of all receipts and expenditures connected with the city's utility systems. (Code 1962, § 2-8; Code 1986, § 25-1) Sec. 56-2. - Application for service. Application for any city utility service shall be made to the city clerk on blanks furnished by the clerk for that purpose. The application shall state the location of the premises and the uses for which the service is desired. (Code 1962, §§ 21-11, 21-43; Code 1986, § 25-2) Sec. 56-3. - Service outside city limits not required. Nothing in this chapter shall require or be construed as requiring the city to provide utility services to any applicant outside of the city limits. (Code 1986, § 25-3; Ord. No. 245, 1-14-1980) Sec. 56-4. - Customer deposits. The applicant for any city utility service shall pay, in advance, such deposit as may be prescribed, from time to time, by the board of commissioners. (Code 1962, 21-3, 21-36, 21-44; Code 1986, § 25-4) Sec. 56-5. - Unauthorized use or initiation of service. No person shall use any city utility service, or turn on or otherwise initiate any such service for any premises, either for the first time or after the service has been discontinued for any reason, without authority from the city. (Code 1962, 21-13, 21-15, 21-42; Code 1986, § 25-5) Sec. 56-6. - Utility rates, fees, and charges savings provision. Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code, shall be construed to repeal or otherwise affect the validity of the utility rates, fees, or charges prescribed by this chapter, or any ordinance contained therein or amendatory thereto. All such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code. Secs. 56-7—56-34. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - GAS Sec. 56-35. - Tapping charge. Each customer of the city's natural gas system shall pay a tapping charge and shall pay for pipe in excess of 100 feet used in making the connection. The tapping charge shall be established by ordinance or resolution of the city commission, from time to time, and made available for public examination in the office of the city clerk. (Code 1962, § 21-4; Code 1986, § 25-21; Ord. No. 263, 1-5-1982) Sec. 56-36. - Residential gas rates. The city does hereby establish two rate schedules for residential users of natural gas in the city. (1) Seasonal residential gas users, city rate A. Seasonal residential gas users are those customers who do not use natural gas on a yearround basis. All residential gas customers shall be initially categorized as seasonal gas users. The rate for seasonal gas users shall be established by ordinance or resolution of the city commission, from time to time, and made available for public examination in the office of the city clerk. (2) Yearround residential gas users, city rate B. a. Yearround residential gas users are those residential customers which have appliances which consume or use natural gas yearround in a significant amount. In order to qualify as a yearround user, the customer shall request that the city inspect and verify that the customer has appliances or other gas-using devices in the home such as would result in a continual consumption of gas for the entire year. The consumption of gas by the leaving of a pilot light burning or the fact that a barbecue grill is attached to city gas will not constitute a use such as would entitle the customer to rate B charges. The rate for yearround residential users shall be established by ordinance or resolution of the city commission, from time to time, and made available for public examination in the office of the city clerk. b. Should a customer be dissatisfied with the determination by city personnel after inspection the customer's home, the customer shall be entitled to appeal the determination to the utility hearing board. Upon an appeal to the utility hearing board, the customer shall be allowed to present evidence to show that he or she is qualified to a rate B charge and the city shall be allowed to present evidence substantiating the cities initial determination that rate A, not rate B, should be applied to the customer's account. The burden of proof shall be upon the customer. 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 120/196 c. In addition to the cost of the natural gas consumed plus Btu adjustment and sales tax, each residential gas customer shall pay a line charge each month. The line charge shall be established by ordinance or resolution of the city commission, from time to time, and made available for public examination in the office of the city clerk. (Code 1962, § 21-1; Code 1986, § 25-22; Ord. No. 235, 1-23-1979; Ord. No. 269, 7-6-1982; Ord. No. 276, 12-7-1982; Ord. No. 387, §§ 1, 2, 5-1-1990) Sec. 56-37. - Special rate for certain nonresidential customers. Nonresidential customers of the city's natural gas system who have facilities for using other fuels on days when interruptible gas service is not available to the city from its suppliers shall pay the city's cost, including Btu adjustment content, plus an additional charge per 1,000 cubic feet for gas. This rate is available by special contract only. The amount of the special rate shall be established by ordinance or resolution of the city commission, from time to time, and made available for public examination in the office of the city clerk. (Code 1962, § 21-1; Code 1986, § 25-23; Ord. No. 235, 1-23-1979; Ord. No. 269, 7-6-1982; Ord. No. 276, 12-7-1982) Sec. 56-38. - Adjustment of rate when city's wholesale cost changes. Whenever the wholesale cost of natural gas to the city is increased or decreased, the rate charged customers by the city shall be adjusted to the nearest whole mill, to reflect the increase or decrease, as of the first day of the following month. (Code 1962, § 21-1; Code 1986, § 25-24; Ord. No. 235, 1-23-1979; Ord. No. 269, 7-6-1982; Ord. No. 276, 12-7-1982) Sec. 56-39. - Disconnection and reconnection charges. In addition to the rates prescribed elsewhere in this article, the following charges shall be in force as to customers of the city's natural gas system: (1) Commercial customers using not more than 80,000 cubic feet of gas a month, a disconnection charge and a reconnection charge as established by ordinance or resolution of the city commission, from time to time, and made available for public examination in the office of the city clerk. (2) Commercial customers using more than 80,000 cubic feet of gas a month, a disconnection charge and a reconnection charge as established by ordinance or resolution of the city commission, from time to time, and made available for public examination in the office of the city clerk. (3) There shall be a seasonal disconnection charge for all customers disconnecting their gas service for a portion of a year. The term "seasonal disconnection" shall be defined as the disconnection of gas by the residential gas customers, with the intention to have the gas reconnected within a 12-month period of time. Should the gas customer state that the disconnection will be for a period of time in excess of one year, then no disconnection charge will be assessed. Should the gas customer or another member of his or her household request reconnection within the 12-month period of time after the disconnection fee was charged, there shall be assessed and paid by the gas customer prior to reconnection a reconnection fee. Disconnection charges shall not apply to periods of disconnection for repairs or for maintenance or replacement of short duration. These charges shall be established by ordinance or resolution of the city commission, from time to time, and made available for public examination in the office of the city clerk. (Code 1962, § 21-2; Code 1986, § 25-25; Ord. No. 248, 9-8-1980; Ord. No. 389, 5-17-1990) Sec. 56-40. - Gas meter recovery cost. (a) If any customer of the city's gas system so desires, a paid customer may request that his or her gas meter be tested. If the customer makes such a request, he or she shall be charged a testing fee. This testing fee shall be established by ordinance or resolution of the city commission, from time to time, and made available for public examination in the office of the city clerk. (b) If, after the testing has been completed, the meter is found to be two percent or more in error, then said customer shall be entitled to a refund of the testing fee. Additionally, there shall be an adjustment of the customer's bill for only the immediately preceding 12 months prior to the testing. (Code 1986, § 25-26; Ord. No. 345, 1-4-1988) Secs. 56-41—56-68. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - WATER FOOTNOTE(S): (35) State Law reference— Authority of city to provide water service, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(7). DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY Secs. 56-69—56-94. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - REGULATIONS Sec. 56-95. - Tap charges—Within city. (a) The charge for each water tap to serve property within the city, including the installation of the meter and up to 50 feet of pipe, shall be based upon the size of the tap. If any of the above tap sizes require the installation of more than 50 feet of pipe, the tapping charge, including the installation of the meter, shall be the cost of materials and labor, plus a charge calculated for each foot of pipe exceeding 200 feet. The tap charges shall be established by ordinance or resolution of the city commission, from time to time, and made available for public examination in the office of the city clerk. 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 121/196 (b) The charge for each water tap of three, four or six inches to serve property within the city, including the installation of the meter, shall be the total cost of materials, labor and use of equipment, plus ten percent of such total cost. (c) The water tap charges for any request or situation not specifically covered by this section shall be as prescribed by the board of commissioners. (d) All pipe, equipment and meters installed pursuant to this section shall be owned and maintained by the city. (Code 1962, § 21-28; Code 1986, § 25-36; Ord. No. 239, 9-10-1979; Ord. No. 353, 7-5-1988; Ord. No. 513, § 1, 5-4-2004; Ord. No. 514, § 1, 6-24-2004) Sec. 56-96. - Same—Outside city. Water taps to serve property outside the city limits shall be at the expense of the applicant. The charges shall be the same as the charges for taps inside the city, as provided for in this division. These charges shall be paid at the time of the application and, when the tap is completed, all material and equipment shall become the property of the city. The applicant shall provide, at his or her own expense, any and all necessary easements and rights-of-way to the city. (Code 1962, § 21-29; Code 1986, § 25-37; Ord. No. 245, 1-14-1980; Ord. No. 513, § 1, 5-4-2004; Ord. No. 514, § 1, 6-24-2004) Sec. 56-97. - Board approval required for certain connections. No connection to the city's water system which requires a tap larger than two inches in diameter or the installation of more than 300 feet of pipe shall be made, unless the board of commissioners has approved the connection, after receiving cost estimates and feasibility recommendations from the city manager. (Code 1962, § 21-28; Code 1986, § 25-38; Ord. No. 239, 9-10-1979) Sec. 56-98. - Maintenance and protection of consumers' pipes and fixtures; stopcock and waste cock required. Persons using city water shall keep their own pipes and all fixtures connected therewith in good repair and protected from freezing. They shall provide a stopcock and waste cock properly located inside the premises and have the pipes so arranged that the water can be cut off and drained therefrom whenever there is any danger of freezing. Water will not be furnished to any premises not provided with a stopcock and waste cock. (Code 1962, § 21-16; Code 1986, § 25-39) Sec. 56-99. - Repair of leaking connections. If the connection or branch pipe, stopcock or hydrant cock through which the premises of any person is supplied with water by the city becomes leaky and out of repair, it shall be the duty of such person to have the same repaired immediately. If such person shall fail or neglect to have the same repaired within 24 hours after notice is given to him or her by any police officer or other officer or employee of the city, he or she shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. (Code 1962, § 21-14; Code 1986, § 25-40) Sec. 56-100. - Pipes for fire protection to be sealed. Water pipes erected or installed in buildings for fire protection must be sealed and, as no charge will be made for water used in extinguishing fires, whenever the seals on outlets are broken, the consumer shall notify the city and have the seals renewed. (Code 1962, § 21-18; Code 1986, § 25-41) Sec. 56-101. - Consumer not to sell water or allow its unauthorized use. No consumer of city water shall sell water or allow it to be used by any person or for any purpose except those specified in the original application for service. (Code 1962, § 21-17; Code 1986, § 25-42) Sec. 56-102. - Polluting water supply. If any person shall willfully or knowingly pollute, contaminate or defile in any manner the water in any reservoir, standpipe, fountain, pipe or main connection with the waterworks in the city, he or she shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. (Code 1962, § 21-12; Code 1986, § 25-43) Sec. 56-103. - Second water meter regulations. (a) Residential customers; application; restrictions, etc. All residential customers of the city may request a second meter from the city by written application to the city manager's office. Said second meter shall be the same size as the meter presently servicing said residential customer. Said second meter shall be for the purpose of allowing water for all uses with the exception of such uses as would allow said water back into the sewage or storm drain system of the city. Specifically contemplated are the following uses: watering grass, flowers, shrubs and gardens; washing cars; water for animals, pools or any other use not specifically designated herein. No use shall allow the flow of said water back into the storm drain system of the city or the sewage system of the city. (b) Residential customer; cost of installation. Each residential customer shall pay the city the costs of installing the second water meter in such amounts as may be deemed appropriate by the board of commissioners of the city and, as such, may be changed from time to time by said board of commissioners. DIVISION 5. - WELLHEAD PROTECTION 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 123/196 Sec. 56-193. - Short title and purpose. (a) This division shall be known as the "Wellhead Protection Ordinance." (Ord. No. 508, § 1, 8-5-2003) Sec. 56-194. - Definitions. No. 344, art. 2, 12-7-1987) Secs. 56-220—56-246. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - SEWER USE Sec. 56-247. - Use of public sewers required. Sec. 56-249. - Building sewers and connections. (a) Permit required to uncover, connect to, alter, etc., any public sewer. No unauthorized person shall uncover, make any connections with or opening into, use, alter, or disturb any public sewer or appurtenance thereof without first obtaining a written permit from the city. (b) Permit application. The owner or his or her agent shall make application on a special form furnished by the city. The permit application shall be supplemented by any plans, specifications, or other information considered pertinent in the judgment of the city manager. A permit and inspection fee as specified elsewhere shall be paid at the time the application is filed. (c) Cost of installation and connection to be borne by owner; indemnification of city. All costs and expenses incidental to the installation and connection of the building sewer shall be borne by the owner. The owner shall indemnify the city from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned by the installation of the building sewer. (d) Separate building sewer required for every building; exceptions. A separate and independent building sewer shall be provided for every building; except where one building stands at the rear of another on an interior lot and no private sewer is available or can be constructed to the rear building through an adjoining alley, court, yard, or driveway, the front building may be extended to the rear building and the whole considered as one building sewer, but the city does not and will not assume any obligation or responsibility for damage caused by resulting from any such single connection aforementioned. (e) Use of old building sewers with new buildings. Old building sewers may be used in connecting with new buildings only when they are found, on examination and test by the city manager to meet all requirements of this division. (f) Construction standards. The size, slope alignment materials of construction of a building sewer, and the methods to be used in construction shall conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing code or other applicable rules and regulations of the state or county. In the absence of code provisions or in amplification thereof, the materials and procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of the American Society for Testing and Materials (ASTM) Water Pollution Control Federation (WPCF) Manual of Practice No. 9, and the American Water Works Association (AWWA) shall apply. Additionally, the following materials and methods shall apply to building sewers within city's supervision: (1) The building sewer shall be cast iron soil pipe, ASTM Specification A74, latest revision, or equal; ductile iron pipe, American National Standards Institute (ANSI) Specification A21.51, latest revision, or equal; or polyvinyl chloride (PVC) sewer pipe, ASTM Specification D3034, latest revision. All joints shall be tight and waterproof. Any part of the building sewer that is located within ten feet of a water service pipe shall be constructed of cast iron soil pipe or ductile iron pipe with bolted mechanical joints as may be required by the city manager where the sewer is exposed to damage by tree roots. If installed in filled or unstable ground, the building sewer shall be of cast iron soil pipe, except that plastic pipe may be acceptable if laid on a suitable concrete bed or cradle as approved by the city manager. (2) The size and slope of the building sewer shall be subject to the approval of the city manager, but in no event shall the diameter be less than four inches. The slope of such four-inch pipe shall not be less than one-eighth inch per foot. Furthermore, the appropriate requirements of the Occupational Health and Safety Act (OSHA) shall be followed. (3) 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 128/196 The depth shall be sufficient to afford protection from frost, and the building sewer shall be laid at uniform grade and with straight alignment insofar as possible. Changes in direction shall be made only with proper pipe fittings. Building sewers shall not be placed in the same trench with water service lines. (4) An excavation required for the installation of a building sewer shall be open trench work unless otherwise approved by the city manager. Pipe laying and backfill shall be performed in accordance with ASTM Specification D2321 for PVC pipe and AWWA C600 for cast and ductile iron pipe, latest revision, except that no backfill shall be placed until the work has been inspected and approved. (5) All joints and connections shall be made gastight and watertight. Push-on joints for cast iron soil pipe shall have neoprene gaskets in accordance with the requirements of ASTM C-564. Push-on joints for ductile iron pipe shall have neoprene gaskets and be installed according to the manufacturer's recommendations. PVC pipe joint shall be of the ball and spigot type, sealed with a rubber O-ring gasket, having a composition and texture which is resistant to the common ingredients of sewage, industrial wastes (including grease and oil), and groundwater, and which will endure permanently under the conditions likely to be imposed by this use. Installation of gasket shall be done in accordance with the pipe manufacturer's instructions using all the necessary materials, lubricants, and equipment recommended by the manufacturer. Other jointing materials may be used only when approved by the city manager. (6) The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer shall be made at the "Y" branch. If such a branch is available, the city shall, at the owner's expense, cut a neat hole into the public sewer, and install a saddle with entry in the downstream direction at an angle of about 45 degrees, and install a 45-degree elbow with the spigot end cut so as not to extend past the inner surface of the public sewer. The invert of the building sewer at the point of connection shall be at an elevation of at least one-tenth foot above the invert of the public sewer. A neat smooth joint shall be made, and the connection made secure and watertight by encasement in the connection only when approved by the city manager.
