(d) Limited discharges. The following described substances, materials, waters, or waste shall be limited in discharges to municipal systems to concentrations or quantities which will not harm either the sewers, wastewater treatment process or equipment, will not have an adverse effect on the receiving stream, or will not otherwise endanger lives, limb, public property, or constitute a nuisance. The limitations or restrictions on materials or characteristics of waste or wastewater discharge to the sanitary sewer which shall not be violated without approval of the city are as follows: (1) Wastewater having a temperature higher than150 degrees Fahrenheit (65 degrees Celsius) or wastewater which will elevate the temperature of the influent to the publicly owned treatment works (POTW) to 104 degrees Fahrenheit (40 degrees Celsius) or higher. (2) Wastewater containing more than 25 milligrams per liter of petroleum oil, nonbiodegradable cutting oils, or product of mineral oil origin. (3) Wastewater containing more than 100 milligrams per liter of oils, fat, grease, or was, whether emulsified or not, or containing substances which may solidify or become viscous at temperatures between 32 degrees Fahrenheit (0 C) and150 degrees Fahrenheit (65 C). (4) Any garbage that has not been properly shredded. Garbage grinders may be connected to sanitary sewers from homes, hotels, institutions, restaurants, hospitals, catering establishments, or similar places where garbage originates from the preparation of food in kitchens for the purpose of consumption on the premises or when served by caterers. (5) All industrial discharges to the city's sewer system must comply with the federal industrial pretreatment standards developed by the state environmental protection division. (6) Any waters or wastes containing taste- or odor-producing substances exceeding limits which may be established by the city. (7) Any radioactive wastes or isotopes of such half-life or concentrations as may exceed limits established in compliance with applicable state or federal regulations. (8) Quantities of flow, concentrations, or both which constitute a slug as defined in this article. (9) Waters or wastes containing substances which are not amenable to treatment of reduction by the municipal wastewater treatment processes employed, or are amenable to treatment only to such degree that the wastewater treatment plant effluent cannot meet the requirements of other agencies having jurisdiction over discharge to the receiving waters. (10) 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 130/196 Any water or wastes which, by interaction with other water or wastes in the public sewer system, release obnoxious gases, from solids which interfere with the collection system, or create a condition deleterious to structures and treatment processes. (11) Materials which exert or cause: a. Any unusual concentrations of inert suspended, such as, but not limited to, Fuller's earth, lime slurries, and lime residues, or of dissolved solids, such as, but not limited to, sodium chloride and sodium sulfate. Total suspended solids shall be limited to 250 mg/l or less. b. Excessive discoloration, such as, but not limited to, dye wastes and vegetable tanning solutions. c. Unusual BOD, above 200 mg/l, chemical oxygen demand in such quantities as to constitute a significant load on the sewage treatment plant. (e) Discharge of prohibited waters or wastes; action by city. If any waters or wastes are discharged or are proposed to be discharged to the public sewers, which waters contain the substances or possess the characteristics enumerated above and which in the judgment of the city, may have a deleterious effect upon the wastewater facilities, processes, equipment, or which otherwise create a hazard to life or constitute a public nuisance, the city may: (1) Reject the wastes; (2) Require pretreatment to an acceptable condition for discharge to the public sewers; (3) Require control over the quantities and rates of discharge; and/or (4) Require surcharge payment to cover added cost of handling and treating the wastes. (f) Grease, oil and sand interceptors; when used; exceptions; type; location, etc. Grease, oil, and sand interceptors shall be provided when, in the opinion of the city, they are necessary for the proper handling of liquid wastes containing floatable grease in excessive amounts, sand, or other harmful ingredients; except that such interceptors shall not be required for private living quarters or dwelling units. All interceptors shall be of a type and capacity approved by the city manager and shall be located as to be readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection. In the maintenance of these interceptors, the owner shall be responsible for the proper removal and disposal by appropriate means of the captured material and shall maintain records of the dates and means of disposal which are subject to review by the city manager. Any removal and hauling of the collected materials not performed by owner's personnel must be performed by currently licensed waste disposal firms. (g) Industrial wastes; structure and meters required; installation, etc. When required by (city) the owner of any property serviced by a building sewer carrying industrial wastes shall install a structure together with such necessary meters and other appurtenances in the building sewer to facilitate observation, sampling, and measurement of the wastes. Such structure, when required, shall be accessibly and safely located and shall be constructed in accordance with approved plans. The structure shall be installed by the owner at his or her expense and shall be maintained by him or her so as to be safe and accessible at all times. This requirement will be on a case-by-case basis. (h) Information to be provided by industrial users. The industrial users may be required to provide information needed to determine compliance with this division. These requirements may include: (1) Wastewater discharge peak rate and volume over a specified time period; (2) Chemical analyses of wastewaters; (3) Information on raw materials, processes, and products affecting wastewater volume and quality; (4) Quantity and disposition of specific liquid, sludge, oil, solvent, or other materials important to sewer use control; (5) A plot plan of sewers of the user's property showing sewer and pretreatment facility location; (6) 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 131/196 Details of wastewater pretreatment facilities; and (7) Details of systems to prevent and control the losses of materials through spills to the public sewer. (i) Special agreements between industrial users and city. No statement contained in this section shall be construed as preventing any special agreement or arrangement between the city and any industrial concern whereby an industrial waste of unusual strength or character may be accepted by the city for treatment. (j) Measurements, tests, etc., of water and waste characteristics; sampling methods, etc. All measurements, tests, and analyses of the characteristics of waters and wastes to which reference is made in this division shall be determined in accordance with the latest edition of Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater, published by the American Public Health Association. Sampling methods, location, times, durations, and frequencies are to be determined on an individual basis, subject to approval by the city. (k) Pretreatment of wastes. Persons discharging industrial wastes into the sewerage system may be required to pretreat such wastes. Plans for all pretreatment facilities shall be approved by the city manager and the state environmental protection division prior to construction. At the time written plans are submitted for approval, written maintenance plans shall also be submitted and approved by the city manager. The facilities shall be allowed to operate only as long as they are maintained in accordance with the approved maintenance plans. Pretreatment requirements shall be determined on a case-by-case basis and shall include the following facilities as a minimum: (1) Neutralization. If plans are submitted for the neutralization of strong acid or alkaline wastes, the plans shall include the necessary instrumentation and controls to assure compliance with the above regulations at all times. (2) Equalization. Holding tanks or equalization basins shall be required ahead of the receiving manhole of the city's sewerage system when deemed necessary by the city manager to prevent peak flows that exceed the capacity of the system or that result in operational problems. (3) All pretreatment facilities shall be operated and maintained continuously in satisfactory and effective operation by the owner at his or her expense. (l) Waiver of requirements. There shall be no provision for the granting of variances for discharge of incompatible wastes. If a user begins to violate any of the provisions of this section, it shall be his or her responsibility to apply to the city manager who can issue a temporary permit along with a compliance schedule for planning and construction of necessary treatment or pretreatment works. Each case will be carefully evaluated with respect to its effect on the wastewater treatment system and the environment prior to issuance of a temporary permit and compliance schedule. Any dilution of the wastewater by the user for the purpose of decreasing the concentrations of toxic materials shall be considered as a violation of this division. (m) Discontinuance of service for failure to comply. Failure to comply with the provisions of this section shall be cause for the discontinuance of sewer or water service to the offending person. The procedure shall be as follows: A written notice, signed by the city manager, shall be delivered personally to the person then responsible for the offending use, outlining the conditions of the wastes which violate the city's ordinances. In the event that the person in charge will not accept the notice, it shall be conveyed by registered mail to the responsible person. The person notified shall have 24 hours from the time of receipt of the notice, either personally delivered or received by registered mail, to correct the offending conditions. If correction is not made or a request for extension is not received by the city within 24 hours, it shall be mandatory that water or sewer service shall be discontinued to the offending person without further notice. If a request for an extension of time is received by the city within 24 hours of the above notice and if circumstances are such that, in the opinion of the city manager, the best interest of the city would be served by extending the time for correction of the offending condition, then he or she may grant an extension of time up to a maximum limit of 30 days. (n) Responsibilities of the person discharging waste. It shall be the responsibility of the company, corporation, or person discharging industrial waste into the city's sewerage system to: (1) Build a control structure in the discharge line from his or her premises, immediately prior to the entrance of the discharge line into the city's sewerage system, suitable for the sampling and measuring of wastes. Plans for this structure must be approved by the city. This requirement must be waived if deemed unnecessary by the city. In the event that no special manhole is required, the control manhole shall be considered to be the nearest downstream manhole in the public sewer to the point at which the building sewer is connected. (2) Contact the city manager prior to operation changes which will materially alter the characteristics of the waste from the last prior sampling. (3) Make timely, periodic payments to the city of surcharges for excessive loadings as detailed in the city's user charge system. (Code 1986, § 25-75; Ord. A quorum shall consist of four members of such board. (Code 1986, § 25-152; Ord. No. 250, 9-8-1980) Sec. 56-377. - Right to and notice of dispute; payment of undisputed portion of bill. At any time on or before the tenth day of each month, a customer may dispute the correctness of all or any part of the amount of his or her utility bill, by notifying the city manager, orally or in writing, of such dispute and stating, as completely as possible, the basis for the dispute. Such customer shall, at that time, pay all undisputed amounts of his or her utility bill. Failure to pay the undisputed amounts by the tenth day of the month shall result in the assessment of a delinquency charge pursuant to this chapter. (Code 1986, § 25-153; Ord. No. 251, 9-8-1980) Sec. 56-378. - Meeting with and decision by city manager. Within two working days of the receipt of a notice of dispute pursuant to this article, the city manager and such city personnel as the manager deems necessary, shall meet informally with the customer. Based on the city's utility records, the customer's allegations and all other relevant materials available, the city manager shall make a decision in regard to the dispute, attempting to do so in a manner satisfactory to both the city and the customer. The city manager shall give the customer written notice of his or her decision. (Code 1986, § 25-154; Ord. No. 251, 9-8-1980) Sec. 56-379. - Hearing before board. 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 138/196 (a) If a decision of the city manager under this article is unfavorable to the customer, the customer may request a formal hearing before the utility hearing board. Such request shall be in writing and shall be delivered to the city manager within two working days after the customer receives notice of the manager's decision. Upon receipt of such request, the manager shall immediately notify the chairperson of the utility hearing board, either orally or in writing, that a dispute is pending, and the chairperson shall set a time for a hearing thereon to be held within three working days thereafter. The city manager and the customer shall be notified of the time set for such hearing. (b) At a hearing under this section, the city and the customer shall be entitled to present all evidence that is, in the opinion of the chairperson of the utility hearing board, relevant to the dispute and to examine and cross examine witnesses. (Code 1986, § 25-155; Ord. No. 250, 9-8-1980; Ord. No. 251, 9-8-1980) Sec. 56-380. - Board's decision. Based upon the evidence presented at a hearing held pursuant to this article, the utility hearing board shall, by majority vote, render a decision on the dispute and notify the customer and the city manager in writing, within two working days. Such decision shall be subject to approval by the board of commissioners. (Code 1986, § 25-156; Ord. No. 250, 9-8-1980; Ord. No. 251, 9-8-1980) Secs. 56-381—56-403. - Reserved. ARTICLE VIII. - PROTECTION OF UNDERGROUND UTILITIES FOOTNOTE(S): (36) State Law reference— Georgia Utility Facility Protection Act, O.C.G.A. § 25-9-1 et seq. Sec. 56-404. - Definitions. (a) The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Mechanical equipment means equipment operated by means of mechanical power, including trenchers, bulldozers, power shovels, augers, backhoes, scrapers, drills, cable and pipe plows and other equipment used for plowing-in or pulling-in cable or pipe. Utility means any line, system or facility used for producing, storing, conveying, transmitting or distributing communication, electricity, gas, petroleum petroleum products, hazardous liquids, water, steam or sewage. Working day means every day, except Saturday, Sunday and national and legal state holidays. (b) The definitions set forth in O.C.G.A. § 25-9-3, shall be effective as definitions of the words, terms and phrases used in this article. All words, terms and phrases used herein, other than those specifically defined elsewhere in this article, shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them in O.C.G.A. § 25-9-3, and shall have the same scope and effect that the same words, terms and phrases have where used in O.C.G.A. § 25-9-3. (Code 1986, § 25-171; Ord. No. 280, § 2, 4-5-1983) State law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 25-9-3. Sec. 56-405. - Affect of article on civil remedies for personal injury or property damage. This article does not affect any civil remedies for personal injury or property (including underground utilities) damage, except as otherwise specifically provided for in this article. (Code 1986, § 25-172; Ord. No. 280, § 10, 4-5-1983) Sec. 56-406. - Excavation and demolition permits do not affect responsibility for complying with article. A permit issued pursuant to law authorizing excavation or demolition operations shall not be deemed to relieve a person from responsibility for complying with the provisions of this article. (Code 1986, § 25-173; Ord. No. 280, § 3, 4-5-1983) Sec. 56-407. - Precautions to avoid damage during excavation or demolition operations. In addition to the notification requirements of the Georgia Utility Facility Protection Act (O.C.G.A. § 25-9-1 et seq.), each person responsible for any excavation or demolition operation designated in this article shall: (1) Plan the excavation or demolition to avoid damage to, or minimize interference with, underground utilities in and near the area. (2) Maintain such clearance between an underground utility and the cutting edge or point of any mechanized equipment, taking into account the known limit of control of such cutting edge or point as may be reasonably necessary to avoid damage to the utility. (3) Provide such support for underground utilities in and near the area, including during backfill operations, as may be reasonably necessary for the protection of such utilities. 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 139/196 (Code 1986, § 25-179; Ord. No. 280, § 8, 4-5-1983) Sec. 56-408. - Procedure in case of damage. (a) Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, each person responsible for any excavation or demolition operation designated in this article that results in any damage to an underground utility shall, immediately upon discovery of such damage, notify the operator of such utility of the location and nature of the damage and shall allow the operator reasonable time to accomplish necessary repairs before completing the excavation or demolition in the immediate area of such utility. (b) Each person responsible for any excavation or demolition operation designated in this article that results in damage to an underground utility permitting the escape of any flammable, toxic or corrosive gas or liquid shall, immediately upon discovery of such damage, notify the operator and the police and fire departments and take any other action as may be reasonably necessary to protect persons and property and to minimize the hazards until arrival of the operator's personnel or police and fire department personnel. (Code 1986, § 25-180; Ord. No. 280, § 9, 4-5-1983)

div.head: Chapter 58 - VEHICLES FOR HIRE
div.p: ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL Sec. 58-1. - Streets; certain buses or trucks loading or unloading passengers or freight restricted; terminal required. (a) The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Bus or truck means a motor vehicle, including any trailer or semitrailer attached thereto, operated for hire, on regular or fixed routes or on regular or fixed schedules, for carriage of passengers or freight from points within the city to points beyond the city or from points beyond the city to point within the city, irrespective of whether the same are so operated in intrastate commerce or interstate commerce. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person to park or stop a bus or truck, as defined in subsection (a) of this section, on any street in the city for the purpose of receiving or discharging passengers or freight. (c) The owners of lessees of buses or trucks defined in subsection (a) of this section shall provide, within the city, a suitable terminal or station, with sufficient parking space at, near or around the same, for the parking of all of such buses or trucks in receiving and discharging passengers or freight, so that the streets of the city will not be used for parking purposes in receiving or discharging passengers or freight. (Code 1962, § 22-1; Code 1986, § 26-1) Sec. 58-2. - Bond or insurance for passenger vehicles—Generally. (a) Every person engaged in the business of operating motor vehicles for the transportation of passengers for hire, either with or without drivers, within the city shall, at all times while so engaged, carry and maintain, in full force and effect, and file in the office of the city manager a bond, for injury to any one person, for injury to more than one person in the same accident and for damage to property resulting from any one accident. The amounts for each classification designated in the bond shall be designated by ordinance or resolution of the board of commissioners, from time to time, and made available for public examination in the office of the city clerk. The bond shall have, as surety thereon, a surety company duly authorized and qualified to transact a surety business in the state and having an agent in the city, or shall be secured by a cash deposit in the amounts set forth by ordinance or resolution of the board of commissioners, and shall be payable in and to the city and shall be and insure: (1) For and to the benefit of any person who shall receive personal injuries by reason of the negligence or misconduct of the driver or operator of any such motor vehicle while the vehicle is being operated within the city or adjacent territory. (2) For and to the benefit of any person titled to recover, under the laws of the state, for the death of any person who shall die by reason of injury caused by the negligence or misconduct of the driver or operator of any such motor vehicle while the vehicle is being operated within the city or adjacent territory. (3) For and to the benefit of any person who shall sustain damage to his or her property by reason of the negligence or misconduct of the driver or operator of such motor vehicle while the motor vehicle is being operated in the city or adjacent territory. (b) The bond required by this section shall be conditioned to indemnify passengers and the general public receiving personal injuries or sustaining property damage from any act of negligence or misconduct of the obligor or any of his or her servants, agents or employees in the operation of any motor vehicle used in his or her transportation business. The bond shall be payable in the city and shall be for the benefit of and subject to action thereon by any person described in subsection (a) of this section. (c) In lieu of the bond required by the foregoing provisions of this section, the operator of a motor transportation business described in this section may file a policy of liability insurance with a casualty or insurance company authorized and qualified to transact business in the state and having an agent in the city, with liability in at least the minimum amounts specified for such bond. The insurance policy shall provide for the payment of the same amounts and to the same persons and under the same terms and conditions as provided with respect to such bond. 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 140/196 (d) The city manager shall not accept any bond or insurance policy required by this section, unless the same has been approved, as to form and substance, by the city attorney. (Code 1962, §§ 22-2—22-4, 22-6, 22-7; Code 1986, § 26-2) Sec. 58-3. - Same—Prerequisite to licensing. No license shall be issued to engage in or continue in the business of the transportation of persons for hire within the city, unless the bond or insurance policy required by section 58-2 has been filed with the city manager and is in full force and effect. (Code 1962, § 22-5; Code 1986, § 26-3) Sec. 58-4. - Same—Cancellation. No bond or insurance policy filed pursuant to this chapter shall be cancelled by the company issuing the same, except upon a 20 notice, in writing, to the city manager. Upon such notice being given by the company issuing the bond or policy, the license of the person giving or furnishing the bond or policy shall be revoked, unless a new bond or policy is filed and approved before the date of the cancellation. (Code 1962, § 22-5; Code 1986, § 26-4) Secs. 58-5—58-26. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - TAXICABS DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY Sec. 58-27. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Taxicab means any motor vehicle operated for the transportation of passengers for hire on the streets of the city and the territory adjacent thereto, but not operated on fixed routes with fixed schedules. (Code 1962, § 22-14; Code 1986, § 26-16) Sec. 58-28. - Compliance with article. It shall be unlawful for any person, either as principal, agent or employee, to use or operate on any street or public place in the city any motor vehicle used as a taxicab, without complying with the provisions of this article. (Code 1962, § 22-15; Code 1986, § 26-17) Sec. 58-29. - Reservation of rights of board to regulate. All licenses and permits issued under this article shall be subject to the right of the board of commissioners, from time to time, to make or adopt any ordinances, resolutions and regulations further controlling, regulating and governing the operation of taxicabs and taxicab businesses. (Code 1962, § 22-16; Code 1986, § 26-18) Sec. 58-30. - General vehicle requirements. Every taxicab operated under this article shall be well built, kept in good repair and in clean and sanitary condition and capable of safely and comfortably transporting passengers. (Code 1962, § 22-31; Code 1986, § 26-19) Sec. 58-31. - Identification of vehicles. (a) Within ten days of the assignment of a taxi number to a motor vehicle by the city clerk pursuant to this chapter, the owner of the vehicle shall cause to be painted upon each side of the body thereof, between the front door and the hood or, if no space is available at this location, on the back edge of the hood or on the upper front corner of the front door, and on the rear, just below the rear glass of the vehicle, the word "TAXI" in two-inch letters and below the word "TAXI" the number which has been assigned to the vehicle, in four-inch figures. No other numbers, words, printing or other matter shall be printed or exhibited within 12 inches of such lettering and numbering. (b) Lettering and numbering required by this section shall be of such coloring and against such background as to be plainly visible. (Code 1962, § 22-27; Code 1986, § 26-20) Sec. 58-32. - Inside lights required. Taxicabs as operated under this article shall be equipped on the inside with lights which furnish illumination at night for the convenience of passengers. (Code 1962, § 22-32; Code 1986, § 26-21) Sec. 58-33. - Inspection. Every taxicab operated under this article shall at all times be subject to inspection by the police department or its designated mechanic or garage. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a taxicab when the same has been disapproved by the police department. (Code 1962, § 22-31; Code 1986, § 26-22) 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 141/196 Sec. 58-34. - Information relating to drivers to be filed with city clerk. Each person to whom a license is issued pursuant to this article shall file with the city clerk a list stating the name, age and address of each driver employed by the licensee and the number of the permit issued to such driver pursuant to this article. Any change in the information so furnished, through termination of employment, addition of new drivers or otherwise, shall be immediately reported to the city clerk by the licensee. (Code 1962, § 22-17; Code 1986, § 26-23) Sec. 58-35. - Maximum rates. It shall be unlawful for any person operating a taxicab in the city to charge, for the transportation of persons or their baggage, any sum or sums in the excess of the rates prescribed, from time to time, by the board of commissioners. (Code 1962, § 22-28; Code 1986, § 26-24) Sec. 58-36. - Rates to be displayed. Each operator of a taxicab in the city shall at all times exhibit, in a prominent and conspicuous place in the taxicab, visible to the occupants of both the front and rear seats thereof, a schedule of rates or charges for the transportation services furnished. Such schedule shall be furnished by the city clerk to the operator with each license issued under this article for the operation of a taxicab. (Code 1962, § 22-29; Code 1986, § 26-25) Sec. 58-37. - Use of street as stand; stopping on street to receive or discharge passengers. No person shall use any portion of a street as a taxicab stand, without the consent of the board of commissioners. The driver of a taxicab shall not stop such vehicle upon any street for the purpose of receiving or discharging passengers, except at the curb of the street at its intersection with another street, and then only for such time as is reasonably necessary to receive or discharge the passengers and provided in such position as not to interfere with pedestrians crossing the street. (Code 1962, § 22-34; Code 1986, § 26-26) Sec. 58-38. - Disposition of articles left in vehicle by a passenger. The driver of a taxicab shall carefully preserve any article left in the vehicle by a passenger. If not called for by the owner in 24 hours, such article shall thereupon be turned over to the chief of police for safekeeping and identification by the owner. When the owner calls for the same, either in the hands of the driver, licensee or chief of police, and proves his or her ownership, the article shall be promptly delivered to him or her. (Code 1962, § 22-33; Code 1986, § 26-27) Secs. 58-39—58-62. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - LICENSE Sec. 58-63. - Required. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person, either as owner, lessee or otherwise, to engage in the business of operating a taxicab in the city, without first obtaining a license from the city clerk. (b) The provisions of article I of chapter 30 of this Code shall apply to a license required by this section, except those provisions which are in conflict with any provision of this division. (Code 1962, § 22-17; Code 1986, § 26-41) Sec. 58-64. - Application. Written application for a license required by this division shall be filed with the city clerk. Such application shall contain: (1) The name of the applicant, his or her home address and the name and address of his or her business. (2) The number of motor vehicles proposed to be operated as taxicabs and the following information concerning each such vehicle: make; factory number; motor number; seating capacity; and name of the owner. (Code 1962, § 22-17; Code 1986, § 26-42) Sec. 58-65. - Information required from corporation applicants. If the applicant for a license under this division is a corporation, a certified copy of its charter, accompanied by a statement showing the amount of capital actually paid into the corporation and the names and places of residence of all officers thereof, shall be filed with the city clerk at the time the license application is filed. (Code 1962, § 22-17; Code 1986, § 26-43) Sec. 58-66. - Fee. The fee for a license required by this division shall be established by ordinance or resolution of the board of commissioners, from time to time, and made available for public examination in the office of the city clerk. (Code 1962, § 22-17; Code 1986, § 26-44) 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 142/196 Sec. 58-67. - Issuance and assignment of vehicle number. (a) When the applicant has complied with applicable provisions of article I of chapter 30 of this Code, the provisions of section 58-2 of this chapter and the provisions of this division, the city clerk shall issue a license applied for under this division. (b) When a license is issued under this section, the city clerk shall assign a taxi number to each vehicle to be operated as a taxicab pursuant to the license. The clerk shall keep a permanent record of the number so assigned, which record shall be accessible to the public at all time during office hours. (Code 1962, §§ 22-25, 22-26; Code 1986, § 26-45) Sec. 58-68. - Revocation. The board of commissioners reserves the right to revoke any license issued pursuant to this division at any time for a violation by the licensee of the provisions of this article or any other ordinance of the city, when the safety of the public demands such action. (Code 1962, § 22-18; Code 1986, § 26-46) Secs. 58-69—58-94. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - DRIVER'S PERMIT Sec. 58-95. - Required. No person shall drive a taxicab for the transportation of persons for hire within the city, unless he or she has a current permit to do so issued pursuant to this division. (Code 1962, § 22-19; Code 1986, § 26-61) Sec. 58-96. - Application. Written application for a permit required by this division shall be filed with the city clerk. Such application shall contain the name, age and address of the applicant, together with such information as will enable the city clerk to determine if the applicant is qualified to receive the permit. Sec. 58-97. - Qualifications of applicant. Each applicant for a permit required by this division shall be at least 18 years of age and shall possess a current driver's license issued by the state. No such permit shall be issued to any person who has, within one year prior to the date of the application, been convicted of any of the following offenses: (1) Operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcoholic beverages or opiates. (2) Transporting alcoholic beverages for the purpose of sale contrary to the laws of the state or the ordinances of the city. (3) Transporting persons for immoral purposes contrary to the laws of the state or the ordinances of the city. (4) Any crime involving moral turpitude which, in the opinion of the board of commissioners, renders such person unfit to operate a motor vehicle for the transportation of persons for hire. (5) Violation of the traffic ordinances of the city. (Code 1962, § 22-22; Code 1986, § 26-63) Sec. 58-98. - Fee. Before a permit required by this division is issued or renewed, the applicant shall pay such fee therefor as is prescribed by the board of commissioners. (Code 1962, § 22-19; Code 1986, § 26-64) Sec. 58-99. - Issuance; term. Upon a qualified applicant's compliance with the provisions of this division, the city clerk shall issue the permit required by this division. Such permit shall be valid for the remainder of the calendar year in which issued, unless sooner suspended or revoked. (Code 1986, § 26-65) Sec. 58-100. - Revocation or suspension. (a) After a hearing, the board of commissioners may revoke the permit issued under this division to the driver of a taxicab, if such driver is convicted of a violation of any provision of this article, of any offense mentioned in section 58-97, or if the board receives a report from the chief of police of facts affecting the proficiency, sobriety or character of such driver. (b) 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 143/196 For the temporary period from any conviction referred to in subsection (a)of this section, until a final hearing by the board of commissioners on the revocation of the violator's taxicab driver's permit, the city manager may suspend such permit. (Code 1962, § 22-24; Code 1986, § 26-66) Secs. 58-101—58-128. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - WRECKERS Sec. 58-129. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Chief means the chief of the police department of the city and any officer specifically designated by him or her to administer and carry out the provisions of this article; Disabled shall be limited to refer to a motor vehicle disabled on a public way or other public places in such a manner as to obstruct vehicular or pedestrian travel or access to public or private property. Operator includes such persons, firms, corporations or associations owning or operating wreckers for, on behalf of, or within a wrecker service in the city and all officers, agents and employees of such persons, firms, corporations or associations who are engaged in the business of the wrecker service. Wrecker means an automobile vehicle equipped and used for the purpose of towing and hauling wrecked or disabled vehicles or other motor vehicle. Wrecker service means any person, firm, corporation or association regularly engaged in the business of towing or hauling wrecked or disabled vehicles for hire within the city, whether or not such wrecker service maintains an office within the corporate limits of the city. (Code 1986, § 26-72; Ord. No. 422, § 2, 5-4-1993) Sec. 58-130. - Enforcement. It shall be the duty of the chief of police to administer and carry out the provisions of this article. All law enforcement officers of the city shall have the authority to prosecute violations of this article. (Code 1986, § 26-73; Ord. No. 422, § 3, 5-4-1993) Sec. 58-131. - Towing wrecked, abandoned or disabled motor vehicle from public way or other public place. It shall be unlawful for any wrecker service or operator to tow or haul any motor vehicle which has been wrecked, abandoned or disabled on a public way or other public place within the jurisdiction of the city from the scene of a wreck, abandonment or disablement except in compliance with the provisions of this article. (Code 1986, § 26-74; Ord. No. 422, § 4, 5-4-1993) Sec. 58-132. - City's rotation system—Wrecker required to be on list. At all times, when necessary for the police department to remove any motor vehicle for any cause from any place within the jurisdiction of the city, no wrecker shall be used to tow or haul such vehicles unless that wrecker is on the city's rotation system; provided, however, that this article shall not be construed to prohibit the police department from using a wrecker owned by the city to tow or haul an abandoned vehicle or a vehicle to be impounded in connection with a criminal investigation or to prohibit the use of a wrecker not in the rotation system under circumstances where police jurisdiction is not involved. For purpose of this section, police jurisdiction shall be deemed to exist in all cases of vehicular wreck or collision, all cases in which a criminal offense is under investigation, all cases in which a vehicular disablement results in obstruction of use of or travel on a public right-of-way and all cases of abandonment of a vehicle on a public right-of-way or public place. (Code 1986, § 26-75; Ord. No. 422, § 5, 5-4-1993) Sec. 58-133. - Same—Application. In order to be placed on the rotation system, the owner or operator of a wrecker shall file an application with the chief, supplying the following information: (1) Title certificate number of the wrecker, date issued, and the name, home and business address and telephone number of the owner or owners of the wrecker. (2) Complete home and business address and telephone number of the principal operator and operator's of the wreckers. (3) Description of the wrecker to be registered, including the make model, vehicle identification number and capacity. (4) Date the vehicle was first placed in service as a wrecker. (5) Name of the wrecker service operating the wrecker and all persons having a financial interest therein. (6) Persons including all agents and employees, authorized to operate the wrecker/s and class of drivers license held by each operator. (7) The location and telephone number of the office or garage to and from which the wrecker is operated. 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 144/196 (8) The name and address of the insurance company or companies providing motor vehicle liability coverage for the wrecker/s and wrecker service and general comprehensive liability coverage for the business operations, the policy number of each insurance policy, the policy limits provided by each policy, and expiration date of each policy. (9) Owner/driver must successfully pass a background examination of employment, driver and criminal history. It shall be the policy of the city police department that no owner/driver shall be added to the wrecker rotation who has been adjudicated guilty of crime involving theft, use of drugs or alcohol or crimes involving moral turpitude. (Code 1986, § 26-76; Ord. No. 422, § 6, 5-4-1993; Ord. No. 472A, § 26-76, 1-6-1998) Sec. 58-134. - Inspection. The chief or his or her designate shall inspect each wrecker before approving the application for placement on the rotation system, to determine whether the same is serviceable, properly equipped and in compliance with the requirements of this article and with other applicable laws. Thereafter, the chief or his or her designate shall inspect each wrecker annually. (Code 1986, § 26-77; Ord. No. 422, § 7, 5-4-1993) Sec. 58-135. - Weight and equipment requirements. Each wrecker shall have a minimum rating of not less than10,000 pounds gross vehicle weight, and shall be minimally equipped with the following additional equipment: one broom, one shovel, one ABC type fire extinguisher, one two-way radio capable of transmitting and receiving over a distance of ten miles under normal conditions, and a revolving amber emergency light mounted on the top of the cab or boom of the vehicle. (Code 1986, § 26-78; Ord. No. 422, § 8, 5-4-1993) Sec. 58-136. - Cleaning debris from wreck area. The removal of broken glass and other debris from the scene of an accident shall be part of the wrecker services obligation pursuant to this article. When two or more wrecker services are assigned to one scene, all shall be equally responsible for cleaning debris from the wreck area. (Code 1986, § 26-79; Ord. No. 422, § 9, 5-4-1993) Sec. 58-137. - Display of amber emergency light. A wrecker operator shall not display the amber emergency light except upon arrival at the scene where a call originated and when leaving the scene with the vehicle in tow. Each wrecker operator shall abide by all applicable traffic regulations and shall be responsible for any violation incurred in the process of responding to a call. (Code 1986, § 26-80; Ord. No. 422, § 10, 5-4-1993) Sec. 58-138. - Area for storage of towed vehicles. Each wrecker service shall maintain an area for storage of towed vehicles, either within or without of the city, sufficient to provide storage in a manner not inconsistent with the applicable zoning ordinances or other laws. If outside the city, the storage area shall be not more than five miles from the city limits by the shortest route of vehicular travel. The storage area shall be enclosed or the entire perimeter fenced. Towed or hauled vehicles shall not be parked or left standing on any city right-of-way at any time or under any circumstances. All stored vehicles shall be subject to reclamation 24 hours a day. (Code 1986, § 26-81; Ord. No. 422, § 11, 5-4-1993) Sec. 58-139. - Liability insurance required. In addition to the motor vehicle liability insurance required by state law, each wrecker shall maintain general comprehensive liability and garage and extended operation insurance on business operations providing a minimum of $25,000.00 single-limit coverage per occurrence. The chief may require each wrecker service to furnish copies of its insurance certificates showing the amount of coverage and expiration of the policies required by the section and other laws. (Code 1986, § 26-82; Ord. No. 422, § 12, 5-4-1993) Sec. 58-140. - Display of name and address and telephone number required. Each wrecker shall have the name, address and telephone number of its business displayed on both sides of the vehicle. Said information shall be permanently painted onto the side of the vehicle in block letters in contrasting color of not less than 2½ inches in height. Attachment to the vehicle of removable signs for this purpose shall not be allowed. (Code 1986, § 26-83; Ord. No. 422, § 13, 5-4-1993) Sec. 58-141. - Preparation and maintenance of rotational call list. It shall be the duty of the chief of police or his or her designate to prepare and maintain a rotational call list of wreckers which meet the qualifications, standards, and requirements enumerated in this article. Each wrecker service shall have no more than one listing on the rotational call list for each business address. (Code 1986, § 26-84; Ord. No. 422, § 14, 5-4-1993) Sec. 58-142. - Order in which wreckers will be called. At any time it becomes necessary for the police department to remove any vehicle for any cause, the police radio operator, or such person as may be designated by the chief, shall engage the services of those on the rotational call list by calling them in order of call to wit: Service A, Service B, Service C, Service A, Service B, Service C and in rotation provided. However, a deviation from this order may occur and be permitted if: (1) The next rotation wrecker service does not have a wrecker available with sufficient capacity to handle the call; 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 145/196 (2) The owner or person in possession of a vehicle or person in possession of a vehicle about to be removed designates a wrecker service of his or her preference; (3) In the event the wrecker service called in rotation does not respond within 20 minutes after receiving the call, the next designated wrecker service in the rotation shall be called; In the event such person designates a wrecker service of his or her preference, that wrecker service shall be called whether or not it is next on the rotational call list, and such designation shall not interfere with such wrecker's position on the call list; however, if it is necessary to skip over one or more wrecker services because they do not have a wrecker with sufficient capacity to handle a particular call, the wrecker service or services skipped over shall not lose position on the rotation list, but the wrecker service which handles the call shall lose position. (Code 1986, § 26-85; Ord. No. 422, § 15, 5-4-1993) Sec. 58-143. - Calls to wrecker services to be made by police radio operator or designee. All calls to wrecker services shall be made by the police radio operator or such person as may be designated by the chief, and in no event shall an investigating officer undertake to call directly for a wrecker service. Police officers are strictly prohibited from recommending any particular wrecker service to any person, and any police officer violating this provision shall be subject to appropriate disciplinary action. (Code 1986, § 26-86; Ord. No. 422, § 16, 5-4-1993) Sec. 58-144. - Solicitation scene of accident prohibited. It shall be a violation of this article for any wrecker operator, wrecker service or other person to solicit business at the scene of a motor vehicle accident or other vehicular disablement, whether such solicitation be conducted from a wrecker vehicle, private vehicle, other motor vehicle, or on foot. (Code 1986, § 26-87; Ord. No. 422, § 17, 5-4-1993) Sec. 58-145. - Proceeding without being called, impeding traffic prohibited. It shall be a violation of this article for any wrecker operator to proceed to the scene of an accident or vehicular disablement unless called as provided hereinabove. Upon being so called, a wrecker operator shall not block traffic and shall maintain his or her vehicle in such position as not to impede emergency vehicles and/or normal vehicular traffic. (Code 1986, § 26-88; Ord. No. 422, § 18, 5-4-1993) Sec. 58-146. - Release of vehicle by investigating officer required. No vehicle shall be removed from the scene of a wreck, abandonment or disablement until it is released by the investigating officer. The chief or his or her designated officers of the city police department may direct that a vehicle to be removed shall be impounded and towed or hauled to the city's impoundment area, and in such event, it shall be a violation of this article for any wrecker operator to remove a vehicle to any other location. No vehicle shall be released or moved until a written release is obtained from the police department. The police officer may, at his or her discretion, require inside secured storage of the vehicle until any investigation and processing is completed. (Code 1986, § 26-89; Ord. No. 422, § 19, 5-4-1993) Sec. 58-147. - Vehicle inventory; procedure. (a) Whenever any vehicle is removed by a wrecker service without the owner or operator present, the police officer shall make a thorough inventory of all equipment, accessories, personal articles or other items either attached to or located within the vehicle. Said inventory shall be completed on the form supplied by the police department and signed by the officer in charge of the removal. Upon acceptance of the vehicle, and prior to its removal, the agent or employee of the wrecker service performing the removal shall sign the inventory form. The officer shall retain the original, and the wrecker service shall retain a copy. (b) Whenever any vehicle is removed at the request of the vehicle owner and without participation by a police officer, the agent or employee of the wrecker service performing the removal shall complete and sign the inventory form supplied by the police department. The vehicle owner shall be given a reasonable opportunity to verify and sign the inventory form and shall sign the same. The owner or lawful custodian of the vehicle shall keep the original of the inventory form. The wrecker service shall keep a copy thereof and shall forward a copy to the police department at the time it supplies the information requested by the above. (c) Whenever the vehicle owner picks up his or her vehicle, the wrecker service shall provide him or her a copy of the inventory form. (Code 1986, § 26-90; Ord. No. 422, § 20, 5-4-1993) Sec. 58-148. - Schedules of maximum fees and charges. All wrecker services participating in the rotation system shall adhere to a schedule of maximum fees and charges which shall be established by ordinance or resolution of the board of commissioners, from time to time, and made available for public examination in the office of the city clerk. The services that a wrecker service on the rotation system may charge for are as follows: (1) Attaching to and towing or hauling a vehicle in condition to be moved without the use of dollies or special equipment. (2) Attaching to and towing or hauling a vehicle in condition to be removed that require the use of dollies or special equipment. 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 146/196 (3) Storage to be prorated per day, 24 hours. (4) Maximum shop opening fee after normal business hours (8:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m.). (Code 1986, § 26-91; Ord. No. 422, § 21, 5-4-1993) Sec. 58-149. - Suspension from rotation system. The chief may suspend the wrecker and/or the operators of any wrecker service from the rotation system upon any of the following. (1) Charging fees in excess of those approved by the city commissioners; (2) Failure of a wrecker to pass inspection; or (3) Any violation of the provisions of this article or other law. (Code 1986, § 26-92; Ord. No. 422, § 22, 5-4-1993) Sec. 58-150. - Violations. A conviction of violation of section 58-144, prohibiting solicitation at the scene of a wreck or vehicular disablement, or section 58-145, prohibiting a wrecker from coming to the scene unless called as provided herein, shall result in mandatory suspension of the wrecker service from the rotation system for a period of one year. (Code 1986, § 26-88; Ord. No. 422, § 23, 5-4-1993) Sec. 58-151. - Notification of suspension. Any wrecker service suspended by the chief shall be notified in writing of the suspension to take effect within ten days after notice, the reasons therefor in writing, the witnesses relied upon by the chief and that the wrecker service shall be granted a hearing upon written request filed with the city manager within five days. The city manager, upon hearing the matter, may affirm the decision of the chief or reinstate the wrecker service. (Code 1986, § 26-94; Ord. No. 422, § 24, 5-4-1993) Sec. 58-152. - Penalty. Any person who shall violate any of the provisions or sections of this article shall be punished upon conviction in the municipal court of the city according to the general penalties described in section 1-12. (Code 1986, § 26-95; Ord. No. 422, § 25, 5-4-1993) APPENDIX A - SUBDIVISIONS FOOTNOTE(S): (37) Editor's note— Printed herein are the subdivision regulations of the city, Ordinance No. 399, as adopted by the board of commissioners on June 4, 1991. Amendments are indicated by parenthetical history notes following amended provisions. The absence of a history note indicates that the provision remains unchanged from the original. Obvious misspellings and punctuation errors have been corrected without notation. The style used for headings and catchlines has been made uniform and consistent with those appearing in the Code. Additions made for clarity, such as consistent state statute citations and catchline modifications, are indicated by brackets. ARTICLE I. - SHORT TITLE, PURPOSE, AND JURISDICTION 1-1. Short title. This ordinance shall be known as the "Land Subdivision Ordinance of the City of Quitman, Georgia." 1-2. Purpose. This ordinance is enacted pursuant to the authority contained in the Constitution of the State of Georgia, as amended for the following purposes: a. To encourage economically sound and stable land development. b. To assure the provision of required streets, utilities, and other facilities and services to land developments. c. To assure the adequate provision of safe and convenient traffic access and circulation, both vehicular and pedestrian, in land developments. d. To assure the provision of needed public open spaces and building sites in land developments through the dedication or reservation of land for recreational, educational, and other public purposes. e. To assure that land is developed in conformity with the Comprehensive Plan for the City of Quitman. 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 147/196 1-3. Jurisdiction. This ordinance shall govern all subdivision of land within the corporate limits of the City of Quitman, Georgia. ARTICLE II. - DEFINITIONS 2-1. General. When used in this ordinance the following words and phrases shall have the meaning given in this section. Terms not herein defined shall have their customary dictionary definitions where not inconsistent with the context. The term "shall" is always mandatory. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the singular number include the plural, and those used in the plural number include the singular. Words used in the present tense include the future. 2-2. Abutting property. Any property that is immediately adjacent or contiguous to property proposed to be subdivided or that is located immediately across any road or public right-of-way. 2-3. Alleys. A public right-of-way, not intended to be a vehicular arterial or to provide the primary means of access to abutting property, but used for service access to the rear or side of properties otherwise abutting a public street. 2-4. Applicant. Any person who submits subdivision plans to the city for the purpose of obtaining approval thereof. 2-5. Architect. A qualified person registered and currently licensed to practice architecture in the State of Georgia. 2-6. Building line. A line beyond which no foundation wall or part of the structure of any building shall project, with the exception of roof overhang, walkways, and the subsurface projection of footings; provided, however, that such overhang does not exceed six feet and does not encroach upon the adjacent property or right-of-way. 2-7. City. The City of Quitman, Georgia. 2-8. City commission. The Board of Commissioners of the City of Quitman, Georgia. 2-9. City engineer. The official to whom the responsibilities normally associated with this title have been delegated. 2-10. Commissioner of health. The Brooks County Commissioner of Health, the Brooks County Health Department and/or the State of Georgia Department of Human Resources. The words "commissioner of health" are used in this ordinance to denote the fact that all matters pertaining to health regulations shall be directed to that official or his staff. 2-11. Comprehensive plan. The Comprehensive Plan for Quitman, Georgia, approved by the planning commission and/or the city board of commissioners, which may consist of the major thoroughfare plan, general land use plan, street and road classification plan, and other maps, data, and descriptive matter for the physical development of the city or any portions thereof, including any amendments, extensions, or additions thereto as adopted by the planning commission and/or the city commission. 2-12. Chairman. The Chairman of the Quitman City Commission. 2-13. Crosswalk. A right-of-way within a block dedicated to public use for pedestrian use only and so designed as to provide access to adjacent streets or lots. 2-14. Cul-de-sac. A street having only one end open for access to another street, the other end being terminated by a turnaround as specified in this ordinance. 2-15. Developer. Same as "Subdivider" (see section 2-31). 2-16. Development. The act or process of erecting buildings, structures, or of making improvements to property. 2-17. Easement. A grant by the owner of land for the use of such land by others, including public usage, for a specific purpose or purposes. 2-18. Hardship. A situation arising as the result of extraneous or unique circumstances which deprives the developer of the reasonable use of his land if the strict application of the various provisions of this ordinance are applied. (See "Variance.") 2-19. Improvement plan. The second stage of plat or subdivision plan review, as described in section 4-2 of this ordinance. 2-20. Land characteristics. A soils inventory of the area proposed for development. The inventory will include a soils map and identification of soil types. This information may be obtained by request of the property owner from the local soil conservation office. 2-21. Lot. A portion or parcel of land separated from other portions or parcels by description, as on a subdivision plat or record of survey map or as described by metes and bounds, and intended for transfer of ownership or for building development. For the purpose of this ordinance, the term does not include any portion of a dedicated right-of-way. 2-22. Lot, corner. A parcel of land at the junction of and fronting on two or more streets. 2-23. Lot width. The distance measured straight between the side lot lines, measured at the intersection of the building line, which shall be parallel to the street right-ofway line. 2-24. M.S.L. Mean sea level. 2-25. Planning commission. The Planning Commission of the City of Quitman. 2-26. Plat. A map, generally of a subdivision, showing the location, boundaries and ownership of individual properties. a. Plat, preliminary. The first stage of plat or subdivision plan review, as described in section 4-1 of this ordinance. b. Plat, final. The final stage of plat or subdivision plan review, as described in section 4-3 of this ordinance. 2-27. Public water and sewage systems. A system owned and operated by the City of Quitman. 2-28. Public right-of-way. A portion of land being used as a public street, road, thoroughfare, crosswalk, pipeway, drainage canal, and/or other similar uses and designated by means of right-of-way lines. 2-29. Staff development review committee. A committee of public employees with specific technical expertise who are officially responsible to the Quitman City Commission for various public management functions. Under this ordinance, the staff development review committee shall assist the planning commission and city 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 148/196 commission in the review of the numerous technical functions associated with the land subdivision process. This committee shall be chaired by the city manager and will include the zoning administrator, city utilities director, city utilities superintendents, and other city staff as determined by the city manager. 2-30. Street. A public right-of-way which provides vehicular access to abutting property. 2-30.1. Major Arterial Street: A street which is designated as such on the major thoroughfare plan and which is intended to provide swift and safe movement of traffic through the county. 2-30.2. Secondary Arterial Street: A street which is designated as such on the major thoroughfare plan and which is intended to provide easy and convenient traffic movement within the county. 2-30.3. Collector Street: A street which is designated as such on the major thoroughfare plan and which is intended to collect traffic from local streets and direct it safely to secondary or major streets. 2-30.4. Dead-End Street: A street having only one end open for access to another street, and other end being abruptly terminated with no turn-around. 2-30.5. Marginal-Access Street: A street generally parallel to and adjacent to an arterial street providing access to abutting properties and protection from through traffic. 2-30.6. Local Street: A street used for local circulation in areas providing access to abutting property. 2-31. Subdivider. Any person, firm, corporation, association or partnership or any agent thereof who undertakes or proposes to undertake the subdivision of land so as to constitute a subdivision as herein defined. 2-32. Subdivision. All divisions of a tract or parcel of land into two or more lots, parcels, building sites, or other divisions for the purpose, whether immediate or future, of sale, legacy, or building development, including all division of land involving a new street or a change of width or alignment in existing street(s), and including resubdivision and, where appropriate to the context, relating to the process of subdividing or to the land or area subdivided; provided, however, that the following are not included within this definition: a. The public acquisition of land. b. The sale of public land. 2-33. Tax assessor. The Brooks County Board of Tax Assessors. 2-34. Tract. A portion of land with definite and ascertainable limits or boundaries. (See definition of "Lot.") 2-35. Utility. Any community service available to the public by means of an overhead or underground distribution or collection system such as electricity, telephone, water, gas, and sewage disposal. 2-36. Variance. The relaxation of a dimensional requirement or design standard described within this ordinance as it applies to the development of a particular tract or parcel of land. None of the minimum improvements required by this ordinance shall be subject to variance. 2-37. Zoning Ordinance. The zoning ordinance enacted by the Board of Commissioners of the City of Quitman, as duly amended [appendix B]. ARTICLE III. - GENERAL 3-1. Platting authority. From and after the passage of this ordinance [June 4, 1991], the planning commission shall be the official platting authority, and no plat of a land subdivision shall be recorded in the office of the Clerk of the Superior Court of Brooks County unless it has the approval of the planning commission inscribed thereon. The filing or recording of a plat of a subdivision without the approval of the appropriate reviewing agencies and/or authorities as required by this ordinance is declared to be a misdemeanor. 3-2. Use of plat. The transfer or sale of land by reference to, exhibition of, or other use of a plat of a subdivision that has not been given final approval by the planning commission and recorded in the office of the Clerk of the Superior Court of Brooks County is prohibited, and the description by metes and bounds in such an instrument of transfer or other document shall not exempt the transaction from prescribed penalties. 3-3. Opening and improving public streets. The Board of Commissioners of the City of Quitman shall not accept, lay out, open, improve, grade, pave, or light any street, or lay any utility lines in any street, which has not attained the status of a public street prior to the effective date of this ordinance [June 4, 1991], unless such street corresponds to the street location shown on an approved subdivision plat or the major thoroughfare plan; provided that the city commission may accept, lay out, open, and improve any street not so platted if it first submits such proposed action to the planning commission for its review and comment. 3-4. Issuance of building permits. The City of Quitman will not issue building permits for any parcel of land, lot, tract, or building site subject to this ordinance that has not been designated and recorded as required by this ordinance. 3-5. Zoning Ordinance compliance. No subdivision shall be accepted for review which does not conform with the City of Quitman Zoning Ordinance. Proposed subdivisions must conform with the zoning district classification requirements applicable to the land for which it is proposed. 3-6. Official interpretation. The requirement(s) of this ordinance, as they may apply to a proposed land subdivision, shall be officially interpreted by the staff development review committee, which is officially represented by the city manager. In cases which the subdivider disagrees with the official interpretation of these regulations, the developer may appeal to the Quitman City Commission pursuant to the guidelines established in section 9-4. ARTICLE IV. - APPROVAL OF SUBDIVISIONS Pre-application procedure. The subdivider may visit with the Quitman Staff Development Review Committee and discuss the effect of the major thoroughfare plan and other official plans on the subdivision, as well as general design standards, zoning, and related matters. The subdivider may submit pre-application plans and data for review, advice, and assistance by the staff development review committee, city engineer, and the Brooks County Health Department. Professional assistance at this early stage may save time and effort during later steps. Pre-application plans and data should include: A. 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 149/196 Location sketch map, showing site in relation to the section of the city in which it is located. B. A simple sketch plan on a topographic survey showing general layout of lots, streets, major drainage ways, and other features in relation to existing conditions on the site and the surrounding street system. C. General subdivision information including data on proposed or existing covenants, wooded areas, available and proposed community facilities, and utilities, typical lot size, etc., and land characteristics as defined. Subdivisions shall be officially reviewed and approved in three stages as follows: 4-1. Preliminary plat. 4-1.1. Purpose: The purpose of the preliminary plat is to safeguard the subdivider from unnecessary loss of time and expense in preparation of a subdivision plat which does not conform with the specifications of the subdivision ordinance. The preliminary plat requires only approximate accuracy of scale and dimension. Public agencies having jurisdiction will review preliminary plats regarding matters within their jurisdiction. During the review process, the subdivider or his agent may be called upon for consultation. 4-1.2. Subdivisions Requiring No New Street, Water, or Sewer Facilities: All subdivisions which do not involve the platting, construction, or opening of new streets, water or sewer facilities may be accepted by the City of Quitman Zoning Administrator in the form of a final plat, provided that essential data required by the reviewing agencies to ensure compliance with the intent of this ordinance is submitted. 4-1.3. Filing: Any person desiring to subdivide land shall file with the City of Quitman Zoning Administrator five copies of the preliminary plat accompanied by a letter of application. The letter of application shall contain the name and address of the developer(s) and his agent(s), the zoning of the property to be subdivided, whether or not the subdivision will be developed in phases, plans for potential annexation, and plans for serving the proposed subdivision with sewer and water facilities. The plat shall be prepared in accordance with this ordinance and with applicable city specifications by a registered land surveyor, who is licensed under the laws of the State of Georgia. The preliminary plat shall be deemed filed with the planning commission when it is filed with the City of Quitman Zoning Administrator. At the time of filing, a certificate of filing shall be provided to the subdivider and shall include the time and date of filing. The zoning administrator shall have authority to reject the preliminary plat if it does not comply with this ordinance. If rejected, the zoning administrator shall provide the subdivider with a written statement specifying all the respects in which the plat fails to comply. Filing of the preliminary plat shall be accomplished at least 20 days prior to the regular planning commission meeting at which it is to be considered. The preliminary plat shall include: a. Title block and north arrow: The plat will show the name of the proposed subdivision, its location, the name, address and registration number of the surveyor preparing the plat and the date of the plat. A north arrow shall be included with a notation referencing the bearings to magnetic north, astronomical north or grid north. b. General layout: The plat shall show information as to the proposed street layout and widths, layout of lots with a notation as to the minimum size and width of lots and any proposed open space. Any lands to be dedicated will be clearly identified. Plat scale, total acreage of the site and total number of lots created shall also be indicated. Lot and block identification and building setback lines shall also be indicated. c. Topography: The plat shall show existing contour lines dashed and any proposed contour lines solid (unless waived by the city engineer), both set of lines to be at twofoot intervals, mean sea level (M.S.L.). Prominent drainage features such as lakes, depressions, streams, etc., which could affect the design of the subdivision shall be shown. Engineering data showing the high water elevation and how it was established shall be submitted with the plat. d. Existing features: The plat shall show the locations and names of existing and platted property lines, streets (and its right-of-way), railroads (and its right-of-way), public and private rights-of-way, sanitary sewer (and size), water mains (and size), bridges, culverts, storm drainage (and size), easements, parks and other public open spaces, land lot and land district lines, city limits lines and names of adjoining property owners or subdivisions. Groups of trees and swamp areas shall also be indicated. e. Location map: The plat shall include a small-scale map of sufficient clarity so that the location of the proposed subdivision can be readily determined. f. Water and sewer: A statement from the subdivider shall be submitted with the preliminary plat which will describe the method by which sanitary sewer and water facilities will be provided. If non-public sewer is proposed to serve a subdivision, then soils will be identified according to local Soil Conservation Service soil maps (see section 2-20) and soils percolation test results and contour map shall accompany the preliminary plat at the time of submission. The contour map shall show location and identification of each soil class and site of each percolation test. Percolation tests shall be made in accordance with county health department requirements. g. Future tract plan: In cases where a subdivision is to be developed in stages with additional plats being filed with the planning commission at a later date(s), the filing of the initial plat will be accompanied by a future tract plan, a reasonably accurate plat in sketch form of the entire tract which will show the future street system and topography for the entire tract. Once the required tract plan has been given approval by the planning commission, five copies of the approved future tract plan must be provided for distribution to the various reviewing agencies and the inspections office. 4-1.4. Completeness: If any of the above required information is omitted or misrepresented on the plat, the City of Quitman Zoning Administrator may refuse to review the plat and shall return the plat to the subdivider to be completed or revised. 4-1.5. Approval by Individual Agencies: No preliminary plat shall be approved by the planning commission unless it is approved by the city engineer and the commissioner of health. Said agencies shall, with or without modification, approve or disapprove the preliminary plat to the extent that each has jurisdiction. If the plat is rejected, the respective reviewing agency shall provide the planning commission with a written statement specifying all respects where the plat fails to comply. 4-1.6. Staff Development Review Committee: Upon receipt of the filing of the preliminary plat, the zoning administrator shall prepare those materials for presentation to the staff development review committee. The staff development review committee shall review the preliminary plan for technical compliance with the City of Quitman Land Subdivision Ordinance, Zoning Ordinance, Comprehensive plan, and other city ordinances that might impact on the proposed land subdivision. The staff development review committee shall recommend in writing approval, conditional approval, postponement or disapproval within 60 days of submission. 4-1.7. Coordination: It shall be the responsibility of the zoning administrator to ensure that the respective reviews of the city engineer and staff development review committee are brought together in a timely fashion for proper presentation to the planning commission. 4-1.8. Review by Planning: The planning commission shall review the preliminary plat, giving due consideration to the reviews of the staff development review committee, [and] the city engineer. The planning commission shall then recommend to the city commission for preliminary approval, conditional approval, postponement or disapproval within 30 days of submission. 4-1.9. Review by City Commission: Final review of the proposed preliminary subdivision plat shall be made by the city commission at its next regular meeting. The zoning administrator shall be responsible for coordination of information to be brought before the city commission, which at a minimum shall include the 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 150/196 recommendations of the staff development review committee, the city engineer, the commissioner of health, and the recommendation of the planning commission. The City Commission may grant preliminary approval, conditional approval, postponement or disapproval within 30 days of submission. 1. Preliminary approval by the city commission means that the developer is now authorized to proceed with the preparation of the required improvements plans, outlined in detail under section 4-2. No developer is now authorized to proceed with any construction or any other work in the proposed subdivision before obtaining preliminary approval of these improvement plans in writing. Lots shall not be sold nor shall building construction begin at this time. Preliminary approval grants the developer a minimum time of 18 months within which he shall submit his improvements plan and final plat for approval unless a time extension is granted by the city commission before the expiration of the eighteen[(18)]-month period. If, in the opinion of the staff development review committee, substantial changes have been made to the approved preliminary plat, the revised plat shall be resubmitted as a new preliminary plat. 2. Conditional approval by the city commission means the developer may proceed after written notice from the zoning administrator, as outlined under "preliminary approval," but only after he has submitted at least five copies of the corrected preliminary plan to the zoning administrator, noting thereon the condition or changes required by the approval of the city commission. 3. Postponement by the city commission means action is delayed for specific reasons which shall be noted and transmitted in writing to the developer by the zoning administrator. Postponed preliminary plans may be reconsidered by the city commission without resubmittal to the staff development review committee, the city engineer, the commissioner of health and the planning commission. 4. Disapproval by the city commission means denial of the application for the subdivision because the developer's plans are not in compliance with this ordinance. For further consideration, the developer must rework and resubmit his plans as though they were a completely new preliminary plan. 4-2. Improvement plans. 4-2.1. General Requirements: Subdivision plans receive their second official consideration as "improvement plans." These plans shall be approved by the city engineer, who shall certify that the improvement plans are in conformance with this ordinance, official city specifications, and with the requirements of the approved preliminary plan. No developer shall proceed with any construction work in the proposed subdivision before obtaining this approval. 4-2.2. Professional Engineer Required: The developer shall have a professional engineer, registered in the State of Georgia, prepare the improvement plans in conformance with the format, design and improvement standards required by this ordinance and such plans shall reflect his registration. 4-2.3. Filing: To secure formal review of his improvement plans, the developer shall file with the zoning administrator three certified (signed and sealed by the developer's professional engineer) white background prints of the improvement plans. The zoning administrator will then distribute the improvements plan to the city engineer and the staff development review committee, and the city engineer shall jointly review the proposed improvement plans and shall approve or deny the proposed improvement plans. The zoning administrator shall notify the city commission of the committees' action in writing. a. Approval means the developer is now authorized to proceed with the physical improvements in the subdivision, after securing any required construction permits, and may proceed with the preparation of the final subdivision plat. b. Conditional approval means the developer may proceed as outlined in the preceding paragraph [a.], but only after he submits three certified copies of the corrected improvement plans to the city engineer for his review and approval. c. Denial means disapproval of the improvement plans. For further consideration, the developer must rework his plans to conform to the requirements of this ordinance, and then submit the reworked plans to the zoning administrator as though they were a completely new set of plans. 4-2.4.
