Plans and Data Required for Improvement Plan Submission: The plans for the required public improvements shall be prepared for the approval by the staff development review committee and city engineer prior to the construction and only after approval of the preliminary plan. Such improvement plans shall show the proposed locations, sizes, types, grades and general design features of each facility, and shall be based on reliable field data. Construction plan approvals are good for 24 months. If the subdivision is sold prior to completion and final platting, a mandatory review by the staff development review committee and city engineer is required. Failure to comply may result in revocation of construction permit after notice and hearing before the staff development review committee and city engineer. The developer shall receive a minimum of five days' written notice of said hearing. The improvement construction drawing shall be submitted on white background prints. The sheet size shall be 24 inches by thirty-six (36) inches unless another size is approved by the city engineer. The drawing shall include the following information: a. Construction plans. The developer shall provide the plan and profile of each proposed street (indicating the existing ground surface elevation and proposed street grade surface elevation including extensions for a distance of 100 feet to three hundred (300) feet beyond the tract boundary) as required by the city engineer. Design shall be in accordance with good engineering practices. b. Street-typical sections. A typical section of each proposed street shall be submitted, showing the width of pavement and the right-of-way. c. Water supply and stormwater drainage. The plan and profile of proposed distribution systems, and storm drainage sewers or other drainage ways, with grade and sizes indicated. Stormwater drainage shall be consistent with city ordinances and other applicable governmental agencies. Water and sewer systems shall be approved by the staff development review committee and all relevant state agencies. The plat shall not be recorded until the developer submits to the zoning administrator all final permits required for the construction of all improvements from other state, local or federal agencies. d. Utility service agreement. A developer's agreement for city utilities service shall be required before final development approval is granted. e. Other public improvements. A plan shall be prepared for parks, recreation or other public use areas and improvements if included in the approved preliminary plan. f. As-built plans. The designing engineer shall submit to the zoning administrator three sets of white background prints of certified as-built plans. 4-3. Final plat. 4-3.1. Conformance: The final plat shall conform with the approved preliminary [plat]. If desired by the subdivider, he may submit only that portion of the preliminary plat he proposes to record and develop at that time; provided, that such portion conforms with all requirements of this ordinance. The record plat is to be prepared and sealed by a registered land surveyor, licensed in the State of Georgia. 4-3.2. Filing: Filing the final plat with the zoning administrator shall include the following: a. A letter of application shall contain: 1) The name and address of the person (3) [sic] developing the subdivision and his agent(s); 2) Zoning of the property to be subdivided; 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 151/196 3) Whether or not the subdivision will be developed in phases; 4) Plans for serving the proposed subdivision with sewer and water facilities. b. A complete list of deviations, if any, from the approved preliminary plat. c. A certified copy of all private covenants or deed restrictions, if any, pertaining to land within the subdivision. d. A copy of the agreement for providing the necessary water and sewer facilities. e. A fee to cover the cost of investigation and review of the preliminary plan, construction plans, the final plat, and final recording costs will be charged at time of application. The fees are as set by the Quitman Board of Commissioners. f. The original reproducible on plastic or linen and five blueline prints of the final plat, which will include the following: 1) Sheet design: The final plat shall conform to the items listed under the preliminary plat (4-1.3a, 4-1.3b, 4-1.3d, 4-1.3e, 4-1.3g) and the requirements thereof, as set forth in this ordinance and shall be drawn in black India ink on one or more sheets of linen tracing cloth or mylar film measuring 18 inches by 24 inches. When two or more sheets are used, a key map shall be shown on each sheet. There shall be a two-inch margin on the left end of the plat and a one-half inch margin on the remaining three sides. A revision to a recorded plat shall be drawn in black India ink on the same type cloth or film as mentioned above. The final plat shall be drawn on the scale (stated and graphical) of one inch in 100 feet. If necessary, more than one sheet may be used as long as a key may is provided to relate each sheet to the entire platted area. 2) Surveyor certificate: The following certificate shall be entered on the face of the plat as shown in figure 1 [at the end of this appendix]. Placement of this certificate may vary as necessary: I certify that all measurements are correct and were prepared from an actual survey of the property made under my supervision; the field data upon which this plat is based has a closure precision of one foot in ____________ feet and an angular error of ____________ per angle point, and was adjusted using ____________/____________/____________ rule; the plat has been calculated for closure and is found to be accurate within one foot in ____________ feet; monument and pin locations are correctly shown by the symbols ____________ and the pins are ____________ (type of metallic material and length). Signed ____________ (Seal) (Date) ..... Surveyor, Georgia Registration No. ..... 3) Owner certificate: The following certificate shall be entered on the face of the plat as shown in figure 1 [at the end of this appendix]. Placement of this certificate may vary as necessary: We, the undersigned owner(s) and/or mortgagee(s) of the ____________ Subdivision, hereby offer to dedicate and/or reserve for public use the rights-of-way, easements and other ground as shown on this plat. Owner Date Mortgagee Date ____________/____________/____________ ____________/____________/____________ ____________/____________/____________ ____________/____________ 4) Approvals: The following spaces shall be provided (as shown in figure 1) in the form listed below for approval by all agencies having jurisdiction. Placement on plat may vary: Approved by the Commissioner of Health, Brooks County, Georgia Date ..... Signed ..... Health Department Representative Approved by City Engineer, Quitman, Georgia Date ..... Signed ..... City Engineer Approved by the Planning Commission Date ..... Signed ..... Chairman Approved by the Quitman City Commission Date ..... Signed ..... Chairman 5) Surveying data: The final plat shall contain the location, bearing and length of every street line, lot line and boundary line whether curved or straight. A note will be made on the plat as to whether curved dimensions are arch [arc] or chord distances. Easement lines (and width), land lot and land district lines will be shown. All dimensions shall be shown in feet and decimals to the nearest one one-hundredth of a foot, and all angles shall be shown to the nearest second. The error of closure shall not exceed one in ten thousand (10,000), or as defined by the technical standards required by Georgia Code 84-21 of the Law Governing the Practice of Professional Engineering and Surveying (1980), as amended. 6) Monuments: The final plat shall show the accurate location, material and description of all monuments. A permanent master bench mark shall be established (subject to the approval of the city engineer) within or adjacent to the site by transfer of levels, not less than third order accuracy, from the nearest approved bench mark of known mean sea level (M.S.L.) elevation showing its location on the final plat and recording its elevation on the final plat to the nearest one one-hundredth of a foot. 7) Easements: In addition to the requirements for the preliminary plat as set forth in section 4-3.d of this ordinance, the final plat will show the location and width of all temporary construction easements (as required by standard engineering practice), public utility easements and drainage easements where required. 4-3.3. Filing certificate: The final plat shall be deemed filed with the planning commission when it is filed with the zoning administrator. At the time of filing, a certificate of filing shall be furnished the applicant which will include the time and date of filing. The final plat shall be prepared in accordance with this ordinance and applicable city requirements by a registered land surveyor who is licensed under the laws of the State of Georgia. The zoning administrator shall have authority to reject the final plat if he finds that it does not conform with the approved preliminary plat or this ordinance. If the plat is rejected, the zoning administrator shall provide the subdivider with a 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 152/196 written statement specifying all the respects in which it does not conform. Filing the final plat shall be accomplished at least 20 days prior to the regular planning commission meeting at which it is to be considered. 4-3.4. Approval by Individual Agencies: No final plat shall be approved unless the planning commission first obtains approval of the commissioner of health, and the city engineer. Said agencies shall approve, with or without modification, or disapprove the final plat to the extent to which each has jurisdiction. Within ten days of time of submittal, the developer will be notified of approval or disapproval. If disapproved, reasons for denial shall be noted. 4-3.5. Staff Development Review Committee: Upon receipt of the filing of the final plat, the zoning administrator shall prepare those materials for presentation to the staff development review committee. The staff development review committee shall review the final plan for technical compliance with the City of Quitman Land Subdivision Ordinance, Zoning Ordinance, Comprehensive Plan, and other city ordinances that might impact on the proposed land subdivision. The staff development review committee shall recommend in writing approval, conditional approval, postponement or disapproval. 4-3.6. Coordination: It shall be the responsibility of the zoning administrator to ensure that the respective reviews of the city engineer, commissioner of health and staff development review committee are brought together in a timely fashion for proper presentation to the planning commission. 4-3.7. Review by Planning Commission: The planning commission shall review the final plat, giving due consideration to the reviews of the staff development review committee, the city engineer and the commissioner of health. The planning commission shall then recommend to the city commission for final approval, conditional approval, postponement or disapproval. 4-3.8. Review by City Commission: Final review of the proposed final subdivision plat shall be made by the city commission at its next regular meeting. The zoning administrator shall be responsible for coordination of information to be brought before the city commission, which at a minimum, shall include the recommendations of the staff development review committee, the city engineer, the commissioner of health, and the recommendation of the planning commission. The city commission may grant final approval, conditional approval, postponement or disapproval. 4-3.9. Recording a Plat: Upon satisfactory compliance with this ordinance, and after approval by the city commission, the final plat will be forwarded to the Quitman City Manager to retain until such time that all required minimum improvements have been completed, accepted by the city, and the required guarantee has been posted. At such time the Quitman City Manager shall release said final plat for recording. The plat shall be returned to the zoning administrator, who shall record the plat in a timely manner. 4-3.10. Revision to a Recorded Plat: Proposed revisions to a recorded plat which do not affect platted rights-of-way may be submitted for administrative approval in accord with the provisions of section 4-2.13. In addition, a revision to a recorded plat shall show the name, phase (if any), date of the recorded subdivision plat being revised, and the exact citation with regard to the county land records and the book and page number wherein said plat is recorded. Revisions to a recorded plat which involve platted rights-of-way or other major changes shall be submitted as a preliminary plat. 4-3.11. Distribution: The zoning administrator shall make the following distribution of prints and reproducibles: City Records (Recording copies) Original linen or plastic reproducible and one print City Engineer One print and one reproducible Building Inspector One print City Fire Department One print County Tax Assessor One print County Health Department One print Sheriff's Department One print City/County Traffic Eng. One print Board of Education One print Planning Commission One reproducible and two prints 4-3.12. Administrative Approval of Small Subdivisions and Resubdivisions: Where a proposed subdivision presents no engineering problems, no required improvements, and few, if any, planning problems, the city manager may waive the requirements of filing a preliminary plat and may recommend approval of the final plat to the board of commissioners. In addition, where located on an existing road or street, the combination or recombination of previously platted lots, where the total number of lots does not increase, and the resultant lots are equal to the current standards of the city as determined by the staff development review committee, shall also be subject to administrative approval. Such plats shall conform fully to the requirements of this ordinance. It shall be the responsibility of the zoning administrator to coordinate said administrative review responsibilities. ARTICLE V. - MINIMUM DESIGN STANDARDS 5-1. Blocks. 5-1.1. Nonresidential: Blocks for other than residential use shall be of such length and width as may be suitable for their prospective use, including adequate provision for off-street parking and maneuvering space. 5-1.2. Residential: The length of residential blocks shall not exceed twelve hundred (1,200) feet nor be less than four hundred (400) feet. Blocks of more than twelve hundred (1,200) feet will be permitted if natural or manmade barriers such as streams and railroads require blocks of greater size. The depth of residential blocks shall be sufficient to allow two tiers of lots, unless prohibited by natural or manmade barriers, or unless one tier backs onto a line of another person's property, except as provided for in section 5-3.4. The foregoing shall not prevent the inclusion of blocks of greater width, including super blocks. Super blocks may contain public or joint use areas such as parks and playgrounds and shall be covered by adequate maintenance agreements if not dedicated and accepted for public maintenance. 5-1.3. Crosswalks: Rights-of-way for pedestrian crosswalks shall be provided when in the opinion of the planning commission crosswalks are necessary for direct pedestrian access to schools, shopping centers, and parks. A crosswalk right-of-way shall not be less than 20 feet wide. 5-2. Easements. 5-2.1. Utility: Utility easements for overhead services shall be located within the platted street right-of-way and shall be a minimum width of 20 feet. Where possible (as determined by the city engineer), water lines shall be located on the west and south sides of streets, and sewer and gas lines shall be on the east and north sides. Wherever public utility easements are planned adjacent to the subdivision tract boundary or phase, they shall be platted within said subdivision or phase thereof. Water and sewer lines outside of street rights-of-way shall follow side and rear property lines where possible and shall have a minimum easement width of 20 feet except that a greater width shall be provided where it is determined by the city engineer that a greater width is necessary for maintenance or construction. 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 153/196 5-2.2. Drainage: Drainage easements shall be provided as required by the city engineer after review of the preliminary improvement plans and preliminary plat of the subject subdivision. 5-3. Lots. 5-3.1. Minimum Lot Elevation: The lot area contained within and contiguous to the building walls and for a minimum distance of ten feet measured from all sides of said building shall have a minimum elevation of two feet above the 100-year flood stage of streams or canals in the particular area being developed based on acceptable engineering procedure and approved by the city engineer. Said minimum elevation shall be subject to approval by the commissioner of health. No change of elevation necessary to meet this requirement will be permitted if the change constitutes filling within a designated flood hazard zone. Flood-prone areas: All preliminary and final plats shall clearly delineate identified floodplain areas in conformance with the City of Quitman Floodplain Management Ordinance [chapter 10, Code of Ordinances]. 5-3.2. Lot Width and Lot Area Requirements: Lots hereafter established within a subdivision shall conform to the lot area and lot width requirements set forth in the zoning ordinance for the City of Quitman [appendix B] or in other sections of this ordinance. 5-3.3. Corner Lots: Corner lots shall be of such size and dimensions that will permit the location of buildings so as to conform with the building setback lines as prescribed in the zoning ordinance [appendix B]. Corner property lines at street intersections shall have a minimum of twenty-five-foot radii. 5-3.4. Double-and Reverse-Frontage: Lots having street frontage both to the front and rear shall be prohibited (unless allowed by variance) except to provide for separation of residential development from railroad right-of-way or arterial or collector streets rights-of-way. Where the aforementioned abuts or runs through any portion of the subdivision, the subdivision plan shall provide for lots backing on said railroad or right-of-way, or major or collector street right-of-way. All lots shall have a minimum depth adequate to provide for the rear yard setback, required by the respective zoning district, plus an additional 30 feet, ten feet of which shall be a planted, nonencroachable buffer strip separating the lots from the right-of-way. The buffer zone shall be landscaped with hedges or closely planted small trees to provide a visual screen and shall be planted at the time of development. Said planted, nonencroachable buffer strip shall be clearly indicated on the final plat and proper covenants shall be prepared to insure this restriction. 5-4. Building lines. All building setback lines shall be as specified in the zoning ordinance for the City of Quitman [appendix B]. 5-5. Buffer zones. 5-5.1. Commercial Use Buffer Zones: When a portion of the subdivision is to be devoted to commercial purposes and when the commercial area adjoins residential lots, or when a portion of a proposed subdivision adjoins an area zoned for commercial or industrial use, a buffer zone not less than 20 feet in width shall be provided. Said buffer strip shall be landscaped with hedges or closely planted small trees so as to provide visual screening. No building or portion thereof may be constructed in said buffer zone, and protective covenants shall be provided to ensure this restriction. Said buffer zone shall be labeled as such on the subdivision plat and shall be planted at the time of development. 5-6. Streets. The street and road system of any subdivision shall give due consideration to the Major Thoroughfare Plan. 5-6.1. Access: Every lot of every subdivision shall abut a public street a minimum of 30 feet, which is or shall be maintained by the appropriate governing body. Where the subdivision does not immediately adjoin a public street, the subdivider shall provide a public street from the subdivision to a public street. 5-6.2. Alignment and Continuation: Streets within the subdivision shall be so arranged as to provide for the alignment and continuation of or projection of existing public streets. 5-6.3. Cul-de-Sacs: Permanent cul-de-sacs shall not be longer than five hundred (500) feet from the nearest street right-of-way line with which it intersects to the center of its diameter. Where the area served by the cul-de-sac has two or less dwelling units per acre, the maximum length may be increased to one thousand (1,000) feet. Cul-desacs shall terminate in a circular turnaround having a right-of-way of not less than 100 feet. Paving within the turnaround shall have an outside diameter of not less than 80 feet. 5-6.4. Dead-End Streets: Permanent dead-end streets and dead-end alleys shall be prohibited. 5-6.5. Half Streets: Permanent half streets and half alleys shall be prohibited. Half streets and half alleys are streets and alleys with substandard rights-of-way. 5-6.6. Intersections: The center line of no more than two streets shall intersect at any one point. No street shall intersect another street at less than 80 degrees and shall as nearly as possible intersect at 90 degrees. 5-6.7. Right-of-Way Radius: The right-of-way radius at street intersections shall be no less than twenty-five (25) feet except on major arterial streets where Georgia Department of Transportation standards shall prevail. 5-6.8. Curved Streets: The centerline radius shall not be less than three hundred fifty (350) feet for arterial streets, and one hundred twenty (120) feet for collector and local streets. Centerline tangents between reverse curves shall be not less than two hundred (200) feet for arterial streets and 100 feet for collector streets and local streets. 5-6.9. Right-of-Way Extension: Where the proposed subdivision abuts undeveloped properties, it is essential that appropriate extensions of streets be provided to facilitate future growth and development. Such street rights-of-way to facilitate future development shall be extended by dedication and improved to the boundary of the proposed subdivision. 5-6.10. Street Jogs: Street jogs at intersections shall be not less than one hundred fifty (150) feet between centerline offsets. This provision shall not negate the design intent of section 5-6.2. 5-6.11. Street Names: The subdivider shall indicate on the subdivision plat the proposed name or number of all streets within the subdivision. Streets and roads that are obviously in alignment with and are extensions of existing previously named or numbered streets shall bear that name. The names of all new streets within the subdivision shall be subject to the review and approval of the board of commissioners. 5-6.12. Alleys: Alleys shall not be allowed in residential subdivisions. 5-6.13. Street Right-of-Way and Pavement Width: Street rights-of-way shall be measured between lot lines and shall be prescribed in this section. The pavement width shall be as prescribed below. Street Classification (In feet) Minimum Right-of-Way Minimum Pavement Width (In feet) Arterial 100 40 (Divided) 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 154/196 Collector 80 24 Local Street 60* 24 Easements ** ** When new development is proposed in proximity to existing curb and gutter sections, said development may be developed with 24-foot minimum pavement width with curb and gutter and proper storm drainage within a 50-foot right-of-way. When proposed without curb and gutter, a minimum 24-foot minimum pavement width with properly designed swale ditch drainage may be developed within a 60-foot right-of-way. Subdivisions planned for annexation shall be developed to current city standards and shall be subject to review of the city engineer. As appropriate for the proposed development, with approval required by the city engineering department. 5-6.14. Additional Rights-of-Way: If the subdivision boundary line lies adjacent to the right-of-way line of an existing street of less than minimum right-of-way width, a minimum of one-half the required extra right-of-way shall be dedicated. 5-6.15. Provisions for Public Use: In subdividing land, due consideration shall be given to suitable sites for schools, parks, playgrounds, and other common areas for public use. Such land should be located in accordance with the comprehensive plan. The acquisition of such land shall rest with the appropriate public authority. ARTICLE VI. - MINIMUM IMPROVEMENTS 6-1. General. The subdivider shall provide all public improvements as required by this ordinance and by applicable city specifications and requirements. 6-1.1. The design of all minimum improvements shall be under the direction of an engineer registered in the State of Georgia, and all plans shall bear his seal. 6-1.2. A certificate of approval from the commissioner of health shall accompany all water and sewer plans. 6-2. Curbs and gutter. The subdivider may install curb and gutter in accordance with the requirements of section 5-6.13. 6-3. Monuments/pins. The subdivider shall provide, through the licensed surveyor, the setting of all reinforced concrete monuments and pins. The reinforced concrete monuments shall be four inches in diameter or square, 30 inches long with a flat top. The top of each monument shall be set flush with the ground. Said monuments shall be set within each block of the subdivision and shall be located along the longest interior straightaway; a minimum of four per block shall be installed as shown on the approved plat. Pins, a minimum of 15 inches long and one-half inch in diameter (metallic material type to be listed on plat) shall be placed along the exterior boundary and interior lot intersection except where concrete monuments are to be located, on each street corner, points of curvature in each street at all points where the street lines intersect the exterior boundary of the subdivision, and where such corners lie within a stream meander (in which case reference pins shall be placed on the bank of the stream). The pin shall be set a minimum of two inches under the ground. The top of the concrete monument shall contain a metal plate or metal rod, which shall be scored in such a manner that will properly and accurately identify the location. 6-4. Water supply and sanitary sewerage. 6-4.1. Every lot of a proposed subdivision shall be supplied with adequate water and sanitary facilities, which shall require the approval of the commissioner of health. Where existing water and sewer mains are in the street, but no services to the proposed lots, the subdivider shall have the services installed. Where public water and sanitary sewerage is available through extensions, the subdivider shall assure that every lot of the subdivision shall be provided with said public facilities in accordance with applicable city specifications. 6-4.2. Minimum Improvements: Standard fire hydrants of a type specified by the City of Quitman in the construction specifications shall be installed as a part of the water distribution system within a subdivision (existing or new) for single-family dwellings. A fire hydrant shall be located at each intersection and additional hydrant or hydrants installed where the distance between intersections exceeds five hundred (500) feet. In no case shall hydrants be spaced greater than five hundred (500) feet and shall be sized to have flow of seven hundred fifty (750) g.p.m. (gallons per minute) when adequate flow and pressure is available to the point of connection for the subdivision to the city system. In multifamily and residential professional districts, fire hydrants shall be installed so that the distance from fire hydrants to the driveway entrance nearest the front of the building shall not exceed two hundred fifty (250), feet, with a total distance not to exceed five hundred (500) feet, with a total distance not to exceed five hundred (500) feet to the extreme back of the building by way of driveways. [As] an option, provided automatic sprinklers are installed according to N.F.P.A. regulations, the spacing of hydrants may be increased to three hundred fifty (350) feet to the driveway entrance nearest the front of the building, provided the total distance does not exceed seven hundred (700) feet to the extreme back of the building by way of driveways. In light industrial, heavy industrial, central business and general business districts and any facility which handles or uses flammable or hazardous materials, hydrants shall be installed within three hundred (300) feet to the midpoint of the structure and equally spaced thereafter, not to exceed three hundred (300) feet between hydrants and the extreme rear of the building. The distance shall be measured along the line traveled by the fire truck. In the following zoning districts, hydrants shall be sized to have a flow capacity of not less than one thousand (1,000) g.p.m. (gallons per minute) when adequate flow and pressure is available to the point of connection for the subdivision to the city system: L-I, HI, GB and CBD. As an option, provided automatic sprinklers are installed according to N.F.P.A. requirements, the spacing of hydrants may be increased from three hundred (300) feet to five hundred (500) feet. Distance between fire hydrants shall be as specified unless fire department operations would otherwise allow increased spacing. Actual location of fire hydrants shall be the responsibility of the fire chief or his representative. 6-4.3. The entire cost of extending water and sewer lines and their associated services within the subdivision shall be borne by the developer. 6-5. Sidewalks. (Reserved) 6-6. Street paving. The subdivider shall provide paved streets in accordance with this ordinance and applicable city specifications. 6-7. Stormwater drainage. The subdivider shall provide adequate stormwater drainage in accordance with these regulations and applicable city specifications. Where drainage conditions dictate, open ditches shall be paved. The subdivider shall also provide for adequate drainage of springs or other groundwater drainage. 6-8. Utilities. The installation of utilities shall be as follows: 6-8.1. Communication Distribution Systems: All communication distribution systems installed solely for the purpose of extending communications service within a development and within the property limits of such development shall be placed as directed by the staff development review committee. 6-8.2. Electric Power Distribution Systems: All electric distribution systems installed solely for the purpose of extending electric service to a development and within the property limits of such development shall be placed as directed by the staff development review committee. 6-8.3. Easements: Developers shall allocate necessary easements with future maintenance access. 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 155/196 6-8.4. Location of Underground Installations: The plans submitted to the city engineer will set forth the anticipated location of all underground installations. Location approval or acknowledgement by the owners of the underground installations shall be submitted. 6-9. Streetlighting. The general standard of residential streetlighting for Quitman, Georgia, is as follows: 6-9.1. Overhead Electrical Distribution: Residential lighting will be provided at intersections, dead-end streets or courts with a maximum spacing not to exceed five hundred (500) feet for straight streets, provided spacing shall be reduced as conditions indicate for curved streets or irregular contours so as to provide adequate lighting. Luminaries are to be twenty-eight-foot mounted on existing utility distribution poles and of an approved type mercury unit of approximately seven thousand (7,000) lumen. 6-9.2. Underground Electrical Distribution: Residential lighting will be provided at intersections, dead ends, or courts with a maximum spacing of four hundred (400) feet for straight streets, provided spacing shall be reduced as conditions indicate for curved streets or irregular contours so as to provide adequate lighting. Luminaries shall be top mounted on sixteen-foot (approximate) ornamental metal poles of an approved type mercury unit of approximately seven thousand (7,000) lumen. 6-9.3. Cost of Installation: In order to partially defray the cost of installation of streetlighting, the developer shall be required to pay a lump sum fee to the City of Quitman for each streetlight required under the provisions of this ordinance. The fees for streetlights will be as outlined on the current City of Quitman fee schedule. Before the minimum improvements are accepted by the city, a check payable to the City of Quitman must be furnished for the total cost of the streetlights as determined above and as described in the streetlight layout plan. 6-9.4. Actions Prior to Construction: In order that the expense outlined herein may be ascertained and understood prior to commencement of construction, the developer or his engineer will confer with the city engineer and mark on the plans the approximate location for each fixture. 6-9.5. Location of Underground Installations: The plans submitted to the city engineer will set forth the exact location of all underground installations. 6-10. Buffer strips. The subdivider shall provide adequate buffer strips which consist of plantings and/or visual blinds as detailed in this ordinance. 6-11. Street signs. The developer shall pay for street signs necessitated by his subdivision as outlined in the current City of Quitman fee schedule. These fees shall be paid to the City of Quitman prior to the city manager's release of the plat for recording. Signs shall be installed by the city. 6-12. Installation of improvements. No grading, paving, or construction of any required improvements shall be permitted until the final plat and improvements plan of the subdivision has been approved by the city commission. ARTICLE VII. - ACCEPTANCE AND GUARANTEE OF COMPLETED MINIMUM IMPROVEMENTS 7-1. Completion of improvements. Before the plat is signed by the Chairman of the Quitman City Commission, all developers shall be required to complete, in accordance with this ordinance and to the satisfaction of the Quitman City Manager, all minimum improvements as required by section [article] VI of this ordinance, specified on the final plat, and as approved by the planning commission, and to dedicate same to the City of Quitman. 7-1.1. In lieu of completion of the minimum improvements as required under this ordinance prior to recording of the final plat, the developer may post an irrevocable letter of credit or a performance bond. This instrument shall be made payable upon demand to the Quitman Board of Commissioners to ensure the completion of the required minimum improvements and shall be in an amount of not less than one hundred ten (110) percent of the estimated cost of all required minimum improvements. Cost estimates shall be prepared by the subdivider's professional engineer, and shall be subject to the review and approval of the city manager. 7-1.2. Bonds and/or cash posted pursuant to this alternative shall be released after formal acceptance of improvements by the city commission. 7-2. Acceptance. Upon written notification of completion of minimum improvements, the city manager within 30 days after such notice accept or reject, in writing, the completed improvements stating the deficiencies, if any. 7-2.1. The required minimum improvements shall not be accepted unless they conform to this ordinance and officially adopted city specifications. 7-3. Guarantee. The subdivider shall guarantee to the city, for a period of one year, after completion and acceptance of the improvement, all material and workmanship going into such improvement. The subdivider shall post bond with the city, conditioned upon the faithful performance of such guaranty. The guaranty shall be secured in the form of a bond, certified check or an irrevocable letter of credit, payable upon demand to the Quitman Board of Commissioners. Such guaranty and bond shall be posted prior to approval by the city of the subdivision plat. This guaranty shall be in the amount of 20 percent of the total improvements cost. 7-4. Recording of plat. Upon acceptance of all improvements installed by the developer and posting of the required guarantee, the office of the Quitman [City] Manager shall release the final plat for recording. Said plat shall be returned to the zoning administrator, who shall record said plat in a timely manner and distribute appropriate copies thereof in accordance with the directives of section 4-3.12. 7-5. Duration and release of guarantee. Bonds and/or cash posted pursuant to section 7-3 of this ordinance shall be released or returned at such time as the improvements guaranteed thereby have received final inspection after the guaranty period. ARTICLE VIII. - VIOLATIONS AND PENALTIES 8-1. Violations. 8-1.1. It shall be unlawful to convey or improve property by the construction of buildings on lots of any land subdivision which has not been approved and recorded as provided in this ordinance, except those parcels recorded prior to the effective date of this ordinance [June 4, 1991]. 8-1.2. It shall be unlawful to record a subdivision plat or once recorded, to make any changes thereon whatsoever which have not been approved by the city commission, planning commission, city engineer, and the commissioner of health in accordance with the provisions of this ordinance. 8-1.3. Each Day's Violation a Separate Offense. After due notice has been given, each and every day's violation of any provision of this ordinance shall constitute a separate offense. 8-2. Violation and penalty. Any person who violates any provision of this subdivision ordinance shall, upon conviction in recorder's court, be penalized by the imposition of a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) per day and/or imprisonment in the city jail for a period not greater than 60 days. ARTICLE IX. - LEGAL STATUS 9-1. Effect of invalidity of part of resolution [ordinance]. Should any section or provision of this ordinance be decided by the courts to be invalid, such decision shall not affect the validity of this ordinance as a whole or any other part thereof. 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 156/196 9-2. Conflict with other laws. All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict herewith are hereby repealed. 9-3. Amendment. The city commission shall have the authority to amend this ordinance after a public hearing thereon. Notice of the time and place of such public hearing shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the City of Quitman at least 15 days prior to such meetings. 9-4. Variances. In cases of undue hardship under this ordinance, any property owner may petition the planning commission for a variance, and where the planning commission concurs, it will prepare and send to the city commissioners a recommendation for a variance when considered necessary and equitable. In case the planning commission fails to concur, the property owner may appeal to the city commissioners for relief. All variance requests will require a public hearing in the same manner as an amendment. None of the items listed in article VII, "Minimum Improvements," of this ordinance shall be subject to variance. 9-5. Effective date. This ordinance shall take effect and be in force from and after the date of adoption [June 4, 1991]. APPENDIX B - ZONING ZONING ORDINANCE FOR QUITMAN, GEORGIA AN ORDINANCE REGULATING WITHIN THE CITY OF QUITMAN, THE LOCATION; HEIGHT; BULK; NUMBER OF STORIES AND SIZE OF BUILDINGS AND OTHER STRUCTURES; THE SIZES OF YARDS, COURTS, AND OTHER OPEN SPACES; THE DENSITY AND DISTRIBUTION OF POPULATION; AND THE USES OF BUILDINGS, STRUCTURES, AND LAND FOR TRADE, INDUSTRY, RESIDENCE, RECREATION, AGRICULTURE, FORESTRY, CONSERVATION, SANITATION, PROTECTION AGAINST FLOODS, PUBLIC ACTIVITIES, AND OTHER PURPOSES; CREATING DISTRICTS FOR SAID PURPOSES AND ESTABLISHING THE BOUNDARIES THEREOF; DEFINING CERTAIN TERMS USED HEREIN; PROVIDING FOR THE METHOD OF ADMINISTRATION AND AMENDMENT; DEFINING THE POWERS AND DUTIES OF THE BOARD OF APPEALS; PROVIDING PENALTIES FOR VIOLATIONS; REPEALING CONFLICTING ORDINANCES; AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES. ARTICLE I. - ENACTMENT CLAUSE In pursuance of authority conferred by law, the city government of Quitman, Georgia, does ordain and enact into the law the following articles and sections. ARTICLE II. - PURPOSE The purpose of these regulations is to promote the health, safety, morals, convenience, order, prosperity, or the general welfare for the City of Quitman, Georgia; lessen congestion in the streets; secure safety from fire, panic, and other dangers; provide adequate light and air; prevent the overcrowding of land; avoid undue concentration of population; facilitate the adequate provision of transportation, water, sewage, schools, parks and other public requirements; conserve the value of buildings and encourage the most appropriate use of land and buildings throughout the city. ARTICLE III. - SHORT TITLE This ordinance shall be known and be cited as "The Zoning Ordinance of the City of Quitman, Georgia." ARTICLE IV. - DEFINITIONS For the purpose of this ordinance, certain terms and words are hereby defined. Except as specifically defined herein, all words have their customary definition. Section 4-1. - General. Words used in the present tense include the future tense. Words used in the singular include the plural, and words in the plural include the singular. The word "shall" is always mandatory. The word "person" includes a firm, association, organization, trust, company, or corporation as well as an individual. The word "lot" includes the word "plot" or "parcel." The word "building" includes the word "structure." The word "used" or "occupied," as applied to any land or building, shall be construed to include the words "intended, arranged, or designated to be used or occupant." The word "map" or "zoning map" mean the Official Zoning Map of the City of Quitman. Section 4-2. - Specific. The following terms or words are hereby specifically defined: 4-2.1 Accessory Use or Building: The use or building customarily incidental and subordinate to the principal use or building located on the same lot with such principal use or building. 4-2.2 Building: Any structure, except a trailer, intended for shelter, housing, or enclosure of persons, animals, or chattels. 4-2.3 Building, Principal: A building in which is conducted the main or principal use of the lot on which said building is located. 4-2.4 Dwelling: A building designated or used for permanent living quarters for one or more families or individuals. 4-2.5 Dwelling Unit: One or more rooms with kitchen facilities designed as a unit for occupancy by one family for cooking, living, and sleeping purposes. 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 157/196 4-2.6 Family: One or more persons occupying a premises and living as a single housekeeping unit, as distinguished from a group occupying a boarding house, lodging house, hotel, or fraternity or sorority house. 4-2.7 Floor Area, Gross: The total number of square feet of floor area in a building determined by horizontal measurements between the exterior faces of walls, excluding basement area, porches, carports, or garages. 4-2.8 Home Occupation: An occupation or profession for gain or support conducted only by members of the family residing on the premises and conducted entirely within the principal or accessory buildings, provided that the total floor area used for such purposes does not equal more than 25% of the floor area of the principal building. (See Section 5-16) 4-2.9 Junk Yard: Use of property for outdoor storage, keeping, abandonment, sale, or resale of junk including scrap metal, rags, paper or other scrap materials, used lumber, salvaged house wrecking and structural steel, materials and equipment, or for the dismantling, demolition, or abandonment of automobiles or other vehicles or machinery or parts thereof. 4-2.10 Lot: A parcel of land being occupied or capable of being occupied by one or more buildings, including accessory buildings incidental to them, and including such open spaces as required by such [this] ordinance. 4-2.11 Lot of Record: A lot which is part of a subdivision recorded in the office of the clerk of the Superior Court, or a parcel of land described by metes and bounds, the description of which has been so recorded. 4-2.12 Lot, Width: The distance between the side lot lines, measured along the front yard setback line as established by this ordinance, or if no setback is established, the horizontal distance between the side lot lines measured along the street right-of-way line. 4-2.13 Non-Conforming Use: A building, structure, or use of land existing at the time of the enactment of this ordinance which does not conform to the regulations of the district in which it is located. 4-2.14 Nursery School: An agency, organization, or individual providing daytime care of four or more children not related by blood or marriage or not the legal wards or foster children of the attendant adult. 4-2.15 Setback: The distance from the center line of the street to the nearest point of the building. 4-2.16 Street: A public way for vehicular traffic which affords a primary means of access to abutting property. 4-2.17 Structure: Anything constructed or erected with a fixed location on or in the ground, or attached to something having a fixed location on the ground. Among other things, structures include buildings, mobile homes, billboards, swimming pools, and fall-out shelters but does not include walls or fences, excepting signs or billboards of less than 48 square feet in area on one side. 4-2.18 Trailer (Mobile Home): Any trailer, vehicle, or similar portable structure mounted on wheels, or designed for mounting on wheels, including structural additions, except camping type trailers parked and unoccupied. Such unit shall be considered a mobile home whether or not the wheels have been removed and whether or not on a temporary or permanent foundation. (See Section 5-17) 4-2.19 Yard, Front: An open unoccupied space on the same lot with the principal building, between the front line of the principal building and the front line of the lot, and extending the full width of the lot. (See Article VI) 4-2.20 Yard, Rear: An open unoccupied space except for an accessory structure on the same lot with the principal building, between the rear line of the building and the rear line of the lot and extending the full width of the lot. (See Article VI) 4-2.21 Proposed Zoning Change: A request by a party for a change in the zoning ordinance for the city of Quitman which may result in: (a) The adoption of a zoning ordinance; (b) The adoption of an amendment to a zoning ordinance which changes the text of a zoning ordinance; or (c) The adoption of an amendment to a zoning ordinance which rezones property from one zoning classification to another. 4-2.22 Apartment Complex: An apartment complex is defined as any building or portion thereof used as a multiple dwelling for the purpose for providing three or more separate dwelling units whether separated by a fire wall or not which may or may not share a common means of egress or other common facilities, including but not limited to a common yard, recreational facilities, driveway, parking lot, central courtyard, or other facilities of similar nature. (Ord. No. 303, § 1, 1-7-1985; Ord. No. 325, § 3, 10-6-1986; Ord. No. 394, A, 1-8-1991) ARTICLE V. - GENERAL PROVISIONS Section 5-1. - Non-conforming uses. Any use of any building or structure or land existing at the time of the enactment of this ordinance may be continued even though such use does not conform with the provisions of this ordinance, except that a non-conforming use shall not be changed to another non-conforming use or re-established after discontinuance of more than one year; or extended except in conformity with this ordinance; or rebuilt, altered, or repaired after damage exceeding 75% of the replacement cost at the time of destruction. (See Section 4-2.13). Section 5-2. - Minimum off-street parking requirements. The following off-street parking requirements shall apply to all zoning districts except the CBD (Central Business District). Off-street vehicle storage or standing space (each space to be ten feet wide, 20 feet deep in addition to adequate access drives and maneuvering area) shall be provided on any lot where any of the following uses are hereafter established. Such parking area shall have direct vehicular access to a street or alley and shall contain at least the number of parking spaces as set forth below: 5-2.1 Residences: One parking space for each family dwelling unit. 5-2.2 Rooming Houses, Tourist Homes, Motels, and Hotels: One parking space for each rental unit. 5-2.3 Churches, Theaters, Auditoriums, or Other Places of Public Assembly: One parking space for every three hundred (300) square feet of floor area, or one space for each four seats or facilities available for patron use, whichever is greatest. 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 158/196 5-2.4 Indoor Recreation Establishments, Clubs, Lodges or Commercial Schools: One parking space for every three hundred (300) square feet of floor area, or one space for each four seats or facilities available for patron use, whichever is greatest. 5-2.5 Kindergarten and Nursery Schools: One parking space for each employee plus a suitable area for safe and convenient loading of students. 5-2.6 Trailer Park: One parking space for each trailer stall. 5-2.7 Retail Trade and Services: One parking space for each two hundred (200) square feet devoted to trade or service activity, plus one parking space for each vehicle used directly in the conduct of the enterprise. 5-2.8 Office, Professional, or Public Building: One parking space for each three hundred (300) square feet of floor area. 5-2.9 Hospitals: One parking space for each two beds intended for patients. 5-2.10 Warehousing, Wholesale Trade, Manufacturing, or Industrial Establishments: One parking space for each two employees plus one parking space for each vehicle used directly in the conduct of the enterprise. Section 5-3. - Minimum number of loading spaces required. Industrial, wholesale, and retail operations shall provide loading space as follows: 5-3.1 Spaces Appropriate to Functions: Off-street loading spaces shall be provided as appropriate to the functions and scope of operation of individual or groups of buildings and uses. 5-3.2 Design of Loading Spaces: Off-street loading spaces shall be designed and constructed so that all maneuvering to park and unpark vehicles for loading and unloading can take place entirely within the property lines of the premises. Loading spaces shall be provided so as not to interfere with the free, normal movement of vehicles and pedestrians on public rights-of-way. 5-3.3 Off-Street Loading Spaces: Where off-street truck loading and unloading space is required such space shall be at least ten feet wide and 24 feet in length. Section 5-4. - Off-street parking within 250 feet of the principal use. If vehicle parking or storage space required cannot be reasonably provided on the same lot on which the principal use is conducted, such space may be provided on other property provided such property lies within two hundred fifty (250) feet of the main entrance of the principal use. Section 5-5. - Uses except as hereinafter provided. No building or structure shall hereafter be used or occupied and no building or structure or part thereof shall be erected, constructed, reconstructed, moved, subdivided, or altered except in conformity with the regulations herein specified. (See Sections 9-2 and 9-3) Section 5-6. - Buildings. No building shall hereafter be erected, constructed, or altered so as to exceed the height limit, or so as to accommodate or house a greater number of families than required or specified by the regulations herein for the district in which it is located. Section 5-7. - Yard and parking requirements maintained. No building shall hereafter be erected, reconstructed, constructed, or altered to have a narrower or smaller front, side or rear yard than herein required, and off-street parking spaces shall not be reduced below the minimum number as required herein. (See Article VI and Section 5-2) Section 5-8. - Lot size. No lot shall hereafter be created except in conformity with the regulations herein specified; and no lot shall be reduced in size so that lot width, size of yard, lot area, or any other requirement of this ordinance is not maintained. Section 5-9. - Public street frontage. No building shall hereafter be constructed on a lot which does not have at least 30 feet of frontage on a publicly dedicated, publicly accepted, and publicly maintained street. Section 5-10. - One principal building per lot. Within residential districts only, no more than one principal building with its customary accessory buildings may occupy or be constructed upon any lot of record. (See Section 4-2.11 and Section 4-2.3) Section 5-11. - Lots with multiple frontage. On a corner lot where the main entrance into a residence is facing a side yard, it shall be permissible for purposes of this ordinance to construe the residence to be fronting on the street other than that street which said entrance faces, and side and rear yard requirements may be provided accordingly. If a building is constructed on a through lot having frontage on two roads not at an intersection, a setback from each road shall be provided equal to the front yard requirement for the district in which the lot is located. Section 5-12. - Permitted modification of setback requirements. When a building is proposed on a lot and when on either or both lots which adjoin such lot at the street right-of-way line there exists a principal building which does not conform to the setback requirements of this ordinance, and the Board of Zoning Appeals finds that because of the width and shape of the lot it would impose an unnecessary hardship on the owner if the rigid requirements of this ordinance were followed, the Board may allow the required setback for such building to be as follows: (1) where only one said adjoining lot contains a principle building with a non-conforming setback, the setback shall be the computed average of (a) the normal setback requirement with (b) the nonconforming setback; or (2) 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 159/196 where both adjoining lots contain a principle building each with a nonconforming setback, the minimum setback shall be the computed average of the two nonconforming setbacks. (See Section 10-6.3) Section 5-13. - Adjoining and vacant lots of record. If two or more adjoining and vacant lots of record with continuous frontage are in a single ownership any time after the adoption of this ordinance and such lots individually are less than the lot width requirements for the district in which they are located, such groups of lots shall together be considered as a single lot or shall be grouped into several lots of minimum permitted size; the resulting lot or lots shall be subject to the dimensional requirements of this ordinance. (See Section 4-2.11) Section 5-14. - Lots of record. Except as set forth in Section 5-13, any lot of record at any [the] time of the adoption of this ordinance which does not meet the minimum lot width and/or lot area requirements herein provided, may be used as a building site for a single-family residence, provided the required yard setbacks are maintained. (See Section 4-2.11) Section 5-15. - Permitted encroachment of yards and setbacks. Architectural features such as cornices, eaves, steps, gutters, and fire escapes may project not more than three feet beyond any required setback line, except where such projections would obstruct driveways which are or may be used for access for service and/or emergency vehicles. Section 5-16. - Home occupations. A home occupation as defined by this ordinance shall be governed by the following requirements: (See Section 4-2.8) a. Only residents of the dwelling may be engaged in the home occupation. b. The home occupation shall be clearly incidental to the residential use of the dwelling, and shall not change the essential residential character of the building. c. No display of products shall be visible from the street, and only products produced on the premises may be sold on the premises. d. Use of the building for this purpose shall not exceed 25% of one floor of the principle building. e. No internal or external alterations inconsistent with the residential use of the building shall be permitted. f. The occupational [occupation] shall not constitute a nuisance in the neighborhood. g. No accessory buildings or outside storage shall be used in connection with the occupation. h. Instruction in music and similar subjects shall be limited to two students at a time. i. Vehicles used primarily as passenger vehicles only shall be permitted in connection with the conduct of the customary home occupation. j. No more than three non-transient guests may be boarded at any one time as a customary home occupation. k. The following and similar uses shall be considered home occupations: addressing service, art instructor, beauty shop, dentist, doctor, drafting, dressmaking, insurance agent, manufacturing agent, massage parlor, music teacher, notary public, photography, real estate agent, tax consultant. Section 5-17. - Trailer parks. Trailer parks are allowed within R-P and G-B districts provided the following requirements are met: (See Section 5-2.6) a. The minimum size shall be three acres; and b. The park shall have minimum side yards of 15 feet and a front yard at least 20 feet greater than that required for other uses permitted in the district; and c. Each trailer shall be connected to water, sewerage, and electrical utilities; and, d. 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 160/196 The minimum lot area per trailer shall be no less than two thousand four hundred (2,400) square feet with a minimum stall width of 40 feet where served by public water and sewers. The lot shall not contain less than four thousand (4,000) square feet of lot area per trailer where trailers will be served by septic tanks; and e. The minimum distance between any two trailers or between any trailer and any other building in the park shall be 20 feet; and f. A 20 foot drive properly drained, shall serve each trailer lot and be drained so as to prevent damage to adjoining property, public or private; and g. Each trailer lot shall be clearly defined by means of concrete, steel, or iron pipe markers placed at all corners; and h. At least two hundred (200) square feet per trailer lot not to be a part of required trailer stalls, shall be provided in one or more locations for community playground and recreation purposes; and i. No trailer park shall be occupied by a greater number of trailers than that authorized in the approved building and occupancy permits. No trailer park shall be enlarged or extended unless a separate building permit and a separate occupancy permit have been issued; and j. Access to all trailer parks shall be limited to a major or secondary street, as designated on the Thoroughfare Plan for the City. [Section 5-18. - Use of mobile home, etc., as a residence as a special exception.] In emergency and hardship situations a special exception may be granted by the Board of Commissioners of the City of Quitman by majority vote upon written application directly to said board to allow the temporary use of a mobile home or other type of movable dwelling facility including travel trailers as a residence in the City of Quitman for a period not to exceed 120 days from date of issuance, provided the following conditions and/or restrictions are complied with: (a) Hardship or emergency situation shall be limited to the destruction or partial destruction (to the extent that same is rendered uninhabitable in the opinion of the building inspector of the City of Quitman), of an owner occupied single-family residence by fire, wind, flood, earthquake or other act of God. (b) Said residence must be the principal residence of the owner/occupier and an affidavit to that effect shall accompany the application to the Board of Commissioners for the special exception. (c) The special exception shall be limited to the placement of a mobile home or travel trailer upon the same lot occupied by the destroyed or uninhabitable structure by the causes listed in paragraph (a). (d) The special exception permit shall be limited to a period of 120 days from the date of issuance or for so long as the reconstruction or rehabilitation of the residence in question takes whichever period is shorter. Under no circumstances shall a mobile home or travel trailer be allowed to remain in place in an area under this ordinance [section] for a period in excess of 120 days. (e) Each applicant for this special exception must present proof of his or her financial ability to rebuild or repair said residence within the 120-day period of time and said proof shall accompany the application for said special exception and shall be in such form as may be from time to time determined by the Board of Commissioners of the City of Quitman in its sole discretion. (f) The written consent of all land owners within a two-hundred-foot radius of the property in question if said property is not within a subdivision in the City of Quitman[;] and if said property is within a subdivision in the City of Quitman, said application shall be accompanied by a written consent of all owners of property within said subdivision. It is the intention of the commission that this ordinance [section] be interpreted and applied only in very limited cases and only to prevent severe hardships on residents of the city in emergency situations. In determining whether to issue an exception under this section, alternate housing availability shall be a major determining factor to be considered by the Board of Commissioners. (Ord. ARTICLE VII. - ESTABLISHMENT OF DISTRICTS, THE OFFICIAL ZONING MAP, AND THE OFFICIAL THOROUGHFARE PLAN Section 7-1. - Use of Districts. For the purpose of this ordinance, the City of Quitman, Georgia, is hereby divided into seven districts designated as follows: SF Single-Family Residential District MF Multi-Family Residential District RP Residential Professional District CBD Central Business District GB General Business District LI Light Industrial District HI Heavy Industrial District Section 7-2. - District boundaries. The boundaries of each district are hereby established as shown on a map entitled "Official Zoning Map, City of Quitman, Georgia." The Official Zoning Map shall be certified by the signature of the Chairman of the City Commission attested by the City Clerk, together with the date of the adoption of this ordinance. Said map and all explanatory matter thereupon accompanies and is hereby made a part of this ordinance, and will hereinafter be referred to as the "Quitman Zoning Map." An accurate, upto-date copy of said map shall be retained in the office of the Zoning Administrator at all times for display to the general public. Section 7-3. - Rules for determining boundaries. 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 162/196 Where uncertainties exist with respect to the boundaries of any aforesaid districts as shown on the Quitman Zoning Map, the following rules shall apply: 7-3.1 Where the district boundaries are indicated as approximately following the center lines of streets or highways, right-of-way lines, such center lines, street lines, or highway right-of-way lines shall be construed to be such boundaries. 7-3.2 Where district boundaries are indicated on the Quitman Zoning Map as being set back from a street, road, highway, railroad, stream, or river, and parallel thereto, then such district boundaries unless otherwise specifically indicated, shall be construed as being at the scaled distance from the center line of such street, road, highway, railroad, stream, or river and as being parallel thereto. 7-3.3 Boundaries indicated as approximately following platted lot lines shall be construed as following such lot lines. 7-3.4 Where a district boundary line as appearing on the Quitman Zoning Map divides a lot in a single ownership at the time of this enactment, district requirements of the least restrictive portion of such lot shall be deemed to apply to the whole thereof, provided that such extensions shall not include any part of such lot more than thirty-five (35) feet beyond the district boundary line. Section 7-4. - Thoroughfare plan. For the purposes of this ordinance, the streets within the City of Quitman, Georgia are classified as follows: (1) Major Thoroughfare. (2) Secondary. (3) Minor. The classification of each street is hereby established as shown on a map entitled "Official Thoroughfare Plan," City of Quitman, Georgia. The Official Thoroughfare Plan Map shall be certified by the signature of the Chairman of the City Commission attested by the City Clerk, together with the date of the adoption of this ordinance. Said map and all explanatory matter thereupon accompanies and is hereby made a part of this ordinance. An accurate up-to-date copy of said map shall be retained in the office of the zoning administrator at all times for display to the general public.
