Petroleum bulk plant. Auto service stations, including major auto repair. Feed, grain, or fertilizer wholesaling and storage. Freezer locker service, ice storage. Truck terminal. Automobile, truck, farm equipment, or motorcycle sales, repair, or upholstery; auto washeteria, paint shops, or tire recapping (including rebuilding of parts and sale of parts and equipment). Outdoor storage of equipment is permitted. Construction contractors and similar contractors yards and related activities, such as sale and storage of building supplies and materials, including outside storage of equipment and materials. Pest control establishments, including outside storage of equipment and materials on the premises. Section 8-6. - H-I Heavy industrial district. 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 165/196 Within the H-I Heavy Industrial District, the following uses are permitted: All uses which are permitted in the L-I Light Industrial District, except motels. Acid storage and manufacturing. Heavy manufacturing, including any manufacturing, packaging, processing or handling of materials provided that any use such as the manufacturing of cement, corrosive acid, bone distillation, drop forge industry, fat rendering, fertilizer manufacturing, organic material reduction, meat processing plants, and the like which produce noise, odors, dust, fumes, fire hazards, or other nuisance features shall be set back not less than three hundred (300) feet from any H-I District boundary. Junk yards or auto graveyards; provided that they shall be set back not less than five hundred (500) feet from any public road right-of-way unless enclosed by a six foot high solid face fence. Planing or saw mill. Railroad classification and repair yard. Raising or sale of livestock, including slaughter houses. Sanitary fill or incineration. Lumber yard, coal storage yard, and similar storage yards. ARTICLE IX. - ADMINISTRATION, ENFORCEMENT, AND PENALTIES Section 9-1. - Enforcing officer. The office of Zoning Administrator of the City of Quitman, Georgia, is hereby established. The duties of the Zoning Administrator shall include inspecting premises, issuing building permits and certificates of occupancy for uses and buildings, and assuring that all such buildings and uses are in accordance with the requirements of this ordinance. Section 9-2. - Building Permits. Building permits shall be issued in accordance with the following provisions: 9-2.1 Building Permit Required: It shall be unlawful to commence construction, moving, or alteration of any building until the Zoning Administrator has issued a building permit for such work and such permit is posted in view of the street on the premises where the building, moving or alteration is to take place. 9-2.2 Issuance of the Building Permit: In applying to the Zoning Administrator for a building permit, the applicant shall submit two copies of a dimensional sketch or a toscale plan signed by the owner or his authorized agent, indicating the shape, size, and location of the lot to be built upon and the shape, size, height, use, and location of the buildings to be erected, demolished, altered, or moved and of any buildings already on the lot, the number of dwelling units the building is designed to accommodate (if any), the setback lines of buildings on adjoining lots, and such other information concerning the lot or adjoining lots as may be essential for determining whether the provisions of this ordinance are being observed. If the proposed excavation, filling, construction, or movement set forth in said sketch or plan are in conformity with the provisions of this ordinance and other ordinances of the City of Quitman, Georgia, then in force, the Zoning Administrator shall sign and return one copy of the sketch plan to the applicant and shall issue a building permit upon payment of the required fee. The Zoning Administrator shall retain one copy of the building permit and one copy of the sketch or plan. 9-2.3 Refusal of Building Permit: If the sketch of plan submitted describes work which does not conform to the requirements of this ordinance, the Zoning Administrator shall not issue a building permit but shall return one copy of the sketch or plan to the applicant along with the refusal in writing. Such refusal shall state the reasons therefor and shall cite portions of this ordinance with which the submitted sketch or plan does not comply. The Zoning Administrator shall retain one copy of the sketch or plan and one copy of the refusal. 9-2.4 Time Limitations: Any building permit issued shall become invalid unless the work authorized by it shall have been commenced within six months of its date of issue, or if the work authorized by it is suspended or abandoned for a period of one year. Section 9-3. - Certificate of Occupancy. A certificate of occupancy shall be issued by the Zoning Administrator in accordance with the following provisions: 9-3.1 Certificate of Occupancy Required: A certificate of occupancy issued by the Zoning Administrator is required in advance of occupancy or use of: (a) a building hereafter erected. (b) a building hereafter altered so as to affect the height; or the side, front, or rear yards. (c) any building or premises where a change in the type of occupancy or use will occur. 9-3.2 Issuance of Certificate of Occupancy: Upon payment of any required fees, the Zoning Administrator shall sign and issue a certificate of occupancy if the proposed use of land or building as stated on the certificate of occupancy, as signed thereto by the owner or his appointed agent, is found to conform to the applicable provisions of this ordinance and if the building, as finally constructed, complies with the sketch or plan submitted for the building permit. One copy of all certificates of occupancy issued which contain a statement of the intended use of the applicable property signed by the owner or his agent shall be kept on file in the office of the Zoning Administrator. 9-3.3 Denial of Certificate of Occupancy: A certificate of occupancy shall not be issued unless the proposed use of a building or land conforms to the applicable provisions of this ordinance, or unless the building, as finally constructed, complies with the sketch or plan upon which the building permit was issued. Section 9-4. - Records. 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 166/196 It shall be the duty of the Zoning Administrator to keep a record of all building permits and certificates of occupancy issued, with a notation of all special conditions involved. He shall file and safely keep copies of all sketches and plans submitted, and the same shall form a part of the records of his office and shall be available for use by the City Commission, Board of Zoning Appeals, Planning Commission, and Officials of the City of Quitman, Georgia, and the general public. Section 9-5. - Penalties. Any person violating any provision of this ordinance shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be punished for each offense according to law. Each day such violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense. Section 9-6. - Remedies. In case any building is erected, constructed, reconstructed, altered, repaired, converted, or maintained, or any building or land is used in violation of this ordinance, the Zoning Administrator, or any appropriate city attorney, or any person who would be damaged by such violation, in addition to other remedies, may institute injunction, mandamus, or other appropriate action or proceedings to stop the violation in the case of each such building or use of land. ARTICLE X. - BOARD OF ZONING APPEALS Section 10-1. - Membership. 10-1.1 Appointment and Term of Office: The Board of Zoning Appeals of the City of Quitman, Georgia, is hereby established. Said Board shall consist of three members appointed by the City Commission for overlapping terms of three years. Initial appointment shall be as follows: one member, for one year; one member for two years; and one member for three years; each successive appointment shall be for three years. Any vacancy in the membership shall be filled for the unexpired term in the same manner as the initial appointment. Members may be removed for cause by the appointing authority upon written charges and after a public hearing. No member shall hold any public office or position, except that one member may also be a member of the Planning Commission. The Board of Zoning Appeals shall adopt rules in accordance with the provisions of this ordinance for the conduct of its affairs. 10-1.2 Compensation: The Board members shall receive no compensation for their service except that they shall be reimbursed for out-of-pocket expenditures made in connection with their duties. Section 10-2. - Rules and Procedures. The Board shall elect one of its members as Chairman, who shall serve for one year or until he is reelected or his successor is elected. The Board of Appeals shall appoint a secretary who may be an officer of the City of Quitman, or of the Planning Commission. The Board shall have authority to adopt rules of procedure. Meetings of the Board shall be held at the call of the Chairman, or in his absence the acting Chairman. The Chairman, or in his absence the acting Chairman, may administer oaths and compel the attendance of witnesses by subpoena. The Board shall keep minutes of its proceedings, showing the vote of each member upon each question, or if absent or failing to vote, indicating such fact and shall keep records of its examinations and other official actions, all of which shall be immediately filed in the office of said Board and shall be a public record. The decisions of the Board shall be by resolution, which resolution shall contain a statement of the grounds of its decision or action. The full text of the resolution shall be sent to the appellant. No appeal requesting the same relief in regard to the same property shall be received or heard by the Board for a period of 12 months following the date of said resolution, except that this limitation shall not affect the right of said Board to grant a rehearing as provided in the rules of procedure adopted by said Board. All hearings shall be open to the public. Section 10-3. - Administrative Assistance. The Zoning Administrator shall provide such technical, administrative, and clerical assistance and office space as is required by the Board to carry out its function under the provisions of these regulations. Section 10-4. - Appeals. 10-4.1 Who May Appeal: Appeals to the Board may be taken by any person aggrieved or by any officer, department, board, or bureau of the governing authority affected by any decision of the Zoning Administrator. Such appeals shall be filed no later than 30 days after the date of notification of the decision appealed from, by filing with the Zoning Administrator and with the Board a notice of appeal specifying the grounds thereof. The Zoning Administrator shall forthwith transmit to the Board all the papers constituting the record upon which the action appealed from was taken. 10-4.2 Legal Proceedings Stayed: An appeal stays all legal proceedings in furtherance of the action appealed from, unless the Zoning Administrator certifies to the Board, after the notice of appeal shall have been filed with him, that by reason of acts stated in the certificate a stay would, in his opinion, cause imminent peril to life and property. In such a case, proceedings shall not be stayed otherwise than by restraining order which may be granted by the Board or by a court of record on application, on notice to the Zoning Administrator, and on due cause shown. 10-4.3 Presentation of Evidence: The appellant, and any public agency, or private individual shall be entitled to present evidence on matters before the Board; and said Board may request technical service, advice, data, or factual evidence from the Planning Commission, and the governing authority for assistance in reaching decisions. 10-4.4 Extent of Board of Appeal's Power: The Board may, in conformity with the provisions of these regulations, reverse or affirm, wholly or partly, or may modify the order, requirement, decision, or determination of the Zoning Administrator, and to that end shall have all the powers of the Zoning Administrator. The Board may direct the issuance of a permit. It shall be the duty of the Zoning Administrator to carry out the decisions of the Board. Section 10-5. - Public Hearing. 10-5.1 Notice of Hearing Shall Be Given: Before making its decision on a special exception, or on a request for a variance, or on any other matter within the Board's purview, said Board shall hold a public hearing thereon. At least 15 days notice of the time and place of such hearing shall be sent to the appellant or petitioner by mail to his last known address, to the Planning Commission, to the Zoning Administrator, and to the owners of all properties either adjoining the property on which the hearing is concerned or situated directly across a public right-of-way from said property. Such notice shall contain the name of the appellant or petitioner, the date, time, and place set for the hearing, and a brief statement of the nature of the hearing. 10-5.2 Public Notice in Newspaper: The Board shall give public notice of the hearing in a newspaper published and circulated in Brooks County by advertisement published at least 15 days prior to the date of the public hearing. 10-5.3 Who May Appear: Any party may appear at the public hearing in person or by agent or attorney. 10-5.4 Time Limit on Board's Decision: The Board shall reach a decision following a public hearing within 30 days. Section 10-6. - Powers and Duties. 10-6.1 Appeals from Actions of the Zoning Administrator: The Board shall hear and decide upon appeals where it is alleged there is error in any order, requirement, decision, or determination made by the Zoning Administrator in the enforcement of these regulations. 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 167/196 10-6.2 Special Exceptions: The Board shall hear and decide upon special exceptions as authorized by this ordinance. The application to establish such use shall be approved on a finding by the Board of Appeals that: (a) The proposed use will not be contrary to the purpose of this ordinance. (b) The proposed use will not be detrimental to the use or development of adjacent properties or the general neighborhood nor affect adversely the health and safety of residents and workers. (c) The proposed use will not constitute a nuisance or hazard because of the number of persons who will attend or use such facility, vehicular movement, noise or fumes generated, or type of physical activity. (d) The proposed use will not be affected adversely by the existing uses, and the proposed use will be placed on a lot of sufficient size to satisfy the space requirements of said use. (e) The parking and all development standards set forth for each particular use for which a permit may be granted have been met. (f) Provided, that the Board of Zoning Appeals may impose or require such additional restriction and standards as may be necessary to protect the health and safety of workers and residents in the community, to protect the value and use of property in the general neighborhood; and provided, that wherever the Board of Zoning Appeals shall find, in the case of any permit granted pursuant to the provisions of these regulations, that any term, condition, or restrictions upon which such permit was granted are not being complied with, said Board shall rescind and revoke such permit after giving due notice to all parties concerned and granting full opportunity for a public hearing. 10-6.3 Request for a Variance: The Board may authorize upon appeal in specific cases such variance from the terms of these regulations as will not be contrary to the public interest where, owing to special conditions, a literal enforcement of the provisions of these regulations will, in an individual case, result in practical difficulty or unnecessary hardship, so that the spirit of these regulations shall be observed, public safety and welfare secured, and substantial justice done; provided, however, that a variance shall not be granted for a use of land or building or structure that is prohibited by this ordinance in the district in question. Such variance may be granted in an individual case upon finding by the Board that the following exists: (a) there are extraordinary and exceptional conditions pertaining to the particular piece of property in question because of its size, shape, or topography; and (b) the special conditions and circumstances existing are not a result of the action of the applicant; and (c) the application of these regulations to this particular piece of property would create a practical difficulty or hardship; and (d) such conditions are peculiar to the particular piece of property involved; and (e) the variance requested is the minimum variance that will make possible the reasonable use of land, building or structure; and (f) relief, if granted, would not cause substantial detriment to the public good or impair the purposes and intent of these regulations; provided, however, that no variance may be granted for a use of land or building or structure that is prohibited by this ordinance; and (g) a literal interpretation of this ordinance would deprive the applicant of any rights that others in the same district are allowed; and (h) provided, that the Board of Zoning Appeals may impose or require such additional restrictions and standards as may be necessary to protect the health and safety of workers and residents in the community, and to protect the value and use of property in the general neighborhood; and provided, that wherever the Board of Zoning Appeals shall find, in the case of any permit granted pursuant to the provisions of these regulations, that any of the terms, conditions, or restrictions upon which such permit was granted are not being complied with, said Board shall rescind and revoke such permit after giving due notice to all parties concerned and granting full opportunity for a public hearing. 10-6.4 Forms: Appeals shall be made on forms provided by the Zoning Administrator, and all information required on said forms shall be provided by the applicant. Forms shall be filed with the Board, and the appellant shall pay the Board for expense incidental to the appeal. No form shall be accepted by the Board unless it contains all pertinent information and is accompanied by a forty dollar ($40.00) fee, payable to the city, to defray expenses. (Ord. No. 303, § 3, 1-7-1985) Section 10-7. - Limit of Authority. 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 168/196 The Board of Zoning Appeals shall not have the authority to grant special exceptions for the placement of residential mobile homes in areas which are not established mobile home parks. Section 10-8. - Review of Decision. All decisions of the Board of Zoning Appeals shall be subject to the approval of the Board of Commissioners of the City of Quitman, Georgia. ARTICLE XI. - AMENDMENT Section 11-1. - General conditions. These regulations, including the Quitman Zoning Map, may be amended by the City Commission on its own motion, on petition or on recommendation of the Planning Commission. However, no amendment shall become effective unless it shall have been proposed by or shall first have been submitted to the Planning Commission for review and recommendation pursuant to the following procedures, policies and standards. (Ord. No. 325, § 2, 10-6-1986) Section 11-2. - Policies, Procedures and Standards for Processing Requests of an Initial Zoning Ordinance, Update or Major Revision of the Present Zoning Ordinance or Rezoning Requested by the City of Quitman. 11-2.1 In the event of an initial zoning ordinance, update or major revisions of the zoning ordinance or a rezoning requested by the City, the Planning Commission shall, using all available resources and materials at its disposal, study the needs of the City and develop a draft zoning ordinance complete with appropriate specifications and conditions and, additionally, provide a Zoning Map of the City of Quitman to delineate zoned district boundaries, if the same is required. 11-2.2 Standards and Evaluation Form. The Planning Commission shall, whenever it reviews a proposed zoning change, evaluate each proposed change according to each of the standards listed below. The evaluation form listed in Appendix B-1 shall be completed by the Planning Commission for each proposed change. This shall be done prior to the Public Hearing required in Section 11-2.4. The standards are as follows: (1) The existing land use and zoning classification of adjacent and nearby property. (2) The possible creation of an isolated district unrelated to adjacent and nearby property. (3) The extent to which property values of adjacent or nearby property may be diminished by the proposed zoning change. (4) The population density pattern and the possible increase or overtaxing of the load on public facilities including, but not limited to, utilities and streets. (5) The cost of the City of Quitman in providing, improving, increasing or maintaining public utilities, streets and public safety measures. (6) The relative gain to the citizens of Quitman as compared to the hardship imposed upon the property owner. (7) Whether there are substantial reasons why the property cannot be used in accordance with its existing zoning classification. (8) The length of time the property has been vacant as zoned considered in the context of land development in the area in the vicinity of the property. (9) The aesthetic effect of existing and future use of the property as if relates to the surrounding area. (10) The extent to which the proposed zoning change will be consistent with the comprehensive plan of the Zoning Ordinance for the City of Quitman. (11) Any other factors relevant to the balancing of interests in promoting the public health, safety, morality or general welfare of the Citizens of Quitman against the right of unrestricted use of property. 11-2.3 Review of Proposed Zoning Amendment with City Commission. The Planning Commission shall, after the completion of the proposed zoning amendment and its evaluation form, review the same with the City Commission. The City Commission shall make whatever changes, deletions or additions it desires necessary to make at this meeting and any changes made by the City Commission shall be incorporated into a final draft of the Zoning Ordinance for public inspection. The City Commission shall also set a time, date and location for a public hearing before the Planning Commission on the proposed zoning change. 11-2.4 Notice of Public Hearing. The Clerk of the City shall, after the meeting held pursuant to [section]11-2.3, prepare and cause to be published in the official organ for the City of Quitman a notice containing a summary of the proposed zoning change to be considered and the date, and place of the Public Hearing. Said Notice shall be published not less than 15 days nor more than forty-five (45) days prior to the hearing date. 11-2.5 Availability for Public Inspection. The City Clerk shall provide, for public inspection, copies of the proposed zoning ordinance and map, if required, and the evaluation form completed by the Planning Commission. Public inspection may be had during the normal business hours of the City Office from the date of the appearance of the public hearing notice until the day of the hearing. 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 169/196 11-2.6 Procedure and Conduct for the Public Hearing. The public hearing shall be convened at the time, date and location set forth in the public notice and shall be presided over by the Chairman of the Planning Commission. The Chairman shall state that the meeting will be held in accordance with Robert's Rules of Order and, further, shall state the following additional procedures: (1) The Chairman must recognize an individual from the floor before he may speak. Upon being recognized, the individual shall give his name and address. (2) The individual speaking will be allowed three minutes to express any opinion and make points on each separate element of the proposed zoning change which he wishes to address, with a maximum of 15 points allowed per individual. Additional individuals may be recognized by the Chairman in accordance with the aforementioned procedure to enunciate additional points of elements of the proposed zoning change. The Chairman may grant individuals additional time, if he so desires. (3) The citizens in attendance will have the right to discuss all elements of the proposed zoning change that each individual wishes to address so long as the procedures set forth hereinabove are complied with. (4) The Chairman shall, prior to all arguments on the proposed zoning change, review the proposed zoning change and evaluation sheet that has been previously prepared. The Secretary of the Planning Commission shall be made available to make notes of the proceedings. 11-2.7 Decision of the Planning Commission. The Planning Commission shall make a decision on the proposed zoning change within three days of the public hearing. Should the Planning Commission elect to make a decision at the Public Hearing, the Chairman shall announce the Planning Commission's recommendation at the hearing and that its recommendation will be placed on the City Commission's agenda for the next regular monthly meeting for approval or disapproval. Within three business days of its decision, the Planning Commission shall have the minutes of the public hearing, the proposed zoning change and the evaluation form transmitted to the City Clerk so that it may be placed on the City Commission's agenda for the next regular monthly meeting. Not later than one day after the decision has been rendered by the Planning Commission, the decision shall be posted as a regular public notice at the City Hall. (Ord. No. 325, § 2, 10-6-1986) Section 11-3. - Rezoning Requested by Citizens or Property Owners. 11-3.1 Application for Amendment. An application for a request to rezone shall be available from the Zoning Administrator for the City of Quitman. Upon completion of the form by the applicant, it shall be signed by applicant and submitted to the Zoning Administrator along with a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00). Said application shall be filed, during the normal business hours, in the Zoning Administrator's office. 11-3.2 Application for Text Amendment. In the event that the application requires a change in the text of the ordinance, the application shall set forth the new text to be added and the old text to be deleted. 11-3.3 Application for Map Amendment. An application for a map amendment shall include the following information: (a) The area in which the lot proposed to be reclassified is located and the street number, if any, or if none, the location with respect to the nearby public streets in common use; (b) A plat of the lot in question, or a description by metes and bounds, bearings, and distances of the lot, or if the boundaries conform to the lot boundaries within a subdivision for which a plat is recorded in the land records of the county, then the lot, block, and subdivision designations with appropriate plat references; (c) The present zoning classification and the classification proposed for such lot; (d) The name and address of the owners of the land; (e) The area of the land proposed to be reclassified stated in square fee, if less than one acre, and in acres, if one acre or more; and (f) The application number, date of application, and action taken on all prior applications filed for the reclassification of the whole or part of the land proposed to be reclassified. 11-3.4 Referral to Planning Commission. Within five business days after acceptance of any application for amendment, the Zoning Administrator shall transmit two copies of the application to the Planning Commission for its review and recommendation. 11-3.5 Review by Planning Commission. The Planning Commission shall, whenever it reviews a proposed zoning change, evaluate each proposed change according to each of the standards listed in Section 11-2.2. The evaluation listed in Appendix B-1 shall be completed by the Planning Commission for each proposed change. Such review shall be conducted and public hearing date set within 20 days of the Planning Commission's receipt of the application. This shall be done prior to the hearing held pursuant to [section] 11-3.6. 11-3.6 Public Hearing Notice. The Planning Commission shall conduct a public hearing on the proposed zoning ordinance before any action may be taken on it. A notice shall be placed in the official local organ for the City not less than 15 days nor more than forty-five (45) days prior to the hearing date. The Notice shall state the time, place and date of the hearing, the application number, description, location and owner of the property, the present zoning classification of the property and proposed change of zoning classification. 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 170/196 11-3.7 Notice to Interested Parties. A notice of the time, date and place of the hearing shall be sent by the Zoning Administrator by mail to the applicant and Planning Commission. All application files shall be placed in the custody of the Zoning Administrator and shall be open for public inspection during regular business hours. 11-3.8 Posting of Property. (1) Erection of signs. Within three days after the acceptance of an application for a map amendment, the applicant shall erect a sign, to be furnished by the Zoning Administrator, on the land proposed to be reclassified. Such sign shall be erected by the applicant within ten feet of the boundary line of such land that abuts the principal street providing access to the lot; and, if no public road abuts thereon, then such sign shall be erected to face in such manner as may be most readily seen by the public. The sign furnished by the Zoning Administrator shall have a minimum size of 30 by 40 inches, shall show the application number, the present zoning classification, the proposed zoning classification, the scheduled date, time, place of public hearing, and the telephone number to call for further information. If the land sought to be reclassified lies within more than one block as shown on a plat recorded in the land records of Brooks County, then a sign shall be erected by the applicant on the land in each block. Said sign shall be placed in the hereinabove designated location on the property not less than 15 days prior to the date of the hearing. (2) Deposit. No sign shall be furnished by the Zoning Administrator unless the applicant shall deposit the sum of ten dollars ($10.00) to be applied to the cost of said sign. On return of the sign to the Zoning Administrator by the applicant as hereinafter provided, there shall be repaid to the applicant the amount of said deposit. (3) Removal of Sign. Any such sign shall be maintained at all times by the applicant until a decision on the application has been made public by the City Commission, and then shall be removed by the applicant unless a reconsideration shall have been applied for in which event such sign shall remain until after the disposition of the application for reconsideration has been made by the governing authority. The sign shall be returned to the Zoning Administrator within five days thereafter. 11-3.9 Procedure and Conduct for Public Hearing. The public hearing held under this section shall be held in accordance with the procedures and conduct set forth in Section 11-2.6. 11-3.10 Decision of the Planning Commission. The Planning Commission shall make a decision on the proposed zoning change within 30 days of the public hearing. Should the Planning Commission elect to make a decision at the Public Hearing, the Chairman shall announce the Planning Commission's recommendation at the hearing and that its recommendation will be placed on the City Commission's agenda for the next regular monthly meeting for approval or disapproval. If the Planning Commission does not make a decision at the hearing or within 30 days from the date of the hearing, it shall be deemed to have approved the requested change. Not later than one day after the decision has been rendered by the Planning Commission, the decision shall be posted as a regular public notice at the City Hall. Within three business days of its decision, however made, the Planning Commission shall have the minutes of the public hearing, the proposed zoning ordinance and the evaluation form transmitted to the City Clerk so that it may be placed on the City Commission's agenda for the next regular monthly meeting. (Ord. No. 325, § 2, 10-6-1986) Section 11-4. - Reconsideration of a Zoning Change Denial. Any application for a zoning amendment which is denied by the City Commission shall not be reconsidered for one year after the said denial unless the City Commission agrees by two-third (2/3) vote of members present to rehear the petition. (Ord. All other ordinances or parts of ordinances not specifically in conflict herewith are hereby continued in force and effect, but all such ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict herewith are hereby repealed. These rules and regulations are established for the guidance of members of the Fire Department in their conduct and operations. 2. These regulations shall be uniform in their application to all members of the Fire Department. 3. All previous rules and regulations heretofore issued are canceled and superseded by these rules and regulations. 4. Interpretation of these rules and regulations, when needed, shall be made by the Chief of the Department in the form of official bulletins to be added to and become a part of these rules and regulations. 5. All members of the Fire Department will be furnished a copy of these rules and regulations, and it shall be their duty to become familiar with the contents thereof, so that they may thoroughly understand all instructions contained therein and conduct themselves accordingly; but, as emergencies may arise which cannot be foreseen and for which no rule or regulation can be provided at this time, it is expected that all members of the Department will act with discretion and promptness. 6. All members of the Fire Department shall observe all laws and statutes of the City Charter and City Code of the City of Quitman. ARTICLE II. - ORGANIZATION AND PERSONNEL 1. The Fire Department shall operate under the supervision of the Fire Chief. 2. Department matters shall be under the supervision of the Fire Chief with the approval of the City Manager. Employees shall not contact the City Manager or elected officials in regards to Fire Department matters or procedures without prior approval of the Fire Chief. 3. 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 172/196 The Fire Department shall consist of the following officers and men: Chief, Captain, Lieutenants, Engineers/Drivers and Privates. A. CHIEF (1) Shall be in full control of the Department, including stations, apparatus, equipment, fire alarm system, high pressure system, personnel, and all properties of the Fire Department, subject only to orders from the City Manager. (2) Shall act as the administrative and executive head of the Department and all matters pertaining thereto shall clear through his office. (3) Shall attend the meetings of the Commission as the representative of the Fire Department, making such recommendations as the needs of the service may require. (4) Shall once each year have prepared an estimated budget covering the financial needs of the Department for the ensuing year, and submit same to the City Manager. (5) Shall each year have prepared an annual report covering activities of the Department for the past year, and at that time incorporate recommendations for the betterment of the service. (6) May, at his option, assign any of his duties to his subordinates, receiving from them periodical reports as to progress of the work. (7) Shall answer such alarms of fire or other emergency as he shall deem to be for the best interest and protection of the City, and upon arrival shall assume full charge. (8) Shall require and receive from every member of the Fire Department prompt, intelligent and faithful service, and strict compliance with the rules and regulations herein set forth. (9) May suspend any member of the Department for incompetency, neglect of duty, immorality, drunkenness, failure to obey orders or these rules and regulations, or any conduct interfering with the efficient operation of the Fire Department. Such suspension by the Chief shall be final. In the event a member of the Department is suspended by the Chief for a period exceeding 15 days, the facts of such suspension shall be certified in writing immediately to the City Manager. (10) Shall maintain a modern, up-to-date Fire Prevention Program and supervise inspections of all buildings. To maintain permanent inspection system for each building. (11) Serve as Deputy State Fire Marshal and uphold the Laws and Ordinances of the City of Quitman, State Fire Commissioner and the Southern Standard Fire Prevention and Building Codes. (12) Shall initiate and supervise a Preventive Maintenance Program of fire apparatus and equipment. (13) Supervise proper use of Radio Signals and Communications and communications with employees. B. CAPTAIN AND LIEUTENANTS OF COMPANIES (1) Shall have immediate control of the company under his command, including recommendations of suspensions, dismissal, or other actions. (2) Shall arrange work of members of the company and assign members to special detail in order. (3) Shall direct activities of their companies at fires, under the orders of the Chief in charge, or his assistants. (4) Shall conduct, or have conducted, company drills not less frequent than once a week, or as necessary to bring company efficiency up to standard. (5) Shall maintain discipline and harmony among members of their companies. (6) 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 173/196 Shall be directly responsible for the care and cleanliness of their apparatus and equipment. (7) Shall submit all reports required by the Chief's office in proper form and on time. (8) Shall report any serious breach of discipline in their companies to the Assistant Chief in charge, who may forward to the Chief as necessary. (9) Shall inspect all buildings within the company District to become familiar with construction, class of business or occupancy and to learn the most expedient method of attack in case of fire or other emergency. (10) Shall be held responsible for all tools, implements and other equipment belonging to his apparatus. (11) Shall see that all members of the company on duty are ready to respond to alarms. (12) Shall require members of their companies to keep themselves neat and clean, after clean-up periods in the morning. (13) Shall require all members of their companies to familiarize themselves with these rules and regulations. (14) Shall, in the event of accident or injury to a member of their company, report it to the Captain or Chief as soon as possible and shall furnish to the Chief's office the proper accident form, giving all details. (15) Shall, in the event of accident involving Fire Department apparatus or equipment, fill out proper forms, with copy of same to the Chief's office, showing all details. (16) Shall keep and maintain an up-to-date list of names, addresses and telephone numbers of the members of their companies, and shall promptly advise the Chief's office of any change of address, phone number or family status. (17) Shall conduct, at least semi-annually, tests of hose, under approved method as set forth by the Chief. (18) Shall, if station Captain be held responsible for the proper discharge of station duties by members thereof. (19) Shall not cover up or conceal breach of discipline or other misdemeanor by a member of their companies. (20) Shall see that station lights, water and other utilities are not wasted. (21) Shall keep an up-to-date inventory covering equipment of the apparatus and station. (22) Shall keep an accurate and up-to-date log book, showing all pertinent information of the company, which log book shall be open to inspection by any member of the Chief's staff. (23) Shall require all members of the company to maintain good knowledge of their first alarm territory, and a fair knowledge of the entire City. (24) Shall keep their companies informed of any matter pertinent to the operation of the Department which shall come to their attention as general information. (25) Shall be just and dignified in all matters involving their subordinates, being careful to abstain from abusive and immoderate language in giving orders or while engaged in conversation. (26) It will be the responsibility of the Station Captains to keep all maps in the station up-graded and current. 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 174/196 (27) The officer in charge of any box alarm will be responsible for re-setting the box. If he cannot accomplish this he is to notify [the] Chief. C. COMPANY ENGINEERS AND/OR DRIVERS (1) Shall be solely responsible for the proper and safe handling of Department apparatus. (2) Shall be responsible for the proper readiness, care and operation of their respective equipment under the supervision of their officer, and shall report any trouble of any nature to their officer. (3) Shall be thoroughly familiar with the location of fire alarm boxes, hydrants, streets, schools, public buildings, hotels, etc., and must know the shortest and most direct route to the location. (4) Engineers must be capable of operating the pumping equipment of the Department in an efficient manner, and must know details of Fire Department Hydraulics as taught at the Training School. (5) Shall assume command of the company in the absence of the officer, provided such officer has not designated another to act in his stead, during his absence. D. COMPANY PRIVATES (1) Shall perform the duties assigned them by their company officers, both in stations and at fires. (2) Shall keep their officers advised as to their address, telephone number and family status. It is required that each member of the Department have a telephone in his home or business within 30 days of his employment. (3) Shall comply with these Rules and Regulations. E. TRAINING SCHOOL (1) Drill Instructors shall be responsible for the training of present personnel and of new personnel. They shall instruct in all fundamentals of fire fighting, fire prevention and inspections and first-aid, and shall conduct examinations and report qualifications to the office of the Chief. ARTICLE III. - PATRIOTIC CUSTOMS 1. When the National Anthem is played and the flag is not displayed, all present shall stand and face the music. Those in uniform shall salute, using the hand salute to the visor of the cap at the first note of the anthem, retaining the salute until the last note is played. All others shall stand at attention, men removing the headdress. When the flag is displayed, all present should face the flag. 2. During the ceremony of hoisting or lowering the flag, or when the flag is passing in a parade or in a review all persons present shall face the flag, stand at attention and salute. Those present in uniform using the hand salute to the visor of the cap; those not in uniform should remove the headdress with the right hand, holding it at the left shoulder so that the hand is over the heart. Those without hats should salute in the same manner. 3. The salute to the flag in the moving column is made at the moment the flag passes. ARTICLE IIIA. - [APPEARANCE AND CONDUCT ON DUTY AND IN PUBLIC] 1. When a man is in uniform on official business for the Fire Department, he will at all times have his coat buttoned, his hat squared on his head, a four in hand black tie, a black belt, black shined shoes and clean pressed trousers. When a fireman is on the streets he represents the City of Quitman and the entire Fire Department and his appearance and the manner in which he conducts himself is a reflection on all City Employees and Firemen. ARTICLE IV. - [EMPLOYMENT AND TRAINING REQUIREMENTS] A. Firefighter Employment and Training requirements as recommended by the Minimum Standards Council, amended and approved by the State Legislature, 10 April 1971. House Bill 1103 was further amended and passed by the Georgia State Legislature, 20 March 1980. Enclosed herewith under Article IV of these Rules and Regulations. B. 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 175/196 In order for Quitman to have a fire safe city and to carry out goals of training and drills to better educate our Firefighters; and, to have the best Fire Protection and Department that is possible for our size, the following shall be in effect upon the inception of these Rules and Regulations: Firefighters that were employed prior to 20 March 1980 and accepted (or Grand Fathered) as qualified under this Legislative Bill, shall be required to obtain a minimum of a 12th grade education, or equivalent, no longer than 12 months after the approval of these Rules and Regulations. Firefighters employed after 20 March 1980 shall be required to have a 12th grade diploma or a general education development equivalency and have 12 months to obtain. The Firefighters that are not in compliance by the time specified shall be subject to disciplinary action. Please make arrangements to have the last school attended, send to the office at your earliest convenience, the highest grade completed. C. Firefighters shall have a telephone in their homes in order that they may be reached in the event of an emergency. They will have 6 months to arrange for the installation, after the approval of these Rules and Regulations. D. Shift Captains shall be responsible for conducting a minimum of 2 hours of training and drills each duty day except Saturday and Sunday. The training shall follow the guide lines of the Fire Academy. Subject matter shall be selected by the Chief, generally for 30 days duration. Upon completion of the course an examination will be conducted and grades recorded for the Fire Academy. Shift Captains shall be certified under the Georgia Firefighter Standards of Certification #205-1-1.08, as Instructors. ARTICLE V. - GENERAL RULES AND REGULATIONS 1. The membership of the Fire Department shall be divided into three platoons, each working such hours as shall be prescribed by the Chief of the Fire Department. 2. Members are subject to call while off-duty during emergencies, and in the event that a member off-duty wishes to be away from Brooks County, he shall receive permission from his company officer before leaving. In the event more than one member of a company wishes to be away, the matter shall be referred to the Officer or Chief in charge of the shift. 3. Members of each company shall be responsible for the proper care and cleaning of their respective apparatus, handling such work as shall be assigned to them by their company officer. 4. The utmost courtesy shall be shown visitors who may desire information or are calling socially. The presence of "undesirable hanger-ons" is not to be encouraged. 5. The conduct of the men in the station shall at all times be orderly and conducted in a gentlemanly manner. No loud or boisterous talk or horseplay which may result in hard feelings or injury will be permitted. 6. Each morning after station duties have been completed men shall clean up and change to regulation uniform of the day. A member may be excused, however, to perform any permitted work. He shall change to regulation uniform when such work is completed. 7. No conversation shall be carried on through PBX or emergency station phone except such as is strictly Fire Department business and pertinent to the operation of the Fire Department. 8. The time limit on the personnel phone in the station shall be reasonable continuous use, three to four minutes. 9. Members of the Department while off duty shall so conduct themselves that they will not bring discredit to the Fire Department. A member of the Fire Department is a prominent person, and as such his conduct must be good. He must maintain a good reputation and high standard of morals. 10. A member of the Department who may feel that he is being mistreated shall have the right of appeal by the Grievance Procedure outlined in the Personnel Policy, provided the matter is handled in the proper channels. Said member shall notify his officer that he feels that he is being mistreated, and both complaint and officer shall present the case to the officer in charge, who shall rule upon the matter if he feels qualified. If not, the officer and man shall recommend that the matter be taken to the Chief of the Department. In taking the matter to the Chief, both parties shall appear before the Chief, where a decision will be made. Failure of the company officer to take the matter to the Chief shall not bar the member from doing so. Grievance procedures in Personnel Policy shall be followed. 11. Applications for transfer shall be made in writing addressed to the Chief of the Fire Department. 12. No officer or member of the Fire Department shall solicit any fee or renumeration for any service performed in line of duty. 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 176/196 13. Officers shall be addressed by their titles, and shall be referred to in the same manner when not directly addressed. 14. All members of the Department shall bear in mind the fact that they are paid employees of the City of Quitman and are paid for services which the City has the legal and moral right to demand at whatever time it becomes necessary. 15. Any member of the Fire Department failing to respond to special call, unless specifically excused, shall be subject to disciplinary action. 16. When a member is called to report for duty, due to emergency, he shall report to Station One, so that the company can be assembled and then sent to the fire or elsewhere as needed. 17. A member who is unable to report for duty due to sickness or injury shall notify his officer as soon as possible and shall furnish to the Chief's Office a certificate from the doctor who is treating him, stating the nature of the illness of injury, except in cases where there may be extenuating circumstances. 18. A member shall notify his officer of any injury to himself received in line of duty as soon as possible. Proper accident reports shall be filed in the chief's office, and if necessary the member shall be sent to the hospital or doctor for medical attention. The officer shall verbally notify the Chief or officer in charge of the shift. 19. It shall be the duty of all officers, in their discretion, to prefer charges with the Chief of the Department against any member who may be guilty of the following: (a) Neglect of duty. (b) Absence without leave. (c) Disobeying orders of a superior officer. (d) Disrespect to a superior officer. (e) Conduct prejudicial to good order. (f) Conduct unbecoming a member, either on or off duty. (g) Immorality. (h) Cowardice or shirking of duty. (i) Infraction of these rules and regulations. (j) For holding meetings of any kind at any fire station, without prior approval of the Fire Chief. 20. In the event that a member wishes to be away when he is regularly scheduled to work, it will be necessary that a "Leave of Absence" form, properly filled out and bearing the signatures of the applicant, the person who is to work in applicants place and the officer, be in the hands of the Captain or Chief at least six hours before such leave is to take place. This "Leave of Absence", covers periods of more than six hours. In the event of emergency this requirement may be waived by the Chief, or his designee. Members shall not have over one leave of absence request within any two-week period unless there is extenuating circumstances or without special permission from Chief. The relief man must be qualified and have the approval of the officer in charge. 21. The member signing a "Leave of Absence" form, wherein he agrees to work for another member, assumes responsibility for the time as stated, and failure to show up at that time will make him subject to disciplinary action. 22. 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 177/196 For permissible leaves of absence up to a period of six hours, relief must be secured, and the permission of the company officer shall be deemed sufficient. Company officers shall maintain a record of such leaves in the log book so that same may not occur too often. In the event an officer wishes to be away under the terms of this paragraph, he must obtain permission of the Chief in charge of his shift. 23. There shall be no gambling, drug abuse nor drinking of intoxicants on the station premises, nor by any member while on duty. Off duty, drugs of any kind, excessive drinking, [are] not tolerated. 24. Members on duty shall at all times remain within hearing distance of the alarm gong so that they can respond to an alarm without delay. 25. Any material needed to maintain stations in good repair, or any equipment needed for the various apparatus, shall be requisitioned by the officer in charge and submitted to the Chief. 26. No tool will be removed from any fire apparatus or other equipment for any reason except for use at a fire or to work on the apparatus. No tools will be loaned for personal use and anyone removing tools will be subject to disciplinary action. If anyone, other than the engineer, needs a tool to work on the apparatus, he must get permission from the engineer. The tools will be the direct responsibility of the engineer and he will check same each morning, and report any shortage to the officer in charge or Chief. 27. Lunch will not be served before 12:00 Noon. 28. Hair cuts: A neat hair cut will be interpreted to mean that side burns will be less than one inch wide and not extend below the earlobe. Hair length will mean a neat trim so that hair would not fall down and cover the eyes. This is to be interpreted not over two and one-half inches long. The neck hair will be trimmed so that it will not extend over the shirt collar if buttoned. 29. Mustache: Will be allowed, but must be neatly trimmed and not extended more than ¼" beyond the corners of the mouth nor shall they extend below a line horizontal with the corners of the mouth more than ¼". ARTICLE VI. - [UNIFORMS] OFFICIAL DRESS UNIFORM Dress Blue Coat Dress Blue Trousers Dress Shirts—Long or Short Sleeves Black Tie Black Shoes or Dress Boots Black Belt Dress Blue Cap OFFICIAL WORK UNIFORM Blue Overalls or Jump Suits Black Shoes or Dress Boots Caps—Nondescript Jackets—Blue Casual PROTECTIVE CLOTHING Coats, Bunker Pants, Bunker Boots Helmet and Protective Face Shield Each man is directed to have his last name on all Protective clothing. Firemen shall not wear the Fire Department uniform or any part thereof while off duty, without express permission of the Chief. ARTICLE VII. - OPERATING AT FIRES 1. Companies shall respond to alarms with the utmost dispatch consistent with careful operation and protection of the public welfare. 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 178/196 2. Drivers shall exercise caution when approaching intersections, red lights or stop streets, reducing speed to a point where a full stop can be made if necessary. 3. Upon returning for an alarm all traffic regulations must be observed. 4. There shall be no racing of apparatus on the way to a fire, nor shall one apparatus pass another, unless it is clear that the front apparatus is having mechanical trouble. The lighter Chiefs' cars, being more maneuverable, may pass when clear. 5. Upon the sounding of an alarm in the station all members on duty shall immediately report upon the apparatus floor, whether day or night, ready to proceed to the fire if need be. 6. While at fires, the greatest degree of silence compatible with efficient discharge of duty shall be required and any boisterous or noisy conduct will be sufficient cause for censure or other action by commanding officers. 7. While at fires all members shall wear the prescribed protective clothing and equipment. 8. Upon the arrival of companies at a full assignment fire, in the event the Captain or Chief is delayed, the first officer arriving shall assume charge until relieved by a superior officer, and his orders shall be respected. 9. The officers of companies arriving in response to extra alarms shall immediately contact the officer in charge of the fire to ascertain what action he may desire. 10. Incoming companies, on extra alarms, may take instructions from the Chiefs' Aide, as they are presumed to be acting under orders from the Chief in charge. 11. In answering extra alarms, either in responding to the fire or transferring to another station, companies will be governed by orders from the dispatchers. No deviation will be allowed. 12. Upon orders from the Chief, or his authority to call the off-shift, the dispatcher shall immediately assign the duty of calling to the City Hall or a volunteer fireman. In the event that another Fire Department is covering the Quitman station, the calling duty may be assigned to them. 13. Each station to which apparatus normally transfers in the event of a multiple alarm, must maintain a complete and up-to-date list of all members of the Department prominently displayed so that it can be easily found by persons not familiar with the station. 14. In the event that it is necessary to dispatch a company which is engaged in calling the off-shift, the dispatcher will immediately assign the duty of calling to another company, advising them to start at the top of the list. 15. In responding to alarms, all apparatus from the same station will follow the same route as far as possible and practical. 16. In fighting fires, the teachings of the Training School shall be followed as closely as practical. 17. Stations are furnished running cards covering their first alarm territory boxes, and will respond on first alarm without awaiting word from the dispatchers when one of these boxes is received. 18. Telephone boundary lines are eliminated and companies will follow instructions from the dispatchers in responding to alarms received over the telephone, or the City Hall. 19. Responsibility for the proper dispatching of companies rests with the dispatchers, and companies are not to question orders to respond. 20. In the event of multiple alarms the dispatcher may request assistance in the handling of his duties from any officer in charge at Headquarters, and such assistance shall be given if possible. 6/2/2019 Quitman, GA Code of Ordinances 179/196 21. In case of a working fire at the time for changing shifts, it shall be the duty of the incoming officer to check his men, and if ordered to do so, proceed to the fire location to relieve the working shift. Upon relief, however, the shift being relieved shall not leave the fire without permission of the officer in charge. 22. At a fire, upon receiving orders to take up, the company officer shall be responsible for seeing that all equipment from his apparatus is picked up and taken back to the station. 23. Upon arrival at the station, following the working fire or other emergency, the proper care shall be taken of equipment used, whether day or night. 24. It shall be the duty of the company officer to report his company back in service as soon as possible, after having been out of service for any reason. 25. Persons, other than members of the Fire Department, shall not be permitted to ride on the apparatus without permission of a member of the Chief's staff. 26. In stations where extra apparatus are kept; it shall be the duty of the company officers to see that such apparatus is kept clean, and in good running condition. 27. Should a member of a company be in the act of executing an order, and a subsequent order be given by a different officer, the member shall make known to the second officer that he is in the process of executing an order. In the event that the second officer insists that the second order be obeyed, the member shall execute the second order, but the second officer shall assume full responsibility for the change. 28. Members shall not idle or wander away from their companies. When sent for any piece of equipment the member shall secure it from his own apparatus, provided same is carried and the time element is approximately the same. 29. There shall be no smoking on apparatus at any time. Nor shall there be any smoking where there are "No Smoking" signs displayed. The nature of contents shall always be considered in deciding whether an area is restricted or not. Smoking at a fire scene may be permitted by the officer in charge. 30. Companies transferring to another area upon orders from the dispatcher shall report by radio upon leaving their station, and will proceed to the new location at normal speed, unless ordered to change to a faster rate. Sirens will not be used except on urgent instructions. 31. An engine with [an] empty booster tank does not constitute reason for being out of service, provided other equipment can be used. Booster tanks shall be filled at the nearest water supply. 32. In stations, no tools or pieces of equipment shall be removed from the apparatus for private use without permission of the Chief. 33. Hose in apparatus shall be completely changed at least quarterly, and at this time water shall be run through the hose being removed from the hose body. 34. In the event of request for assistance received from a person of authority in another locality, town or city, the dispatcher shall record the name of the person calling, his authority, and the nature of the emergency. This request will then be referred to the Chief or Acting Chief, who may authorize the dispatching of any apparatus, with concurrence of the City Manager, if he is available, or if not, the Duty Chief will make the decision. 35. Hose used on a fire after 10:00 P.M. shall be left until the following morning to be cleaned, provided it is of the cotton jacketed type and that there is sufficient reserve hose to reload. Hose of the polyester type shall be washed and reloaded on apparatus immediately following the fire. 36. Fire equipment that is used at a fire must be cleaned and put in proper place. If the fire company goes back in service after 10:00 P.M., the equipment shall be put in proper place and accounted for. The on-coming Captain shall be notified that all equipment is accounted for and must be cleaned. APPENDIX D - MUNICIPAL FEES, BONDS, AND FINES Code section Description Amount Ch. 2.
